And whoever swears an oath by heaven is swearing an oath by God's throne and by God Himself, who sits upon it.

(Matthew 23:23) 
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you carefully tithe even the smallest garden herbs like mint, dill, and cumin. Yet you have neglected the more important matters of the Law: justice, mercy, and faithfulness to God. You ought to have practiced these weightier matters without neglecting the others.

(Matthew 23:24) 
You blind guides! You strain out a gnat from your drink, yet you swallow a camel. This means you obsess over minor rules but ignore major commands of God.

(Matthew 23:25) 
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you clean the outside of the cup and the dish, but inside, they are full of greed, extortion, and impurity.

(Matthew 23:26) 
You blind Pharisee! First, clean the inside of the cup and the dish, so that the outside may also become truly clean. This is about inner spiritual purity before outward appearance.

(Matthew 23:27) 
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you are like whitewashed tombs, which appear beautiful and clean on the outside to people. But inside, they are full of the bones of the dead and every kind of filth and impurity.

(Matthew 23:28) 
In the same way, on the outside, you appear righteous to people. But inside, you are full of hypocrisy and lawlessness.

(Matthew 23:29) 
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, you hypocrites! For you build tombs for the prophets and decorate the memorials of the righteous.

(Matthew 23:30) 
And you say, 'If we had lived in the days of our ancestors, we would not have participated with them in shedding the blood of the prophets.'

(Matthew 23:31) 
So you yourselves bear witness against yourselves that you are indeed the descendants of those who murdered the prophets.

(Matthew 23:32) 
Go on, then, and fill up the measure of your ancestors' guilt.

(Matthew 23:33) 
You serpents, you brood of vipers! How will you escape the judgment of Gehenna—the place of eternal punishment?

(Matthew 23:34) 
Therefore, behold, I am sending to you prophets, wise men, and scribes. Some of them you will kill and crucify, and some of them you will flog in your synagogues, and you will persecute them from city to city.

(Matthew 23:35) 
This is so that all the righteous blood shed on the earth may come upon you, from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zechariah, son of Barachiah, whom you murdered between the Temple and the altar.

(Matthew 23:36) 
Truly, I tell you, all these things will come upon this present generation.

(Matthew 23:37) 
O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you who kill the prophets and stone those who are sent to you! How often I longed to gather your children together, just as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were unwilling to let me!

(Matthew 23:38) 
Behold, your house—meaning your Temple and your city—is being left to you desolate and deserted.

(Matthew 23:39) 
For I tell you, you will not see Me again from now on until you say, 'Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord.'

(Matthew 24:24:1) 
And as Jesus was leaving the Temple, He was going away. Then His disciples came to Him to show Him the buildings of the Temple.

(Matthew 24:24:2) 
But He, answering, said to them: "Do you see all these things? Truly, I tell you, not a single stone will be left here upon another stone that will not be thrown down (destroyed)."

(Matthew 24:24:3) 
And as He was sitting on the Mount of Olives, His disciples came to Him privately, saying: "Tell us, when will these things happen? And what will be the sign of your coming, and of the end of the age (the completion of time as we know it)?"

(Matthew 24:24:4) 
And Jesus, answering, said to them: "Be careful that no one misleads you:

(Matthew 24:24:5) 
for many will come in my name, saying: 'I am the Anointed One (the Christ)!' and they will mislead many people.

(Matthew 24:24:6) 
For you will hear of wars and rumors of wars. See that you are not alarmed; for it is necessary for these things to happen, but the end is not yet.

(Matthew 24:24:7) 
For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom; and there will be plagues (diseases), and famines, and earthquakes in various places:

(Matthew 24:24:8) 
but all these things are only the beginning of sorrows (or birth pangs).

(Matthew 24:24:9) 
Then they will hand you over to tribulation, and they will kill you; and you will be hated by all nations because of my name.

(Matthew 24:24:10) 
And then many will be scandalized (will fall away from the faith into sin or unbelief), and they will betray one another, and they will hate one another.

(Matthew 24:24:11) 
And many false prophets will rise up, and they will mislead many.

(Matthew 24:24:12) 
And because wickedness has abounded (will increase greatly), the charity (the supernatural love for God and neighbor) of many will grow cold.

(Matthew 24:24:13) 
But he who perseveres (remains steadfast in faith and good works) to the end will be saved.

(Matthew 24:24:14) 
And this Gospel (Good News) of the Kingdom will be preached throughout the whole world (the entire planet), as a testimony to all nations: and then the end (the consummation of all things) will come.

(Matthew 24:24:15) 
Therefore, when you see the abomination of desolation, which was spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing in the holy place — whoever reads, let him understand:

(Matthew 24:24:16) 
then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains:

(Matthew 24:24:17) 
and let him who is on the housetop (the flat roof of his house) not come down to take anything from his house:

(Matthew 24:24:18) 
and let him who is in the field not return to get his cloak.

(Matthew 24:24:19) 
But woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing infants in those days!

(Matthew 24:24:20) 
And pray that your flight (fleeing) may not be in winter, or on the Sabbath (when travel was restricted by religious law):

(Matthew 24:24:21) 
For then there will be great tribulation, such as has not been from the beginning of the world until now, nor ever will be.

(Matthew 24:24:22) 
And unless those days had been shortened, no living thing (no human life) would be saved: but for the sake of the elect (God's chosen people) those days will be shortened.

(Matthew 24:24:23) 
Then if anyone says to you: 'Look, here is the Anointed One (the Christ)!' or 'There!', do not believe it.

(Matthew 24:24:24) 
For false Anointed Ones (false Christs) and false prophets will arise: and they will show great signs and wonders, so as to mislead, if it were possible, even the elect (God's chosen people).

(Matthew 24:24:25) 
Behold, I have told you beforehand.

(Matthew 24:24:26) 
Therefore, if they say to you: 'Look, He is in the desert!' do not go out: 'Look, He is in the inner rooms (secret chambers)!' do not believe it.

(Matthew 24:24:27) 
For just as lightning comes from the East and flashes even to the West across the sky: so will be the coming of the Son of Man.

(Matthew 24:24:28) 
Wherever the dead body (carrion) is, there the eagles (vultures) will gather.

(Matthew 24:24:29) 
But immediately after the tribulation of those days, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light, and the stars will fall from the sky (the visible cosmos), and the celestial powers (the spiritual forces of the heavens) will be shaken.

(Matthew 24:24:30) 
And then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in the sky: and then all the tribes of the earth will mourn (lament): and they will see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of the sky, with great power and majesty.

(Matthew 24:24:31) 
And He will send His Angels with a trumpet call and a loud voice: and they will gather His elect (His chosen people) from the four winds (from all directions), from one end of the universe to the other (from the highest reaches of the cosmos to its very ends).

(Matthew 24:24:32) 
Now learn a parable (a lesson) from the fig tree: When its branch is already tender and puts forth leaves, you know that summer is near:

(Matthew 24:24:33) 
So also, when you see all these things, know that He (the time of His coming) is near, at the doors.

(Matthew 24:24:34) 
Truly, I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all these things have happened (come to pass).

(Matthew 24:24:35) 
The universe and the earth will pass away (will come to an end), but my words will not pass away (will endure forever).

(Matthew 24:24:36) 
But concerning that day and hour, no one knows, not even the Angels of the heavens (the spiritual realms), but the Father alone.

(Matthew 24:24:37) 
For just as were the days of Noah, so will be the coming of the Son of Man.

(Matthew 24:24:38) 
For as they were in the days before the flood, eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day that Noah entered the ark,

(Matthew 24:24:39) 
and they did not understand (or know) until the flood came and swept them all away: so also will be the coming of the Son of Man.

(Matthew 24:24:40) 
Then two men will be in the field: one will be taken (assumed to God), and the other will be left behind.

(Matthew 24:24:41) 
Two women will be grinding at the mill: one will be taken (assumed to God), and one will be left behind.

(Matthew 24:24:42) 
Therefore, be vigilant (keep watch), for you do not know at what hour your Lord is coming.

(Matthew 24:24:43) 
But know this, that if the master of the house had known at what hour the thief was coming, he would certainly have kept watch, and would not have allowed his house to be broken into (dug through).

(Matthew 24:24:44) 
Therefore, you also be ready: for at an hour you do not expect, the Son of Man will come.

(Matthew 24:24:45) 
Who then, do you think, is the faithful and prudent (wise) servant, whom his master has set over his household (his family), to give them food at the proper time?

(Matthew 24:24:46) 
Blessed is that servant whom his master, when he comes, will find doing so (carrying out his duty faithfully).

(Matthew 24:24:47) 
Truly, I say to you, he will set him over all his possessions (all his property).

(Matthew 24:24:48) 
But if that wicked servant says in his heart: 'My master delays his coming (is taking a long time to return):'

(Matthew 24:24:49) 
and begins to beat his fellow servants, and to eat and drink with drunkards:

(Matthew 24:24:50) 
the master of that servant will come on a day when he does not expect him, and at an hour when he does not know (is unaware):

(Matthew 24:24:51) 
and will cut him in pieces (severely punish him), and appoint his portion with the hypocrites. There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

(Matthew 25:1) 
At that time, the Kingdom of God will be compared to ten virgins who took their lamps and went out to meet the bridegroom.

(Matthew 25:2) 
Five of them were foolish, and five were wise.

(Matthew 25:3) 
The foolish ones, when they took their lamps, did not take any oil for them.

(Matthew 25:4) 
But the wise ones took oil in their containers along with their lamps.

(Matthew 25:5) 
As the bridegroom was delayed, all of them became drowsy and fell asleep.

(Matthew 25:6) 
But at midnight, a shout was heard: 'Behold, the bridegroom is coming! Go out to meet him!'

(Matthew 25:7) 
Then all those virgins got up and trimmed their lamps, preparing them to burn brightly.

(Matthew 25:8) 
But the foolish ones said to the wise, 'Give us some of your oil, because our lamps are going out.'

(Matthew 25:9) 
The wise ones answered, saying, 'No, there probably won't be enough for us and for you. Instead, go to those who sell and buy some for yourselves.'

(Matthew 25:10) 
While they were on their way to buy, the bridegroom arrived. And those who were prepared went in with him to the wedding feast, and then the door was shut.

(Matthew 25:11) 
Finally, the other virgins also came, saying, 'Lord, Lord, open the door for us!'

(Matthew 25:12) 
But he answered, saying, 'Truly, I tell you, I do not know you.'

(Matthew 25:13) 
Therefore, stay awake and be vigilant, because you do not know the day nor the hour of My return.

(Matthew 25:14) 
For it is just like a man who, going on a journey, called his servants and entrusted his possessions to them.

(Matthew 25:15) 
To one, he gave five talents—a very large sum of money or skill. To another, he gave two, and to another, one, to each according to his own ability. And then he immediately left on his journey.

(Matthew 25:16) 
Then the one who had received five talents immediately went and traded with them, and he gained another five talents.

(Matthew 25:17) 
Similarly, the one who had received two talents also gained another two.

(Matthew 25:18) 
But the one who had received one talent went and dug a hole in the ground and hid his master's money there.

(Matthew 25:19) 
Now, after a long time, the master of those servants returned and settled accounts with them, requiring each to explain how they used what was given to them.

(Matthew 25:20) 
And the one who had received five talents came forward and brought another five talents, saying, 'Master, you entrusted five talents to me. Behold, I have gained another five on top of that amount!'

(Matthew 25:21) 
His master said to him, 'Well done, good and faithful servant! Because you have been faithful in a few things, I will set you over many things. Come, enter into the joy of your master!'

(Matthew 25:22) 
Then the one who had received two talents also came forward and said, 'Master, you entrusted two talents to me. Behold, I have gained another two on top of that amount!'

(Matthew 25:23) 
His master said to him, 'Well done, good and faithful servant! Because you have been faithful in a few things, I will set you over many things. Come, enter into the joy of your master!'

(Matthew 25:24) 
Then the one who had received one talent also came forward and said, 'Master, I knew that you are a harsh man. You reap where you have not sown, and you gather where you have not scattered any seed.'

(Matthew 25:25) 
And so, out of fear, I went away and hid your talent in the ground. Behold, here you have what is yours back again.

(Matthew 25:26) 
But his master answered and said to him, 'You wicked and lazy servant! You knew that I reap where I have not sown and gather where I have not scattered!'

(Matthew 25:27) 
Therefore, you should have entrusted my money to the bankers, and then, when I returned, I would have received what is mine with interest, a profit on my investment.

(Matthew 25:28) 
So, take the talent from him and give it to the one who has ten talents.

(Matthew 25:29) 
For to everyone who has, more will be given, and he will have an abundance. But from the one who does not have, even what he seems to have will be taken away from him.

(Matthew 25:30) 
And cast this useless servant into the outer darkness, the place of suffering and separation from God. There, there will be weeping and grinding of teeth in despair.

(Matthew 25:31) 
When the Son of Man comes in His divine majesty, and all the Angels are with Him, then He will sit upon the throne of His glory.

(Matthew 25:32) 
And all the nations will be gathered before Him, and He will separate them from one another, just as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.

(Matthew 25:33) 
And He will place the sheep on His right hand, but the goats on His left.

(Matthew 25:34) 
Then the King will say to those on His right hand, 'Come, you who are blessed by My Father, inherit the Kingdom prepared for you from the very foundation of the world.'

(Matthew 25:35) 
For I was hungry, and you gave Me food to eat. I was thirsty, and you gave Me drink. I was a stranger, a foreigner in your land, and you welcomed Me into your home.

(Matthew 25:36) 
I was naked, and you clothed Me. I was sick, and you visited Me. I was in prison, and you came to Me.

(Matthew 25:37) 
Then the righteous will answer Him, saying, 'Lord, when did we see You hungry and feed You, or thirsty and give You drink?'

(Matthew 25:38) 
Or when did we see You a stranger and welcome You in, or naked and clothe You?

(Matthew 25:39) 
Or when did we see You sick or in prison and come to You?

(Matthew 25:40) 
And the King will answer and say to them, 'Truly, I tell you, just as you did it for one of the least of these, My brothers and sisters in faith, you did it for Me.'

(Matthew 25:41) 
Then He will also say to those on His left, 'Depart from Me, you who are cursed, into the eternal fire which was prepared for the devil and his angels, not for you.'

(Matthew 25:42) 
For I was hungry, and you gave Me no food to eat. I was thirsty, and you gave Me no drink.

(Matthew 25:43) 
I was a stranger, a foreigner, and you did not welcome Me in. I was naked, and you did not clothe Me. I was sick and in prison, and you did not visit Me.

(Matthew 25:44) 
Then they also will answer Him, saying, 'Lord, when did we see You hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison, and fail to minister to Your needs?'

(Matthew 25:45) 
Then He will answer them, saying, 'Truly, I tell you, just as you did not do it for one of the least of these My brothers and sisters, you did not do it for Me.'

(Matthew 25:46) 
And these will go away into eternal punishment, the ultimate consequence of their choices, but the righteous will go into eternal life, the unending union with God.

(Matthew 26:26:1) 
It came to pass that when Jesus had finished all these discourses, He said to His disciples:

(Matthew 26:26:2) 
“You know that the Passover is coming in two days, and the Son of Man will be delivered over to be crucified.”

(Matthew 26:26:3) 
Then the chief priests and the elders of the people gathered in the courtyard of the high priest, who was named Caiaphas.

(Matthew 26:26:4) 
And they formed a plan to seize Jesus by cunning and kill Him.

(Matthew 26:26:5) 
However, they were saying: “Not during the festival, lest there be a riot among the people.”

(Matthew 26:26:6) 
Now, when Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,

(Matthew 26:26:7) 
a woman came to Him with an alabaster jar of very expensive ointment, and she poured it over His head as He was reclining at the table.

(Matthew 26:26:8) 
When the disciples saw this, they were indignant, saying: “Why this waste?

(Matthew 26:26:9) 
This ointment could have been sold for a large sum and given to the poor.”

(Matthew 26:26:10) 
But Jesus, knowing their thoughts, said to them: “Why are you troubling this woman? For she has done a good work for me.

(Matthew 26:26:11) 
For you always have the poor with you, but you will not always have me.

(Matthew 26:26:12) 
For by pouring this ointment on my body, she has done this as preparation for my burial.

(Matthew 26:26:13) 
Amen, I say to you, wherever this Gospel is preached in the whole world, what she has done will also be spoken of in memory of her.”

(Matthew 26:26:14) 
Then one of the twelve disciples, named Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests.

(Matthew 26:26:15) 
And he said to them: “What are you willing to give me, and I will deliver Him to you?” And they weighed out and agreed to give him thirty pieces of silver.

(Matthew 26:26:16) 
And from that time on, he sought an opportunity to betray Jesus.

(Matthew 26:26:17) 
Now, on the first day of Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Jesus, saying: “Where do you want us to prepare for you to eat the Passover meal?”

(Matthew 26:26:18) 
But Jesus said: “Go into the city to a certain man and say to him: ‘The Teacher says: My time is near; I will keep the Passover at your house with my disciples.’”

(Matthew 26:26:19) 
And the disciples did as Jesus had instructed them, and they prepared the Passover.

(Matthew 26:26:20) 
When evening came, He was reclining at table with the twelve disciples.

(Matthew 26:26:21) 
And as they were eating, He said: “Amen, I say to you, one of you will betray me.”

(Matthew 26:26:22) 
And they were exceedingly sorrowful, and each one began to say: “Surely it is not I, Lord?”

(Matthew 26:26:23) 
But He answered and said: “The one who dips his hand with me into the dish, he will betray me.”

(Matthew 26:26:24) 
“The Son of Man indeed goes, just as it is written concerning Him; but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would have been better for that man if he had never been born.”

(Matthew 26:26:25) 
Then Judas, who was betraying Him, responded and said: “Surely it is not I, Rabbi?” Jesus said to him: “You have said it.”

(Matthew 26:26:26) 
Now as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed it, and broke it, and gave it to His disciples, and said: “Take and eat; this is my Body.”

(Matthew 26:26:27) 
And taking the chalice, He gave thanks, and gave it to them, saying: “Drink from this, all of you.”

(Matthew 26:26:28) 
“For this is my Blood of the New Covenant, which will be poured out for many unto the remission of sins.”

(Matthew 26:26:29) 
“And I say to you: I will not drink from this fruit of the vine from now on, until that day when I drink it new with you in the Kingdom of my Father.”

(Matthew 26:26:30) 
And after singing a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.

(Matthew 26:26:31) 
Then Jesus said to them: “All of you will stumble because of me this very night. For it is written: ‘I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.’”

(Matthew 26:26:32) 
“But after I have risen, I will go before you into Galilee.”

(Matthew 26:26:33) 
Peter responded and said to Him: “Even if all others stumble because of you, I will never stumble.”

(Matthew 26:26:34) 
Jesus said to him: “Amen, I say to you, that on this very night, before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times.”

(Matthew 26:26:35) 
Peter said to Him: “Even if I must die with you, I will not deny you.” And all the disciples said the same.

(Matthew 26:26:36) 
Then Jesus came with them to a country estate called Gethsemane, and He said to His disciples: “Sit here while I go over there and pray.”

(Matthew 26:26:37) 
And taking Peter and the two sons of Zebedee with Him, He began to be sorrowful and distressed.

(Matthew 26:26:38) 
Then He said to them: “My soul is sorrowful, even to the point of death. Remain here and keep watch with me.”

(Matthew 26:26:39) 
And going forward a little, He fell on His face, praying and saying: “My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass from me. Yet, not as I will, but as you will.”

(Matthew 26:26:40) 
And He came to His disciples and found them sleeping, and He said to Peter: “So, could you not keep watch with me for one hour?”

(Matthew 26:26:41) 
“Keep watch and pray, so that you do not fall into temptation. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak.”

(Matthew 26:26:42) 
Again, a second time, He went away and prayed, saying: “My Father, if this cup cannot pass away unless I drink it, then your will be done.”

(Matthew 26:26:43) 
And He came again and found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.

(Matthew 26:26:44) 
And leaving them again, He went away and prayed a third time, saying the same words.

(Matthew 26:26:45) 
Then He came to His disciples and said to them: “Sleep now and take your rest. Behold, the hour has drawn near, and the Son of Man will be delivered into the hands of sinners.”

(Matthew 26:26:46) 
“Rise, let us go! Behold, he who is betraying me has drawn near.”

(Matthew 26:26:47) 
And while He was still speaking, behold, Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a large crowd with swords and clubs, sent by the chief priests and the elders of the people.

(Matthew 26:26:48) 
Now the one who was betraying Him had given them a sign, saying: “Whomever I kiss, that is He; seize Him.”

(Matthew 26:26:49) 
And immediately he came to Jesus and said: “Hail, Rabbi!” And he kissed Him.

(Matthew 26:26:50) 
Jesus said to him: “Friend, for what purpose have you come?” Then they came forward, laid hands on Jesus, and seized Him.

(Matthew 26:26:51) 
And behold, one of those who were with Jesus stretched out his hand, drew his sword, and striking the servant of the high priest, cut off his ear.

(Matthew 26:26:52) 
Then Jesus said to him: “Return your sword to its place, for all who take up the sword will perish by the sword.”

(Matthew 26:26:53) 
“Do you think that I cannot appeal to my Father, and He would immediately send me more than twelve legions of angels?”

(Matthew 26:26:54) 
“How then would the Scriptures be fulfilled, which say that it must happen in this way?”

(Matthew 26:26:55) 
At that very hour, Jesus said to the crowds: “Have you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs, to apprehend me? Day after day I sat teaching among you in the Temple, and you did not seize me.”

(Matthew 26:26:56) 
“But all this has happened so that the Scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled.” Then all the disciples deserted Him and fled.

(Matthew 26:26:57) 
Then those who had seized Jesus led Him to Caiaphas, the high priest, where the scribes and elders were gathered.

(Matthew 26:26:58) 
But Peter followed Him at a distance, as far as the courtyard of the high priest. And he went inside and sat with the servants to see the outcome.

(Matthew 26:26:59) 
Now the chief priests and the entire council were seeking false testimony against Jesus, so that they might put Him to death.

(Matthew 26:26:60) 
But they found none, though many false witnesses came forward. At last, however, two false witnesses came,

(Matthew 26:26:61) 
and they said: “This man said: ‘I can destroy the Temple of God and rebuild it in three days.’”

(Matthew 26:26:62) 
And the high priest stood up and said to Him: “Do you answer nothing concerning what these men testify against you?”

(Matthew 26:26:63) 
But Jesus remained silent. And the high priest said to Him: “I put you under oath by the Living God, that you tell us if you are the Christ, the Son of God.”

(Matthew 26:26:64) 
Jesus said to him: “You have said it. Nevertheless, I say to you, from now on you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the Power of God, and coming on the clouds of the sky.”

(Matthew 26:26:65) 
Then the high priest tore his garments, saying: “He has blasphemed! What further need do we have of witnesses? Behold, now you have heard the blasphemy.

(Matthew 26:26:66) 
What do you think?” And they answered and said: “He is guilty of death.”

(Matthew 26:26:67) 
Then they spit in His face and struck Him with their fists. Others slapped Him in the face,

(Matthew 26:26:68) 
saying: “Prophesy to us, O Christ! Who is it that struck you?”

(Matthew 26:26:69) 
Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard. And a servant girl came to him, saying: “You also were with Jesus the Galilean.”

(Matthew 26:26:70) 
But he denied it before everyone, saying: “I do not know what you are talking about.”

(Matthew 26:26:71) 
And when he went out to the gateway, another servant girl saw him and said to those who were there: “This man also was with Jesus of Nazareth.”

(Matthew 26:26:72) 
And again he denied it with an oath: “I do not know the man!”

(Matthew 26:26:73) 
And after a little while, those who were standing by came and said to Peter: “Certainly, you too are one of them, for your dialect and accent betray you.”

(Matthew 26:26:74) 
Then he began to curse and swear, saying that he did not know the man. And immediately the rooster crowed.

(Matthew 26:26:75) 
And Peter remembered the word of Jesus, which He had said: “Before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times.” And going outside, he wept bitterly.

(Matthew 27:1) 
When morning came, all the chief priests and the elders of the people met together to conspire against Jesus and to put Him to death.

(Matthew 27:2) 
They bound Him, led Him away, and gave Him over to Pontius Pilate, the governor.

(Matthew 27:3) 
When Judas, who betrayed Him, saw that Jesus was condemned, he regretted what he had done and returned the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and the elders,

(Matthew 27:4) 
saying, "I have sinned by betraying innocent blood." But they said, "What is that to us? You take care of it."

(Matthew 27:5) 
So Judas threw the silver into the temple, left, and went and hanged himself.

(Matthew 27:6) 
The chief priests took the silver and said, "It is not lawful to put this money into the treasury, since it is blood money."

(Matthew 27:7) 
They conferred and bought the potter's field with the money, to be used as a burial place for strangers.

(Matthew 27:8) 
Therefore, that field has been called the Field of Blood to this day.

(Matthew 27:9) 
Then what was spoken by the prophet Jeremiah was fulfilled: "And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of the one whose worth was set by the sons of Israel,

(Matthew 27:10) 
and they gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord commanded me."

(Matthew 27:11) 
Jesus stood before the governor, and the governor asked Him, "Are you the King of the Jews?" Jesus said to him, "You have said it."

(Matthew 27:12) 
But when He was accused by the chief priests and the elders, He made no reply.

(Matthew 27:13) 
Then Pilate said to Him, "Do you not hear how many things they are accusing You of?"

(Matthew 27:14) 
But He did not answer him one word, so the governor was greatly amazed.

(Matthew 27:15) 
Now at the feast the governor was accustomed to release for the people one prisoner whom they wanted.

(Matthew 27:16) 
At that time they had a notorious prisoner called Barabbas.

(Matthew 27:17) 
So when they had gathered, Pilate said to them, "Whom do you want me to release for you: Barabbas, or Jesus who is called Christ?"

(Matthew 27:18) 
For he knew that they had handed Him over because of envy.

(Matthew 27:19) 
While he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent him a message, saying, "Have nothing to do with that righteous man, because I have suffered many things today in a dream because of Him."

(Matthew 27:20) 
But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the crowds to ask for Barabbas and to have Jesus put to death.

(Matthew 27:21) 
The governor said to them, "Which of the two do you want me to release for you?" And they said, "Barabbas."

(Matthew 27:22) 
Pilate said to them, "Then what shall I do with Jesus who is called Christ?" They all said, "Let Him be crucified."

(Matthew 27:23) 
The governor said, "Why? What evil has He done?" But they kept shouting all the more, saying, "Let Him be crucified."

(Matthew 27:24) 
When Pilate saw that he was accomplishing nothing, but rather that a riot was starting, he took water and washed his hands before the crowd, saying, "I am innocent of this Man’s blood; see to it yourselves."

(Matthew 27:25) 
And all the people answered, "His blood be on us and on our children!"

(Matthew 27:26) 
Then he released Barabbas for them; but Jesus he scourged and handed over to be crucified.

(Matthew 27:27) 
Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the Praetorium and gathered the whole cohort around Him.

(Matthew 27:28) 
And they stripped Him and put a scarlet robe on Him.

(Matthew 27:29) 
And they twisted together a crown of thorns and put it on His head, and put a reed in His right hand; and they knelt down before Him and mocked Him, saying, "Hail, King of the Jews!"

(Matthew 27:30) 
And they spat on Him, and took the reed and began to beat Him on the head.

(Matthew 27:31) 
After they had mocked Him, they took the robe off Him and put His own garments back on Him, and led Him away to crucify Him.

(Matthew 27:32) 
As they were going out, they found a man of Cyrene named Simon, and they forced him to carry His cross.

(Matthew 27:33) 
And when they came to a place called Golgotha, which means Place of a Skull,

(Matthew 27:34) 
they gave Him wine to drink mixed with gall; but after tasting it, He was unwilling to drink.

(Matthew 27:35) 
And when they had crucified Him, they divided His garments among themselves by casting lots. This was to fulfill what was spoken by the prophet: "They divided My garments among themselves, and for My clothing they cast lots."

(Matthew 27:36) 
And sitting down, they were guarding Him there.

(Matthew 27:37) 
And above His head they put up the charge against Him, which read, "THIS IS JESUS, THE KING OF THE JEWS."

(Matthew 27:38) 
Then two robbers were crucified with Him, one on the right and one on the left.

(Matthew 27:39) 
And those passing by were hurling abuse at Him, wagging their heads

(Matthew 27:40) 
and saying, "You who are going to destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days, save Yourself! If You are the Son of God, come down from the cross."

(Matthew 27:41) 
In the same way the chief priests also, along with the scribes and elders, were mocking Him and saying,

(Matthew 27:42) 
"He saved others; He cannot save Himself. He is the King of Israel; let Him now come down from the cross, and we will believe in Him."

(Matthew 27:43) 
"He trusts in God; let God rescue Him now, if He delights in Him; for He said, 'I am the Son of God.'"

(Matthew 27:44) 
The robbers who were crucified with Him were also insulting Him in the same way.

(Matthew 27:45) 
From the sixth hour until the ninth hour, darkness came over all the land.

(Matthew 27:46) 
And about the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, "ELI, ELI, LAMA SABACHTHANI?" that is, "MY GOD, MY GOD, WHY HAVE YOU FORSAKEN ME?"

(Matthew 27:47) 
And some of those who were standing there, when they heard it, were saying, "This man is calling for Elijah."

(Matthew 27:48) 
Immediately one of them ran, and taking a sponge, he filled it with sour wine and put it on a reed, and gave Him a drink.

(Matthew 27:49) 
But the rest said, "Let us see whether Elijah will come to save Him."

(Matthew 27:50) 
And Jesus cried out again with a loud voice, and yielded up His spirit.

(Matthew 27:51) 
And behold, the veil of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom, and the earth shook; and the rocks were split,

(Matthew 27:52) 
and the tombs were opened; and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised;

(Matthew 27:53) 
and coming out of the tombs after His resurrection they entered the holy city and appeared to many.

(Matthew 27:54) 
Now the centurion, and those who were with him keeping watch over Jesus, when they saw the earthquake and the things that were happening, became very frightened and said, "Truly this was the Son of God!"

(Matthew 27:55) 
Many women were there, looking on from a distance, who had followed Jesus from Galilee, ministering to Him.

(Matthew 27:56) 
Among them were Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.

(Matthew 27:57) 
When it was evening, there came a rich man from Arimathea, named Joseph, who himself had also become a disciple of Jesus.

(Matthew 27:58) 
This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus. Then Pilate ordered it to be given to him.

(Matthew 27:59) 
And Joseph took the body and wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,

(Matthew 27:60) 
and laid it in his own new tomb, which he had hewn out in the rock; and he rolled a large stone against the entrance of the tomb and went away.

(Matthew 27:61) 
And Mary Magdalene was there, and the other Mary, sitting opposite the tomb.

(Matthew 27:62) 
Now on the next day, which is the day after the Preparation, the chief priests and the Pharisees gathered together with Pilate,

(Matthew 27:63) 
and said, "Sir, we remember that when He was still alive that deceiver said, 'After three days I am to rise again.'

(Matthew 27:64) 
"So give orders for the tomb to be made secure until the third day, otherwise His disciples may come and steal Him away and say to the people, 'He has risen from the dead,' and the last deception will be worse than the first."

(Matthew 27:65) 
Pilate said to them, "You have a guard; go, make it as secure as you know how."

(Matthew 27:66) 
And they went and made the tomb secure, and sealed the stone, along with the guard.

(Matthew 28:1) 
Late on the Sabbath, as the first day of the week began to dawn, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to see the tomb.

(Matthew 28:2) 
Suddenly, there was a great earthquake, because an angel of the Lord descended from the universe. He approached the tomb, rolled back the stone, and sat upon it.

(Matthew 28:3) 
His appearance was like lightning, and his clothing was as white as snow.

(Matthew 28:4) 
Because the guards were so terrified of him, they were terrified and became like dead men.

(Matthew 28:5) 
The angel spoke to the women, saying, “Do not be afraid. I know that you are looking for Jesus, who was crucified.

(Matthew 28:6) 
He isn’t here. He has risen, just as He said. Come and see the place where the Lord was lying.

(Matthew 28:7) 
Then go quickly, and tell His disciples that He has risen. He is going ahead of you to Galilee. You will see Him there. Behold, I have told you.”

(Matthew 28:8) 
So the women left the tomb quickly, with fear and great joy. They ran to tell His disciples.

(Matthew 28:9) 
Suddenly, Jesus met them, saying, “Greetings!” They approached, held onto His feet, and worshipped Him.

(Matthew 28:10) 
Then Jesus said to them, “Do not be afraid. Go and tell My brothers to go to Galilee, and they will see Me there.”

(Matthew 28:11) 
While they were on their way, some of the guard came into the city and reported to the chief priests everything that had happened.

(Matthew 28:12) 
When they had assembled with the elders, they took counsel and gave a large sum of money to the soldiers,

(Matthew 28:13) 
saying, “Tell everyone, ‘His disciples came by night and stole Him away while we were sleeping.’

(Matthew 28:14) 
And if the governor hears about this, we will persuade him and keep you out of trouble.”

(Matthew 28:15) 
So the soldiers took the money and did as they were instructed. And this story has been spread among the Jews to this day.

(Matthew 28:16) 
The eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain where Jesus had instructed them to go.

(Matthew 28:17) 
And when they saw Him, they worshipped Him, though some still doubted.

(Matthew 28:18) 
Jesus came near and spoke to them, saying, “All power in the universe and on earth has been given to Me.

(Matthew 28:19) 
Therefore, go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit,

(Matthew 28:20) 
teaching them to observe all that I have commanded you. And remember, I am with you always, even until the end of the age.”

(Mark 1:1) 
The beginning of the Gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.

(Mark 1:2) 
Just as it is written in Isaiah the prophet: “Behold, I send my angel before your face, who will prepare your way before you.”

(Mark 1:3) 
The voice of one crying in the desert: “Prepare the way of the Lord, make straight his paths.”

(Mark 1:4) 
John was in the desert, baptizing and preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.

(Mark 1:5) 
And all the land of Judea and all the people of Jerusalem went out to him, and were baptized by him in the river Jordan, confessing their sins.

(Mark 1:6) 
And John was clothed in camel’s hair and wore a leather belt around his waist, and he ate locusts and wild honey.

(Mark 1:7) 
And he preached, saying: “There comes after me the One who is mightier than I, the strap of whose sandals I am not worthy to stoop down and loosen.”

(Mark 1:8) 
I have baptized you in water, but he will baptize you in the Holy Spirit.”

(Mark 1:9) 
And it came to pass in those days that Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee and was baptized by John in the Jordan.

(Mark 1:10) 
And immediately, coming up out of the water, he saw the heavens being torn open, and the Spirit descending upon him like a dove.

(Mark 1:11) 
And there came a voice from the heavens: “You are my beloved Son; in you I am well pleased.”

(Mark 1:12) 
And immediately the Spirit drove him out into the desert.

(Mark 1:13) 
And he was in the desert forty days, being tempted by Satan; and he was with the beasts, and the angels ministered to him.

(Mark 1:14) 
And after John was delivered up, Jesus came into Galilee, preaching the Gospel of the kingdom of God,

(Mark 1:15) 
and saying, “The time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of God is at hand; repent and believe in the Gospel.”

(Mark 1:16) 
And passing along by the sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and Andrew his brother casting a net into the sea, for they were fishermen.

(Mark 1:17) 
And Jesus said to them: “Come after me, and I will make you become fishers of men.”

(Mark 1:18) 
And immediately they left their nets and followed him.

(Mark 1:19) 
And going on a little further, he saw James the son of Zebedee and John his brother, who were also in the boat mending the nets.

(Mark 1:20) 
And immediately he called them. And they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired men and followed him.

(Mark 1:21) 
And they went into Capernaum, and immediately on the Sabbath, he entered the synagogue and began to teach.

(Mark 1:22) 
And they were astonished at his teaching, for he taught them as one having authority, and not as the scribes.

(Mark 1:23) 
And immediately there was in their synagogue a man with an unclean spirit; and he cried out,

(Mark 1:24) 
saying: “What have we to do with you, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are, the Holy One of God.”

(Mark 1:25) 
And Jesus rebuked him, saying: “Be quiet, and come out of him.”

(Mark 1:26) 
And the unclean spirit, convulsing him and crying with a loud voice, came out of him.

(Mark 1:27) 
And they were all amazed, so that they questioned among themselves, saying: “What is this? A new teaching with authority! For he commands even the unclean spirits, and they obey him.”

(Mark 1:28) 
And at once his fame spread everywhere throughout all the region of Galilee.

(Mark 1:29) 
And immediately, when they came out of the synagogue, they went into the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John.

(Mark 1:30) 
Now Simon’s mother-in-law lay ill with a fever, and immediately they told him about her.

(Mark 1:31) 
And he came and lifted her up, taking her by the hand; and immediately the fever left her, and she served them.

(Mark 1:32) 
And when evening had come, after the sun went down, they brought to him all who were sick or possessed with demons.

(Mark 1:33) 
And the whole city was gathered together at the door.

(Mark 1:34) 
And he healed many who were sick with various diseases, and cast out many demons; and he would not allow the demons to speak, because they knew him.

(Mark 1:35) 
And in the morning, rising up a great while before day, he went out and went to a lonely place, and there he prayed.

(Mark 1:36) 
And Simon and those who were with him followed him.

(Mark 1:37) 
And when they found him, they said to him: “Everyone is looking for you.”

(Mark 1:38) 
And he said to them: “Let us go on to the next towns, that I may preach there also, for that is why I came out.”

(Mark 1:39) 
And he went throughout all Galilee, preaching in their synagogues and casting out demons.

(Mark 1:40) 
And a leper came to him, beseeching him, and kneeling said to him: “If you will, you can make me clean.”

(Mark 1:41) 
And Jesus, moved with pity, stretched out his hand and touched him and said to him, “I will; be clean.”

(Mark 1:42) 
And immediately the leprosy left him, and he was made clean.

(Mark 1:43) 
And immediately he sternly warned him and sent him away,

(Mark 1:44) 
and said to him: “See that you say nothing to anyone, but go, show yourself to the priest, and offer for your cleansing what Moses commanded, for a proof to them.”

(Mark 1:45) 
But he went out and began to proclaim it freely and to spread the word, so that Jesus could no longer openly enter a town, but was out in desolate places, and people were coming to him from every quarter.

(Mark 2:1) 
Jesus returned to Capernaum a few days later.

(Mark 2:2) 
The news spread that he was at home.

(Mark 2:3) 
A crowd gathered, so many that there was no room left, not even near the door. Jesus began to preach the word of God to them.

(Mark 2:4) 
Some men arrived, carrying a paralytic. The men carried him.

(Mark 2:5) 
Because of the crowd, they couldn't bring him to Jesus. So, they uncovered the roof above where Jesus was and made an opening, then they lowered the man on his mat.

(Mark 2:6) 
Seeing their faith, Jesus said to the paralytic, “Son, your sins are forgiven.”

(Mark 2:7) 
Some scribes were sitting there, and they began to think to themselves:

(Mark 2:8) 
“Why does this man speak like this? He's blaspheming! Who can forgive sins except God alone?”

(Mark 2:9) 
Jesus, immediately aware in his spirit that they were thinking this, said to them, “Why are you thinking these things in your hearts?”

(Mark 2:10) 
“Which is easier: to tell the paralytic, ‘Your sins are forgiven,’ or to say, ‘Get up, pick up your mat, and walk’?”

(Mark 2:11) 
“But so that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins”—He said to the paralytic,

(Mark 2:12) 
“I tell you, get up, pick up your mat, and go home.”

(Mark 2:13) 
He got up immediately, took his mat, and walked out in front of everyone. They were all amazed and praised God, saying, “We have never seen anything like this!”

(Mark 2:14) 
Jesus went out again to the sea, and the whole crowd came to him, and he began to teach them.

(Mark 2:15) 
As he was walking along, he saw Levi, son of Alphaeus, sitting at the tax booth, and he said to him, “Follow me.” And he got up and followed him.

(Mark 2:16) 
While Jesus was having dinner at Levi’s house, many tax collectors and sinners were eating with him and his disciples, for there were many who followed him.

(Mark 2:17) 
When the scribes and the Pharisees saw that he was eating with sinners and tax collectors, they said to his disciples, “Why does he eat with tax collectors and sinners?”

(Mark 2:18) 
Hearing this, Jesus said to them, “Those who are well do not need a physician, but the sick do. I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners.”

(Mark 2:19) 
John’s disciples and the Pharisees were fasting. They came to Jesus and asked, “Why do John’s disciples and the disciples of the Pharisees fast, but your disciples don’t fast?”

(Mark 2:20) 
Jesus said to them, “Can the wedding guests fast while the bridegroom is with them?

(Mark 2:21) 
As long as they have the bridegroom with them, they cannot fast.

(Mark 2:22) 
But the days will come when the bridegroom will be taken from them, and on that day they will fast.

(Mark 2:23) 
“No one sews a patch of unshrunk cloth on an old garment. Otherwise, the new piece tears away from the old, and the tear becomes worse.

(Mark 2:24) 
And no one puts new wine into old wineskins. Otherwise, the wine will burst the skins, and both the wine and the skins will be ruined. Instead, new wine is to be put into new wineskins.”

(Mark 2:25) 
One Sabbath, as Jesus was walking through the grainfields, his disciples began to pick some heads of grain.

(Mark 2:26) 
The Pharisees said to him, “Look, why are they doing what is unlawful on the Sabbath?”

(Mark 2:27) 
He answered them, “Have you never read what David did when he and his companions were hungry and in need?

(Mark 2:28) 
He entered the house of God in the time of Abiathar the high priest and ate the consecrated bread, which is lawful only for the priests to eat, and he also gave some to his companions.”

(Mark 3:1) 
Again, He entered the synagogue. And there was a man there whose hand was shriveled.

(Mark 3:2) 
And they watched Him to see if He would heal on the Sabbath so that they could accuse Him.

(Mark 3:3) 
And He said to the man with the shriveled hand, “Stand up in the middle.”

(Mark 3:4) 
And He said to them, “Is it lawful to do good on the Sabbath, or to do evil? To save a life, or to kill?” But they were silent.

(Mark 3:5) 
And looking around at them with anger, grieved by the hardness of their hearts, He said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” And he stretched it out; and his hand was restored.

(Mark 3:6) 
And immediately the Pharisees, along with the Herodians, went out and began to conspire against Him, as to how they might destroy Him.

(Mark 3:7) 
And Jesus withdrew with His disciples to the sea. And a large crowd from Galilee and Judea followed Him,

(Mark 3:8) 
and from Jerusalem, and from Idumea, and beyond the Jordan. And those near Tyre and Sidon, a great crowd, hearing all that He was doing, came to Him.

(Mark 3:9) 
And He told His disciples that a small boat should be ready for Him because of the crowd, lest they crush Him.

(Mark 3:10) 
For He healed many, so that all those who had afflictions were pressing Him in order to touch Him.

(Mark 3:11) 
And whenever the unclean spirits saw Him, they would fall down before Him and cry out, saying, “You are the Son of God!”

(Mark 3:12) 
And He sternly warned them not to make Him known.

(Mark 3:13) 
And going up on the mountain, He called to Him those whom He Himself willed, and they came to Him.

(Mark 3:14) 
And He appointed twelve, that they might be with Him and that He might send them out to preach,

(Mark 3:15) 
and have authority to cast out demons.

(Mark 3:16) 
And He appointed Simon, to whom He gave the name Peter;

(Mark 3:17) 
and James the son of Zebedee, and John the brother of James, to whom He gave the name Boanerges, which is, Sons of Thunder;

(Mark 3:18) 
and Andrew, and Philip, and Bartholomew, and Matthew, and Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus, and Simon the Zealot,

(Mark 3:19) 
and Judas Iscariot, who betrayed Him.

(Mark 3:20) 
And He went home. And the crowd gathered again, so that they could not even eat a meal.

(Mark 3:21) 
And when His family heard it, they went out to seize Him, for they were saying, “He is out of His mind.”

(Mark 3:22) 
And the scribes who came down from Jerusalem were saying, “He has Beelzebul,” and, “By the prince of demons He casts out demons.”

(Mark 3:23) 
And He called them to Himself and began to speak to them in parables: “How can Satan cast out Satan?

(Mark 3:24) 
And if a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand.

(Mark 3:25) 
And if a house is divided against itself, that house will not be able to stand.

(Mark 3:26) 
And if Satan has risen up against himself and is divided, he cannot stand, but has an end.

(Mark 3:27) 
But no one can enter a strong man's house and plunder his goods unless he first binds the strong man, and then he will plunder his house.

(Mark 3:28) 
“Truly, I say to you, all sins will be forgiven the sons of men, and whatever blasphemies they utter,

(Mark 3:29) 
but whoever blasphemes against the Holy Spirit never has forgiveness, but is guilty of an eternal sin.”

(Mark 3:30) 
For they were saying, “He has an unclean spirit.”

(Mark 3:31) 
And His mother and His brothers came, and standing outside, they sent to Him, calling Him.

(Mark 3:32) 
And a crowd was sitting around Him, and they said to Him, “Your mother and Your brothers are outside, seeking You.”

(Mark 3:33) 
And answering them, He said, “Who is My mother, and who are My brothers?”

(Mark 3:34) 
And looking around at those who sat around Him, He said, “Here are My mother and My brothers!

(Mark 3:35) 
For whoever does the will of God, he is My brother and sister and mother.”

(Mark 4:1) 
And again, He began to teach by the sea. And a great crowd gathered around Him, so that He entered a boat and sat on the sea. And all the crowd was on the land near the sea.

(Mark 4:2) 
And He taught them many things in parables, and said to them in His teaching:

(Mark 4:3) 
Listen: behold, a sower went out to sow.

(Mark 4:4) 
And as he sowed, some seed fell by the wayside, and the birds of the sky came and ate it up.

(Mark 4:5) 
And some fell upon stony ground where it did not have much earth, and immediately it sprang up because it had no depth of earth.

(Mark 4:6) 
And when the sun rose, it was scorched; and because it had no root, it withered.

(Mark 4:7) 
And some fell among thorns, and the thorns sprang up and choked it, and it yielded no fruit.

(Mark 4:8) 
And some fell on good ground and yielded fruit that sprang up and increased, and produced, some thirtyfold, some sixtyfold, and some a hundredfold.

(Mark 4:9) 
And He said, “He who has ears to hear, let him hear.”

(Mark 4:10) 
And when He was alone, those around Him with the twelve asked Him about the parable.

(Mark 4:11) 
And He said to them, “To you has been given to know the mystery of the kingdom of God, but to those who are outside, all things are done in parables,

(Mark 4:12) 
so that seeing they may see and not perceive, and hearing they may hear and not understand, lest they should turn and their sins be forgiven them.”

(Mark 4:13) 
And He said to them, “Do you not understand this parable? How then will you understand all the parables?

(Mark 4:14) 
The sower sows the word.

(Mark 4:15) 
And these are the ones by the wayside, where the word is sown. And immediately Satan comes and takes away the word that was sown in their hearts.

(Mark 4:16) 
And these are the ones sown on stony ground: who, when they have heard the word, immediately receive it with joy.

(Mark 4:17) 
And they have no root in themselves, but are temporary. Afterward, when tribulation or persecution arises because of the word, immediately they are scandalized.

(Mark 4:18) 
And these are the ones sown among thorns: they are those who hear the word,

(Mark 4:19) 
and the cares of the world, the deceitfulness of riches, and the desires for other things enter in and choke the word, and it becomes unfruitful.

(Mark 4:20) 
And those are the ones sown on good ground: who hear the word and receive it, and bear fruit, some thirtyfold, some sixtyfold, and some a hundredfold.”

(Mark 4:21) 
And He said to them, “Does a lamp come to be put under a basket, or under a bed? Is it not to be put on a lampstand?

(Mark 4:22) 
For there is nothing hidden that will not be revealed, nor was anything made secret, but that it should come to light.

(Mark 4:23) 
If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear.”

(Mark 4:24) 
And He said to them, “Take heed what you hear. With whatever measure you measure, it will be measured to you; and to you who hear, more will be added.

(Mark 4:25) 
For whoever has, to him more will be given; and whoever does not have, even what he has will be taken away from him.”

(Mark 4:26) 
And He said, “The kingdom of God is like a man who casts seed on the earth,

(Mark 4:27) 
and sleeps and rises night and day, and the seed sprouts and grows, though he does not know how.

(Mark 4:28) 
For the earth bears fruit of itself: first the blade, then the head, and then the full grain in the head.

(Mark 4:29) 
But when the grain is ripe, immediately he puts in the sickle, because the harvest has come.”

(Mark 4:30) 
And He said, “To what shall we compare the kingdom of God? Or with what parable will we present it?

(Mark 4:31) 
It is like a mustard seed which, when sown on the ground, is the smallest of all the seeds on earth;

(Mark 4:32) 
but when it is sown, it grows up and becomes greater than all herbs, and shoots out large branches, so that the birds of the sky can dwell under its shade.”

(Mark 4:33) 
And with many such parables, He spoke the word to them as they were able to hear it.

(Mark 4:34) 
But without a parable, He did not speak to them. But privately to His own disciples, He explained everything.

(Mark 4:35) 
And on that day, when evening had come, He said to them, “Let us pass over to the other side.”

(Mark 4:36) 
And leaving the crowd, they took Him along in the boat, and there were also other boats with Him.

(Mark 4:37) 
And a great windstorm arose, and the waves were breaking into the boat, so that it was already filling.

(Mark 4:38) 
But He was in the stern, asleep on a cushion. And they awoke Him and said to Him, “Teacher, do you not care that we are perishing?”

(Mark 4:39) 
Then He arose and rebuked the wind, and said to the sea, “Peace! Be still!” And the wind ceased and there was a great calm.

(Mark 4:40) 
And He said to them, “Why are you so fearful? How is it that you have no faith?”

(Mark 4:41) 
And they feared exceedingly, and said to one another, “Who can this be, that even the wind and the sea obey Him?”

(Mark 5:1) 
They went to the sea in the territory of the Gerasenes. As soon as He disembarked from the boat, a man possessed by an evil spirit met Him there from the tombs,

(Mark 5:2) 
The man lived in the tombs. No one could bind him anymore, not even with chains.

(Mark 5:3) 
Often he had been bound with shackles and chains. But he would tear apart the chains and break the shackles, and no one could control him.

(Mark 5:4) 
Day and night among the tombs and in the mountains, he was constantly shouting and cutting himself with stones.

(Mark 5:5) 
Seeing Jesus from afar, he ran to Him and bowed down,

(Mark 5:6) 
shouting in a loud voice, “What have You to do with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I implore You by God, do not torment me.”

(Mark 5:7) 
Jesus was already saying to him, “Come out, unclean spirit, from this man.”

(Mark 5:8) 
Jesus asked him, “What is your name?” He replied, “My name is Legion, for we are many.”

(Mark 5:9) 
And he begged Jesus again and again not to send them out of the area.

(Mark 5:10) 
A large herd of swine was feeding there on the hillside.

(Mark 5:11) 
And the spirits begged Him, saying, “Send us into the swine so that we may enter them.”

(Mark 5:12) 
Jesus gave them permission, and the unclean spirits came out and entered the swine. The herd, about two thousand in number, rushed down the steep bank into the sea and were drowned there.

(Mark 5:13) 
Those who were tending them ran off and reported it in the city and the surrounding countryside. People went out to see what had happened.

(Mark 5:14) 
They came to Jesus and saw the man who had been possessed by the legion of demons sitting there, clothed and in his right mind, and they were afraid.

(Mark 5:15) 
Those who had seen what had happened told them the whole story about the demon-possessed man and the swine.

(Mark 5:16) 
Then they began to beg Jesus to leave their region.

(Mark 5:17) 
As Jesus was getting into the boat, the man who had been demon-possessed begged Him to go with him.

(Mark 5:18) 
Jesus did not let him, but said to him, “Go home to your family and tell them how much the Lord has done for you, and how He has had mercy on you.”

(Mark 5:19) 
So the man went away and began to proclaim in the Decapolis how much Jesus had done for him, and all those who heard it were amazed.

(Mark 5:20) 
When Jesus had crossed over again in the boat to the other side, a large crowd gathered around Him, and He was by the sea.

(Mark 5:21) 
Then one of the synagogue officials, named Jairus, came to Jesus. Seeing Him, he fell at His feet,

(Mark 5:22) 
and begged Him repeatedly, saying, “My little daughter is at the point of death. Please come and put Your hands on her so that she may be healed and live.”

(Mark 5:23) 
So Jesus went with him. A large crowd followed and pressed around Him.

(Mark 5:24) 
And a woman was there who had been suffering from a hemorrhage for twelve years.

(Mark 5:25) 
She had heard about Jesus and came up behind Him in the crowd and touched His cloak,

(Mark 5:26) 
because she said, “If I just touch His clothes, I will be healed.”

(Mark 5:27) 
Immediately her flow of blood dried up, and she realized in her body that she was healed of her affliction.

(Mark 5:28) 
At once Jesus realized that power had gone out from Him. He turned around in the crowd and said, “Who touched My clothes?”

(Mark 5:29) 
His disciples said to Him, “You see the crowd pressing around You, and yet You ask, ‘Who touched Me?’

(Mark 5:30) 
But Jesus kept looking around to see who had done it.

(Mark 5:31) 
The woman, knowing what had happened to her, came with fear and trembling, and fell down before Him and told Him the whole truth.

(Mark 5:32) 
He said to her, “Daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace and be free from your affliction.”

(Mark 5:33) 
While He was still speaking, some people came from the synagogue official’s house and said, “Your daughter is dead. Why bother the Teacher any more?”

(Mark 5:34) 
But Jesus overheard what they were saying and said to the synagogue official, “Do not be afraid; just believe.”

(Mark 5:35) 
He allowed no one to follow Him except Peter, James, and John the brother of James.

(Mark 5:36) 
They came to the home of the synagogue official, and Jesus saw a commotion, with people weeping and wailing loudly.

(Mark 5:37) 
When He entered, He said to them, “Why are you making a commotion and weeping? The child is not dead but sleeping.”

(Mark 5:38) 
And they laughed at Him. But He put them all out and took the child’s father and mother and those who were with Him and went in where the child was.

(Mark 5:39) 
Taking her by the hand, He said to her, “Talitha koum,” which means, “Little girl, I say to you, get up!”

(Mark 5:40) 
Immediately the girl got up and began to walk around (for she was twelve years old). And the people were utterly amazed.

(Mark 5:41) 
He gave them strict orders not to let anyone know about this, and told them to give her something to eat.

(Mark 6:1) 
Jesus left that place and returned to His home country. His disciples followed Him.

(Mark 6:2) 
When the Sabbath arrived, He began teaching in the synagogue. Many people heard Him and were astonished by His teaching. They asked, “Where did He get these things? What is this wisdom given to Him? And what are these mighty works that are done by His hands?”

(Mark 6:3) 
“Isn't this the carpenter, the son of Mary, and the brother of James, and Joseph, and Judas, and Simon? Aren’t His sisters here with us?” And they took offense at Him.

(Mark 6:4) 
Jesus said to them, “A prophet is not without honor, except in his own country, among his own relatives, and in his own house.”

(Mark 6:5) 
And He could do no mighty works there, except that He laid His hands on a few sick people and healed them.

(Mark 6:6) 
And He marveled at their unbelief. Then He went around teaching in the surrounding villages.

(Mark 6:7) 
He called the Twelve to Him and began to send them out two by two, giving them authority over unclean spirits.

(Mark 6:8) 
He instructed them to take nothing for their journey except a staff: no bag, no bread, and no money in their belts.

(Mark 6:9) 
They were to wear sandals and not to put on two tunics.

(Mark 6:10) 
He said to them, “Wherever you enter a house, stay there until you leave that place.

(Mark 6:11) 
And if any place will not welcome you or listen to you, shake off the dust that is on your feet as a testimony against them when you leave. Truly, I say to you, it will be more tolerable for Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment than for that town.”

(Mark 6:12) 
So they went out and preached that people should repent.

(Mark 6:13) 
And they cast out many demons, and they anointed many who were sick with oil, and healed them.

(Mark 6:14) 
King Herod heard about Him, for His name had become well-known. He was saying, “John the Baptist has been raised from the dead, and that is why these powers are at work in Him.”

(Mark 6:15) 
Others said, “He is Elijah.” And others said, “He is a prophet, like one of the prophets.”

(Mark 6:16) 
But when Herod heard this, he said, “John, whom I beheaded, has been raised.”

(Mark 6:17) 
For Herod himself had sent and arrested John, and had bound him in prison on account of Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip, because he had married her.

(Mark 6:18) 
For John had been saying to Herod, “It is not lawful for you to have your brother's wife.”

(Mark 6:19) 
And Herodias was angry with him and wanted to kill him, but she could not.

(Mark 6:20) 
For Herod feared John, knowing that he was a righteous and holy man, and he kept him safe. When he heard him, he was greatly perplexed, and yet he liked to listen to him.

(Mark 6:21) 
But when a convenient time came, Herod gave a banquet for his nobles and military commanders and the leading men of Galilee.

(Mark 6:22) 
When the daughter of Herodias came in and danced, she pleased Herod and those who were with him. And the king said to the girl, “Ask me for whatever you wish, and I will give it to you.”

(Mark 6:23) 
And he swore an oath to her, “Whatever you ask me, I will give you, even up to half of my kingdom.”

(Mark 6:24) 
She went out and said to her mother, “What shall I ask for?” And she said, “The head of John the Baptist.”

(Mark 6:25) 
And immediately she came in a hurry to the king and asked, saying, “I want you to give me the head of John the Baptist on a platter right away.”

(Mark 6:26) 
And the king was exceedingly sorry, but because of his oath and because of those who were with him, he did not want to break his word to her.

(Mark 6:27) 
And immediately the king sent an executioner and commanded that John’s head be brought. So he went and beheaded him in the prison,

(Mark 6:28) 
and brought his head on a platter and gave it to the girl, and the girl gave it to her mother.

(Mark 6:29) 
When his disciples heard about it, they came and took his body and laid it in a tomb.

(Mark 6:30) 
The apostles returned to Jesus and reported to Him all that they had done and taught.

(Mark 6:31) 
He said to them, “Come away by yourselves to a desolate place and rest a while.” For many were coming and going, and they had no leisure even to eat.

(Mark 6:32) 
And they went away in the boat to a desolate place by themselves.

(Mark 6:33) 
Now many saw them going and recognized them, and they ran there on foot from all the towns and arrived ahead of them.

(Mark 6:34) 
When He went ashore, He saw a large crowd and had compassion on them, because they were like sheep without a shepherd. And He began to teach them many things.

(Mark 6:35) 
And when it was already late, His disciples came to Him and said, “This is a desolate place, and it is already late.

(Mark 6:36) 
Send them away so that they may go into the surrounding countryside and villages and buy themselves something to eat, for they have nothing to eat.”

(Mark 6:37) 
But He answered them, “You give them something to eat.” And they said to Him, “Shall we go and buy two hundred denarii worth of bread and give them something to eat?”

(Mark 6:38) 
And He said to them, “How many loaves do you have? Go and see.” And when they had found out, they said, “Five, and two fish.”

(Mark 6:39) 
Then He commanded them all to sit down in groups on the green grass.

(Mark 6:40) 
They reclined in companies of hundreds and of fifties.

(Mark 6:41) 
And taking the five loaves and the two fish, He looked up to the universe and blessed and broke the loaves. Then He gave them to the disciples to set before the people. And He divided the two fish among them all.

(Mark 6:42) 
And they all ate and were satisfied.

(Mark 6:43) 
And they took up twelve baskets full of broken pieces and of the fish.

(Mark 6:44) 
Those who ate the loaves were about five thousand men.

(Mark 6:45) 
Immediately He made His disciples get into the boat and go ahead of Him to Bethsaida, while He sent the crowd away.

(Mark 6:46) 
And after He had taken leave of them, He went up on the mountain to pray.

(Mark 6:47) 
When evening came, the boat was out on the sea, and He was alone on the land.

(Mark 6:48) 
And seeing that they were straining at the oars, for the wind was against them, He came to them in the fourth watch of the night, walking on the sea. He intended to pass by them.

(Mark 6:49) 
But when they saw Him walking on the sea, they thought it was a ghost, and they cried out.

(Mark 6:50) 
For they all saw Him and were terrified. But immediately He spoke with them and said to them, “Take heart; it is I. Do not be afraid.”

(Mark 6:51) 
Then He got into the boat with them, and the wind ceased. And they were utterly astounded,

(Mark 6:52) 
because they had not understood about the loaves, but their hearts were hardened.

(Mark 6:53) 
When they had crossed over, they came to land at Gennesaret and moored to the shore.

(Mark 6:54) 
And when they got out of the boat, immediately the people recognized Him

(Mark 6:55) 
and ran about the whole region and began to bring the sick people on their beds to where they heard He was.

(Mark 6:56) 
And wherever He went, into villages or cities or farms, they laid the sick in the marketplaces and begged Him that they might touch even the fringe of His garment. And as many as touched Him were made well.

(Mark 7:1) 
Then the Pharisees and some scribes came together to see Him, having traveled from Jerusalem.

(Mark 7:2) 
And when they saw some of His disciples eating food with hands that were not washed—that is, common hands—they criticized them.

(Mark 7:3) 
The Pharisees and all the Jews don't eat unless they wash their hands often, holding fast to the traditions of their elders:

(Mark 7:4) 
And after coming from the marketplace, they don't eat unless they wash first. There are many other traditions which they have received to keep, such as washing cups, jugs, bronze vessels, and beds.

(Mark 7:5) 
Then the Pharisees and scribes questioned Him: “Why do Your disciples not live according to the traditions of the elders, but eat food with common hands?”

(Mark 7:6) 
He responded by saying to them: “Isaiah prophesied correctly about you hypocrites, as it is written: ‘This people honors Me with their lips, but their heart is far from Me.’

(Mark 7:7) 
‘In vain they worship Me, teaching doctrines and precepts of men.’

(Mark 7:8) 
‘For, abandoning the commandment of God, you hold to the tradition of men: washing of jugs and cups, and many other similar things you do.’

(Mark 7:9) 
And He said to them: “You do very well at making the commandment of God invalid, so that you can establish your own tradition.”

(Mark 7:10) 
For Moses said: ‘Honor your father and your mother,’ and ‘Whoever curses father or mother must surely die.’

(Mark 7:11) 
But you say: ‘If a man says to his father or mother, “Corban” (which means, a gift), whatever profit you might have received from me,’

(Mark 7:12) 
you no longer permit him to do anything for his father or his mother,

(Mark 7:13) 
making the word of God invalid through your tradition, which you have handed down. And you do many things similar to these.”

(Mark 7:14) 
And, having called the crowd again, He said to them: “Listen to Me, all of you, and understand.

(Mark 7:15) 
There is nothing outside a man which, entering into him, can defile him; but the things which come out of the man, these are what defile the man.

(Mark 7:16) 
If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear.”

(Mark 7:17) 
And when He entered into the house away from the crowd, His disciples questioned Him about the parable.

(Mark 7:18) 
And He said to them: “Are you also as unintelligent? Don’t you understand that everything that enters a man from outside cannot defile him,

(Mark 7:19) 
because it doesn’t enter his heart, but his stomach, and it goes out into the latrine, eliminating all the food?”

(Mark 7:20) 
But He said, “What comes out of a man, that defiles the man.

(Mark 7:21) 
For from within, out of the heart of men, proceed evil thoughts, acts of sexual immorality, thefts, murders,

(Mark 7:22) 
adulteries, acts of greed, wickedness, deceit, sensuality, envy, slander, arrogance, and foolishness.

(Mark 7:23) 
All these evils proceed from within and defile the man.”

(Mark 7:24) 
Then, getting up, He went away to the area of Tyre and Sidon. And, entering a house, He didn’t want anyone to know, and yet He couldn’t remain hidden.

(Mark 7:25) 
For a woman whose daughter had an unclean spirit, immediately after hearing about Him, came and fell at His feet.

(Mark 7:26) 
The woman was a Gentile, of Syrophoenician origin. And she begged Him to cast the demon out of her daughter.

(Mark 7:27) 
He said to her, “Let the children be satisfied first, for it is not right to take the children’s bread and throw it to the dogs.”

(Mark 7:28) 
But she responded, “Yes, Lord; but even the dogs under the table eat from the crumbs of the children.”

(Mark 7:29) 
And He said to her: “Because of this word, go; the demon has gone out of your daughter.”

(Mark 7:30) 
And going home, she found the girl lying on the bed, and the demon had gone out.

(Mark 7:31) 
Then, departing again from the territory of Tyre, He came through Sidon to the Sea of Galilee, through the midst of the territory of the Decapolis.

(Mark 7:32) 
And they brought to Him a man who was deaf and mute. And they begged Him to place His hand on him.

(Mark 7:33) 
And, taking him away from the crowd privately, He put His fingers into his ears, and spitting, He touched his tongue.

(Mark 7:34) 
Then, looking up to the sky, He groaned and said to him, “Ephphatha,” which means, “Be opened.”

(Mark 7:35) 
And immediately his ears were opened, and the bond of his tongue was loosened, and he was speaking correctly.

(Mark 7:36) 
And He commanded them not to tell anyone. But as much as He commanded them, so much the more did they proclaim it:

(Mark 7:37) 
and they were exceedingly astonished, saying, “He has done all things well. He even makes the deaf to hear and the mute to speak!”

(Mark 8:1) 
During those days, after a great crowd had gathered but didn't have anything to eat, Jesus summoned the disciples and told them:

(Mark 8:2) 
“I have pity on the crowd because they’ve been with me for three days, and they don’t have anything to eat.

(Mark 8:3) 
If I send them away hungry to their homes, they will weaken on the way, because some of them have come from far away.”

(Mark 8:4) 
His disciples responded to him: “How can someone possibly feed them with bread here in the desert?”

(Mark 8:5) 
Jesus then asked them: “How many loaves of bread do you have?” They replied: “Seven.”

(Mark 8:6) 
He ordered the crowd to recline on the ground. Then, taking the seven loaves, He gave thanks, broke them, and gave them to His disciples to set before the crowd. They did so.

(Mark 8:7) 
They also had a few small fish. Jesus blessed them and ordered that they be put before the crowd.

(Mark 8:8) 
Everyone ate and was satisfied. They collected what was left of the fragments—seven baskets full.

(Mark 8:9) 
There were about four thousand people eating, and Jesus sent them away.

(Mark 8:10) 
Immediately, He got into a boat with His disciples and went to the region of Dalmanutha.

(Mark 8:11) 
Then the Pharisees came out and began to debate with Him, asking for a sign from the sky, testing Him.

(Mark 8:12) 
He sighed deeply in His spirit, and said, “Why does this generation seek a sign? Truly I say to you, no sign will be given to this generation.”

(Mark 8:13) 
He left them, got back into the boat, and went to the other side of the lake.

(Mark 8:14) 
They had forgotten to bring bread. They had only one loaf with them in the boat.

(Mark 8:15) 
Jesus then commanded them, saying: “Watch out and beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the yeast of Herod.”

(Mark 8:16) 
They reasoned among themselves, saying: “It’s because we have no bread.”

(Mark 8:17) 
Jesus, aware of this, said to them: “Why are you discussing that you have no bread? Don’t you yet understand or comprehend? Do you still have hardened hearts?

(Mark 8:18) 
Do you have eyes but fail to see? Do you have ears but fail to hear? Don’t you remember?

(Mark 8:19) 
When I broke the five loaves for the five thousand, how many baskets of fragments did you gather?” They said to Him: “Twelve.”

(Mark 8:20) 
“And when I broke the seven loaves for the four thousand, how many baskets of fragments did you gather?” They said to Him: “Seven.”

(Mark 8:21) 
Then He said to them: “How is it that you still do not understand?”

(Mark 8:22) 
They came to Bethsaida. They brought a blind man to Jesus, and they begged Him to touch him.

(Mark 8:23) 
Taking the blind man by the hand, He led him outside the village. Then, spitting on his eyes and laying His hands on him, He asked him if he saw anything.

(Mark 8:24) 
The man looked up and said, “I see people, but they look like trees, walking around.”

(Mark 8:25) 
Then Jesus laid His hands on his eyes again, and he saw clearly, and his sight was restored. He could then see everything perfectly.

(Mark 8:26) 
Jesus sent him home, saying, “Do not go into the village.”

(Mark 8:27) 
Jesus and His disciples went to the villages of Caesarea Philippi. On the way, He asked His disciples, “Who do people say that I am?”

(Mark 8:28) 
They replied, “John the Baptist. Others say Elijah, and others say one of the prophets.”

(Mark 8:29) 
Then He asked them, “But who do *you* say that I am?” Peter answered, “You are the Christ.”

(Mark 8:30) 
He strongly warned them not to tell anyone about Him.

(Mark 8:31) 
Jesus then began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer many things, and be rejected by the elders, the chief priests, and the scribes, and be killed, and then rise three days later.

(Mark 8:32) 
He spoke openly about this. Peter took Him aside and began to rebuke Him.

(Mark 8:33) 
But Jesus turned, and looking at His disciples, rebuked Peter and said, “Get behind me, Satan, because you are not thinking the things of God, but the things of men.”

(Mark 8:34) 
Then, calling the crowd to Himself along with His disciples, Jesus said to them: “If anyone wants to follow Me, let him deny himself, take up his cross, and follow Me.

(Mark 8:35) 
For whoever wants to save his own life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for My sake and the Gospel will save it.

(Mark 8:36) 
What does it profit a man to gain the whole world, yet forfeit his soul?

(Mark 8:37) 
Or what can a man give in exchange for his soul?

(Mark 8:38) 
If anyone is ashamed of Me and My words in this adulterous and sinful generation, the Son of Man will also be ashamed of him when He comes in the glory of His Father with the holy angels.

(Mark 9:1) 
And He was telling them: “Truly, I say to you, some of those standing here will not experience death until they see the reign of God coming with power.”

(Mark 9:2) 
And after six days, Jesus took Peter, and James, and John, and led them up to a high mountain apart by themselves, and He was transfigured before them.

(Mark 9:3) 
And His garments became shining, extremely white as snow, of a whiteness no fuller on earth can produce.

(Mark 9:4) 
And Elijah appeared to them with Moses, and they were talking with Jesus.

(Mark 9:5) 
Then Peter responded, and said to Jesus: “Rabbi, it is good for us to be here. So, let us build three tabernacles—one for You, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”

(Mark 9:6) 
For he did not know what he was saying, because they were overcome with fear.

(Mark 9:7) 
And a cloud appeared, overshadowing them, and a voice came from the cloud, saying: “This is My beloved Son, hear Him.”

(Mark 9:8) 
And immediately, looking around, they saw no one any more, except Jesus only with them.

(Mark 9:9) 
And as they were coming down from the mountain, He commanded them not to tell anyone what they had seen, until the Son of Man had risen from the dead.

(Mark 9:10) 
And they kept the word to themselves, questioning among themselves what this “rising from the dead” might be.

(Mark 9:11) 
And they questioned Him, saying: “Why then do the Pharisees and scribes say that Elijah must come first?”

(Mark 9:12) 
Then He, answering, said to them: “Elijah does come first, and will restore all things. But how is it written concerning the Son of Man, that He must suffer many things and be despised?

(Mark 9:13) 
But I tell you, that Elijah has also come, and they did to him whatever they wished, just as it is written of him.”

(Mark 9:14) 
And coming to the disciples, they saw a large crowd around them and scribes disputing with them.

(Mark 9:15)
