And immediately the whole crowd, seeing Jesus, were astonished, and running to Him, they greeted Him.

(Mark 9:16) 
And He asked them: “What are you disputing among yourselves?”

(Mark 9:17) 
And one of the crowd responded, and said: “Teacher, I brought my son to You because he has an unclean spirit.

(Mark 9:18) 
And wherever it seizes him, it throws him down, and he foams at the mouth, grinds his teeth, and becomes rigid. And I told Your disciples to cast it out, but they could not.”

(Mark 9:19) 
Then He answered them: “O faithless generation, how long will I be with you? How long will I put up with you? Bring him to Me.”

(Mark 9:20) 
And they brought him to Him. And as soon as the spirit saw Him, it immediately threw the boy into convulsions. And falling on the ground, he rolled around, foaming at the mouth.

(Mark 9:21) 
And He asked his father: “How long has this been happening to him?” And he said: “From childhood.

(Mark 9:22) 
And often it has thrown him into fire and into water, to destroy him. But if You can do anything, help us and have pity on us.”

(Mark 9:23) 
Jesus said to him: “If you can believe, all things are possible to him who believes.”

(Mark 9:24) 
And immediately the father of the boy cried out with tears, saying: “I believe, Lord. Help my unbelief.”

(Mark 9:25) 
And when Jesus saw that the crowd was running together, He rebuked the unclean spirit, and said to it: “Mute and deaf spirit, I command you, come out of him, and never enter him again.”

(Mark 9:26) 
And crying out and tearing him severely, it came out. And the boy became like a corpse, so that many said he was dead.

(Mark 9:27) 
But Jesus, taking his hand, lifted him up, and he arose.

(Mark 9:28) 
And when He had entered the house, His disciples asked Him privately: “Why could we not cast it out?”

(Mark 9:29) 
And He said to them: “This kind can be cast out by nothing except by prayer and fasting.”

(Mark 9:30) 
And departing from there, they were passing through Galilee. And He did not want anyone to know, because He was teaching His disciples, and He was saying to them: “The Son of Man will be delivered into the hands of men, and they will kill Him; and being killed, after three days, He will rise.”

(Mark 9:31) 
But they did not understand the word, and they were afraid to ask Him.

(Mark 9:32) 
And they came to Capernaum. And when they had entered the house, He was asking them: “What were you arguing about on the way?”

(Mark 9:33) 
But they were silent, for on the way they had argued among themselves about who was the greatest.

(Mark 9:34) 
And sitting down, He called the twelve, and said to them: “If anyone wishes to be first, he will be last of all and the servant of all.”

(Mark 9:35) 
And taking a child, He set him in their midst, and embracing him, He said to them:

(Mark 9:36) 
“Whoever receives one of these children in My name receives Me, and whoever receives Me, does not receive Me but Him who sent Me.”

(Mark 9:37) 
John answered Him, saying: “Teacher, we saw someone casting out demons in Your name, who does not follow us, and we forbade him.”

(Mark 9:38) 
But Jesus said: “Do not forbid him, for there is no one who does a mighty work in My name, and can soon speak evil of Me.”

(Mark 9:39) 
For he who is not against us is for us.

(Mark 9:40) 
For whoever gives you a cup of water to drink in My name, because you are Christ’s, truly I say to you, he will not lose his reward.

(Mark 9:41) 
And whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in Me to stumble, it would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck, and he were cast into the sea.

(Mark 9:42) 
And if your hand causes you to stumble, cut it off. It is better for you to enter into life maimed, than to having two hands, go into hell, into the unquenchable fire,

(Mark 9:43) 
where their worm does not die, and the fire is not extinguished.

(Mark 9:44) 
And if your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off. It is better for you to enter into eternal life lame, than to having two feet, be cast into the hell of unquenchable fire,

(Mark 9:45) 
where their worm does not die, and the fire is not extinguished.

(Mark 9:46) 
And if your eye causes you to stumble, cast it out. It is better for you to enter the kingdom of God with one eye, than to having two eyes, be cast into the hell of fire,

(Mark 9:47) 
where their worm does not die, and the fire is not extinguished.

(Mark 9:48) 
For everyone will be salted with fire, and every sacrifice will be seasoned with salt.

(Mark 9:49) 
Salt is good, but if salt becomes tasteless, with what will you season it?

(Mark 9:50) 
Have salt in yourselves, and keep peace among yourselves.”

(Mark 10:1) 
And then, He rose and went into the borders of Judea beyond the Jordan. Again, the crowds gathered to Him, and He was teaching them again.

(Mark 10:2) 
And the Pharisees approached Him and questioned Him: "Is it lawful for a man to put away his wife?" They were trying to trip Him up.

(Mark 10:3) 
But He answering, said to them: "What did Moses command you?"

(Mark 10:4) 
They said: "Moses allowed a man to write a bill of divorce and to put her away."

(Mark 10:5) 
To whom Jesus answering, said: "Because of the hardness of your hearts, he wrote you this commandment."

(Mark 10:6) 
But from the beginning of creation, God made them male and female.

(Mark 10:7) 
For this cause, a man shall leave his father and mother, and cleave to his wife.

(Mark 10:8) 
And the two will be in one flesh. Therefore, they are no longer two, but one flesh.

(Mark 10:9) 
What God has joined together, let no man separate."

(Mark 10:10) 
And in the house, the disciples again questioned Him about the same matter.

(Mark 10:11) 
And He said to them: "Whoever puts away his wife, and marries another, commits adultery against her.

(Mark 10:12) 
And if a woman puts away her husband, and is married to another, she commits adultery.

(Mark 10:13) 
And they were bringing little children to Him, that He might touch them. But the disciples were rebuking those who were bringing them.

(Mark 10:14) 
When Jesus saw this, He was indignant, and said to them: "Allow the little children to come to Me, and do not forbid them: for of such is the kingdom of God.

(Mark 10:15) 
Amen I say to you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God, as a child, will not enter into it."

(Mark 10:16) 
And embracing them, and imposing hands upon them, He blessed them.

(Mark 10:17) 
And as He was going out into the way, a certain man, running up and kneeling to Him, was asking Him: "Good Master, what must I do that I may receive eternal life?"

(Mark 10:18) 
And Jesus said to him: "Why do you call Me good? No one is good, but God alone.

(Mark 10:19) 
You know the commandments: 'Do not commit adultery. Do not kill. Do not steal. Do not bear false witness. Do not commit fraud. Honor your father and your mother.'

(Mark 10:20) 
But he answering, said to Him: "Master, I have kept all these things from my youth."

(Mark 10:21) 
And Jesus looking upon him, loved him, and said to him: "One thing is lacking to you: go, sell all that you have, and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven: and come, follow Me."

(Mark 10:22) 
But he, being saddened by the word, went away sorrowful: for he had great possessions.

(Mark 10:23) 
And Jesus, looking around, said to His disciples: "How difficult it is for those who have riches to enter into the kingdom of God!"

(Mark 10:24) 
But the disciples were astonished at His words. But Jesus again answering, said to them: "Children, how difficult it is for those who trust in riches to enter into the kingdom of God!"

(Mark 10:25) 
It is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God."

(Mark 10:26) 
And they were much more astonished, saying among themselves: "Who then can be saved?"

(Mark 10:27) 
And Jesus, looking upon them, said: "With men it is impossible; but not with God. For all things are possible with God."

(Mark 10:28) 
And Peter began to say to Him: "Behold, we have left all things, and have followed You."

(Mark 10:29) 
Jesus answering, said: "Amen I say to you, there is no one who has left home, or brothers, or sisters, or father, or mother, or children, or lands, for My sake, and for the Gospel,

(Mark 10:30) 
who will not receive a hundredfold now in this time, houses, and brothers, and sisters, and mothers, and children, and lands, with persecutions, and in the world to come life everlasting.

(Mark 10:31) 
But many that are first will be last, and the last will be first."

(Mark 10:32) 
And they were on the road, going up to Jerusalem: and Jesus was preceding them, and they were astonished: and those who followed were afraid. And taking the twelve again, He began to tell them the things that were to happen to Him.

(Mark 10:33) 
Saying: "Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be betrayed to the chief priests, and the scribes, and they will condemn Him to death, and will deliver Him to the Gentiles:

(Mark 10:34) 
And they will mock Him, and spit upon Him, and scourge Him, and kill Him: and the third day He will rise again."

(Mark 10:35) 
And James and John, the sons of Zebedee, approached Him, saying: "Master, we want You to do whatever we ask."

(Mark 10:36) 
But He said to them: "What do you want Me to do for you?"

(Mark 10:37) 
And they said to Him: "Grant to us that one of us may sit at Your right hand, and the other at Your left, in Your glory."

(Mark 10:38) 
But Jesus said to them: "You do not know what you are asking. Can you drink the chalice that I drink? Or be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with?"

(Mark 10:39) 
They said to Him: "We can." And Jesus said to them: "The chalice indeed that I drink, you shall drink: and with the baptism that I am baptized, you shall be baptized.

(Mark 10:40) 
But to sit at My right hand or at My left is not Mine to give to you, but to those for whom it is prepared."

(Mark 10:41) 
And the ten hearing it, began to be indignant at James and John.

(Mark 10:42) 
But Jesus calling them, said to them: "You know that those who are seen to rule over the Gentiles, lord it over them: and their great ones exercise power over them.

(Mark 10:43) 
But it shall not be so among you: but whoever will become greater among you, will be your servant:

(Mark 10:44) 
and whoever will want to be first among you, will be the servant of all.

(Mark 10:45) 
For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give His life a redemption for many."

(Mark 10:46) 
And they came to Jericho. And as He was departing from Jericho, and with His disciples and a great multitude, Bartimaeus, the son of Timaeus, a blind beggar, was sitting by the road.

(Mark 10:47) 
And when he heard that it was Jesus of Nazareth, he began to cry out and say: "Son of David, Jesus, have mercy on me."

(Mark 10:48) 
And many were rebuking him, that he should be quiet: but he cried out much more: "Son of David, have mercy on me."

(Mark 10:49) 
And Jesus standing, ordered him to be called. And they called the blind man, saying to him: "Have confidence: arise, He calls you."

(Mark 10:50) 
Who, casting off his garment, leaping up, came to Him.

(Mark 10:51) 
And answering, Jesus said to him: "What do you want Me to do for you?" The blind man said to Him: "Rabboni, that I may see."

(Mark 10:52) 
And Jesus said to him: "Go your way; your faith has made you safe." And immediately he saw and followed Him in the way.

(Mark 11:1) 
As He approached Jerusalem, and the towns of Bethany and Bethphage on the Mount of Olives, He sent two of His disciples,

(Mark 11:2) 
saying to them: “Go into the village which is in front of you. Entering into it right away, you will find a colt tied up. No one has ever ridden on it. Untie it, and bring it.”

(Mark 11:3) 
“If anyone asks you, ‘What are you doing?’ Say that the Lord has need of it, and He will send it back here immediately.”

(Mark 11:4) 
So they went off and found the colt tied up at a door outside, at a fork in the road, and they untied it.

(Mark 11:5) 
Some of those standing there said to them: “What are you doing, untying the colt?”

(Mark 11:6) 
They replied as Jesus had told them to, and they let them go.

(Mark 11:7) 
Then they brought the colt to Jesus. They put their cloaks on it, and He sat upon it.

(Mark 11:8) 
And many people spread their cloaks on the road, while others cut down branches from the trees and scattered them on the road.

(Mark 11:9) 
And those who went ahead and those who followed were shouting, saying: “Hosanna! Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord!”

(Mark 11:10) 
“Blessed is the kingdom of our father David, which is coming! Hosanna in the highest!”

(Mark 11:11) 
He entered into Jerusalem, and into the temple. And after looking around at everything, since it was already late in the day, He went out to Bethany with the twelve.

(Mark 11:12) 
On the next day, as they were leaving Bethany, He became hungry.

(Mark 11:13) 
Seeing in the distance a fig tree in leaf, He went to see if perhaps He could find anything on it. When He went up to it, He found nothing but leaves, for it was not the season for figs.

(Mark 11:14) 
Then He said to it: “May no one ever eat fruit from you again.” And His disciples heard it.

(Mark 11:15) 
And they went to Jerusalem. And Jesus went into the temple and began to throw out those selling and buying in the temple. He overturned the tables of the money changers and the chairs of those selling doves.

(Mark 11:16) 
He would not allow anyone to carry anything through the temple.

(Mark 11:17) 
And He taught them, saying to them: “Is it not written, ‘My house shall be called a house of prayer for all the nations’? But you have made it a den of thieves.”

(Mark 11:18) 
The scribes and chief priests heard this and began looking for a way to kill Him, for they were afraid of Him, because all the people were amazed by His teaching.

(Mark 11:19) 
When evening came, He went out of the city.

(Mark 11:20) 
And as they were passing by in the morning, they saw the fig tree withered from the roots.

(Mark 11:21) 
Then Peter, remembering, said to Him: “Rabbi, look! The fig tree which you cursed has dried up.”

(Mark 11:22) 
And Jesus answered, saying to them: “Have faith in God.”

(Mark 11:23) 
“Truly, I say to you, if anyone says to this mountain, ‘Be lifted up and thrown into the sea,’ and does not doubt in his heart, but believes that what he says will happen, it will be done for him.

(Mark 11:24) 
“Therefore I tell you, whatever you pray and ask for, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours.

(Mark 11:25) 
“And whenever you stand praying, forgive anything you have against anyone, so that your Father in the universe may also forgive you your sins.”

(Mark 11:26) 
“But if you do not forgive, neither will your Father who is in the universe forgive your sins.”

(Mark 11:27) 
And again they came to Jerusalem. And as He was walking in the temple, the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders came to Him,

(Mark 11:28) 
and they were saying to Him: “By what authority are you doing these things? And who gave You this authority to do these things?”

(Mark 11:29) 
Jesus answered them, “I will ask you one question, and if you answer Me, I will tell you by what authority I do these things.

(Mark 11:30) 
“Was the baptism of John from the universe, or from men? Answer Me.”

(Mark 11:31) 
And they were reasoning among themselves, saying: “If we say, ‘From the universe,’ He will say, ‘Then why did you not believe him?’”

(Mark 11:32) 
“But if we say, ‘From men,’ we fear the people, for they all consider John to have been a true prophet.”

(Mark 11:33) 
So they answered Jesus, saying, “We do not know.” And Jesus answered them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.”

(Mark 12:1) 
And He began to speak to them in parables: “A man planted a vineyard and put a fence around it, and dug a pit, and built a tower. Then he leased it to tenant farmers, and went away on a journey.

(Mark 12:2) 
And when the harvest season came, he sent a servant to the farmers to collect the fruit of the vineyard.

(Mark 12:3) 
And seizing the servant, they beat him and sent him away empty-handed.

(Mark 12:4) 
And he sent to them again another servant, and him they wounded in the head, and treated shamefully.

(Mark 12:5) 
Then he sent another one, and him they killed. And he sent many others, some of whom they beat, and some they killed.

(Mark 12:6) 
He still had one beloved son. Finally, he sent him to them, saying, ‘Surely they will respect my son.’

(Mark 12:7) 
But those farmers said to one another, ‘This is the heir. Come, let us kill him, and the inheritance will be ours.’

(Mark 12:8) 
And seizing him, they killed him, and cast him out of the vineyard.

(Mark 12:9) 
What therefore will the Lord of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy the farmers, and will give the vineyard to others.

(Mark 12:10) 
Have you not read this scripture: ‘The stone which the builders rejected, the same is become the head of the corner.

(Mark 12:11) 
This was done by the Lord, and it is wonderful in our eyes’?

(Mark 12:12) 
And they sought to seize Him, but they feared the crowds, for they knew that He had spoken the parable to them. And leaving Him, they went away.

(Mark 12:13) 
And they sent to Him some of the Pharisees and of the Herodians, to catch Him in His speech.

(Mark 12:14) 
And when they were come, they said to Him, “Teacher, we know that you are truthful and care for no one; for you do not regard the person of men, but teach the way of God in truth. Is it lawful to pay tribute to Caesar, or shall we not pay?”

(Mark 12:15) 
But He, knowing their hypocrisy, said to them, “Why are you tempting me? Bring me a denarius that I may see it.”

(Mark 12:16) 
And they brought it. And He said to them, “Whose is this image and inscription?” They said to Him, “Caesar’s.”

(Mark 12:17) 
And Jesus answering, said to them, “Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.” And they were astonished at Him.

(Mark 12:18) 
And there came to Him the Sadducees, who say that there is no resurrection; and they were questioning Him, saying:

(Mark 12:19) 
“Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man’s brother dies and leaves a wife, and leaves no children, his brother should take the wife and raise up seed for his brother.

(Mark 12:20) 
There were seven brothers, and the first took a wife, and died without leaving children.

(Mark 12:21) 
And the second took her, and died, and neither did he leave children. And the third in like manner.

(Mark 12:22) 
And the seven took her, and left no seed. Last of all, the woman died also.

(Mark 12:23) 
In the resurrection, therefore, when they rise again, whose wife shall she be of them? For the seven had her as a wife.”

(Mark 12:24) 
And Jesus answering, said to them, “You are mistaken, because you do not know the Scriptures, nor the power of God.

(Mark 12:25) 
For when they rise from the dead, they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like the angels in the heavens.

(Mark 12:26) 
And as for the dead, that they rise again, have you not read in the book of Moses, in the passage about the bush, how God spoke to him, saying:

(Mark 12:27) 
‘I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob’? He is not the God of the dead, but of the living. Therefore, you are much mistaken.”

(Mark 12:28) 
And one of the scribes, who had heard them disputing, and seeing that He had answered them well, asked Him: “Which commandment is the first of all?”

(Mark 12:29) 
And Jesus answered him: “The first is: ‘Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one.

(Mark 12:30) 
‘And you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your mind, and with all your strength.’ This is the first commandment.

(Mark 12:31) 
And the second is like this: ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself.’ There is no other commandment greater than these.”

(Mark 12:32) 
And the scribe said to Him: “Well, Teacher, you have spoken the truth, for there is one God, and there is no other but Him:

(Mark 12:33) 
‘And to love Him with all the heart, and with all the understanding, and with all the soul, and with all the strength, and to love one’s neighbor as oneself, is greater than all whole burnt offerings and sacrifices.”

(Mark 12:34) 
And Jesus, seeing that he had answered wisely, said to him: “You are not far from the kingdom of God.” And no one dared to question Him anymore.

(Mark 12:35) 
And Jesus, answering, said, while teaching in the temple: “How do the scribes say that the Christ is the son of David?

(Mark 12:36) 
For David himself said in the Holy Spirit, ‘The Lord said to my Lord: Sit at My right hand, until I make Your enemies Your footstool.’

(Mark 12:37) 
David himself calls Him ‘Lord.’ How is He then his son?”

(Mark 12:38) 
And the great multitude listened to Him with pleasure.

(Mark 12:39) 
And in His teaching He was saying: “Beware of the scribes, who wish to walk in long robes, and to be greeted in the marketplace,

(Mark 12:40) 
and the chief seats in the synagogues, and the first places at feasts.

(Mark 12:41) 
They devour the houses of widows under the guise of long prayers. These will receive a more severe judgment.”

(Mark 12:42) 
And Jesus sat down opposite the treasury, and watched how the crowd was casting money into the treasury. And many rich people were throwing in much.

(Mark 12:43) 
And a poor widow came and put in two small copper coins, which make a farthing.

(Mark 12:44) 
And calling His disciples to Him, He said to them: “Amen I say to you, that this poor widow has cast in more than all those who have cast into the treasury.

(Mark 12:45) 
For they all put in out of their abundance; but she out of her poverty has put in all that she had, even her whole living.”

(Mark 13:1) 
As He left the temple, one of His disciples said, “Teacher, look at the enormous stones and impressive buildings!”

(Mark 13:2) 
Jesus answered, “Do you see these great buildings? Not a stone will be left upon a stone; all will be torn down.”

(Mark 13:3) 
As He sat on the Mount of Olives opposite the temple, Peter, James, John, and Andrew asked Him privately:

(Mark 13:4) 
“Tell us, when will these things happen? And what sign will there be when all these things are about to be fulfilled?”

(Mark 13:5) 
Jesus began to say to them: “Be careful that no one deceives you.

(Mark 13:6) 
For many will come in My name, saying, ‘I am He,’ and they will deceive many.

(Mark 13:7) 
And when you hear of wars and rumors of wars, do not be alarmed; for such things must happen, but the end is not yet.

(Mark 13:8) 
For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom. There will be earthquakes in various places, and famines. These are the beginning of birth pangs.

(Mark 13:9) 
“But be careful yourselves; for they will deliver you up to councils, and you will be beaten in synagogues. You will stand before governors and kings for My sake, for a testimony to them.

(Mark 13:10) 
And the gospel must first be preached to all the nations.

(Mark 13:11) 
And when they deliver you and bring you to trial, do not worry beforehand about what you are to say, but say whatever is given you at that hour; for it is not you who speak, but the Holy Spirit.

(Mark 13:12) 
And brother will deliver brother to death, and the father his child; and children will rise up against parents and cause them to be put to death.

(Mark 13:13) 
And you will be hated by everyone because of My name, but the one who perseveres to the end will be saved.

(Mark 13:14) 
“But when you see the abomination of desolation standing where it should not be (let the reader understand), then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains.

(Mark 13:15) 
Let the one who is on the housetop not go down, nor enter the house to take anything out.

(Mark 13:16) 
And let the one who is in the field not turn back to get his cloak.

(Mark 13:17) 
“But woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing infants in those days!

(Mark 13:18) 
Pray that it may not happen in the winter.

(Mark 13:19) 
“For those days will be a time of tribulation, such as has not occurred from the beginning of the creation which God created until now, and never will occur.

(Mark 13:20) 
“And unless the Lord shortened those days, no one would be saved; but for the sake of the elect, whom He chose, He shortened the days.

(Mark 13:21) 
“And then if anyone says to you, ‘Behold, here is the Christ,’ or, ‘Behold, He is there,’ do not believe it.

(Mark 13:22) 
For false Christs and false prophets will arise, and will show signs and wonders, in order to lead astray, if possible, the elect.

(Mark 13:23) 
“But be on your guard; I have told you everything beforehand.

(Mark 13:24) 
“But in those days, after that tribulation, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light,

(Mark 13:25) 
and the stars will be falling from heaven, and the powers that are in the heavens will be shaken.

(Mark 13:26) 
“And then they will see the Son of Man coming in clouds with great power and glory.

(Mark 13:27) 
“And then He will send forth the angels, and will gather together His elect from the four winds, from the farthest end of the earth to the farthest end of heaven.

(Mark 13:28) 
“Now learn the parable from the fig tree: when its branch has already become tender and puts forth its leaves, you know that summer is near.

(Mark 13:29) 
“So also you, when you see these things happening, recognize that He is near, right at the doors.

(Mark 13:30) 
“Truly I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all these things take place.

(Mark 13:31) 
“Heaven and earth will pass away, but My words will not pass away.

(Mark 13:32) 
“But of that day or hour, no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but the Father.

(Mark 13:33) 
“Be on the alert, keep awake, and pray; for you do not know when the time will come.

(Mark 13:34) 
“It is like a man away on a journey, who upon leaving his house and putting his servants in charge, assigning to each one his task, also commanded the doorkeeper to stay awake.

(Mark 13:35) 
“Therefore, be on the alert—for you do not know when the master of the house is coming, whether in the evening, or at midnight, or at the rooster’s crowing, or in the morning—

(Mark 13:36) 
lest he come suddenly and find you asleep.

(Mark 13:37) 
“What I say to you I say to all: ‘Be on the alert!’”

(Mark 14:1) 
The Passover and Unleavened Bread were coming in two days. The chief priests and scribes sought how to seize Jesus by treachery and kill Him.

(Mark 14:2) 
They said, “Not during the festival, lest there be a riot among the people.”

(Mark 14:3) 
Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper, and as He reclined at table, a woman came with an alabaster flask of very costly ointment of pure nard. Breaking the flask, she poured the ointment over His head.

(Mark 14:4) 
Some were indignant within themselves and said, “Why was this waste of ointment made?

(Mark 14:5) 
It could have been sold for more than three hundred denarii and given to the poor.” And they were angry at her.

(Mark 14:6) 
Jesus said, “Let her alone! Why do you bother her? She has done a good work for Me.

(Mark 14:7) 
For you always have the poor with you, and whenever you want, you can do good to them. But you do not always have Me.

(Mark 14:8) 
She has done what she could; she has beforehand anointed My body for burial.

(Mark 14:9) 
Amen, I say to you, wherever the Gospel is proclaimed throughout the whole world, what she has done will be told in memory of her.”

(Mark 14:10) 
Then Judas Iscariot, one of the Twelve, went to the chief priests to hand Jesus over to them.

(Mark 14:11) 
They were pleased when they heard this and promised to give him money. And he sought how to betray Him at a convenient time.

(Mark 14:12) 
On the first day of the Feast of Unleavened Bread, when they sacrificed the Passover, His disciples said to Him, “Where do you want us to go to prepare for You to eat the Passover?”

(Mark 14:13) 
He sent two of His disciples and said to them, “Go into the city, and a man carrying a jar of water will meet you. Follow him.

(Mark 14:14) 
Wherever he enters, say to the master of the house, ‘The Teacher says, “Where is the guest room where I may eat the Passover with My disciples?”’

(Mark 14:15) 
Then he will show you a large upper room furnished and ready. Prepare for us there.”

(Mark 14:16) 
The disciples went out and came to the city and found everything as He had told them, and they prepared the Passover.

(Mark 14:17) 
When it was evening, He came with the Twelve.

(Mark 14:18) 
As they reclined and were eating, Jesus said, “Amen, I say to you, one of you will betray Me, the one eating with Me.”

(Mark 14:19) 
They began to be sorrowful and to say to Him one by one, “Surely not I?”

(Mark 14:20) 
He said to them in reply, “One of the Twelve, the one who dips his hand into the dish with Me.

(Mark 14:21) 
The Son of Man goes as it is written about Him, but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed. It would have been better for that man if he had not been born.”

(Mark 14:22) 
While they were eating, He took bread, said the blessing, broke it, gave it to them, and said, “Take this, this is My body.”

(Mark 14:23) 
Then He took a cup, gave thanks, and gave it to them, and they all drank from it.

(Mark 14:24) 
He said to them, “This is My blood of the covenant, which will be shed for many.

(Mark 14:25) 
Amen, I say to you, I shall not drink again the fruit of the vine until the day when I drink it new in the kingdom of God.”

(Mark 14:26) 
Then, after singing a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.

(Mark 14:27) 
Jesus said to them, “You will all have your faith shaken, for it is written: ‘I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.’

(Mark 14:28) 
But after I am raised up, I shall go before you to Galilee.”

(Mark 14:29) 
Peter said to Him, “Even though all should have their faith shaken, I will not.”

(Mark 14:30) 
Jesus said to him, “Amen, I say to you, this very night before the cock crows twice, you will deny Me three times.”

(Mark 14:31) 
But he vehemently protested, “Even though I should have to die with You, I will not deny You.” And they all spoke similarly.

(Mark 14:32) 
They came to a place named Gethsemane, and He said to His disciples, “Sit here while I pray.”

(Mark 14:33) 
He took with Him Peter, James, and John, and began to be troubled and distressed.

(Mark 14:34) 
He said to them, “My soul is sorrowful even to death. Remain here and keep watch.”

(Mark 14:35) 
He advanced a little and fell to the ground and prayed that if it were possible, the hour might pass Him.

(Mark 14:36) 
He said, “Abba, Father, all things are possible to You. Take this cup away from Me, but not what I will, but what You will.”

(Mark 14:37) 
Then He returned and found them sleeping. He said to Peter, “Simon, are you asleep? Could you not keep watch for one hour?

(Mark 14:38) 
Keep watch and pray that you may not undergo the test. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak.”

(Mark 14:39) 
Again He went away and prayed, saying the same thing.

(Mark 14:40) 
Again He returned and found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy, and they did not know what to answer Him.

(Mark 14:41) 
He returned a third time and said to them, “Are you still sleeping and taking your rest? It is over. The hour has come. Behold, the Son of Man is to be handed over to sinners.

(Mark 14:42) 
Get up, let us go. See, My betrayer is near.”

(Mark 14:43) 
Immediately, while He was still speaking, Judas, one of the Twelve, arrived, accompanied by a crowd with swords and clubs, sent by the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders.

(Mark 14:44) 
The one who was to hand Him over had given them a sign, saying, “Whomever I shall kiss is the one; seize him and lead him away securely.”

(Mark 14:45) 
And when he came, he immediately went up to Him and said, “Rabbi,” and kissed Him.

(Mark 14:46) 
Then they laid hands on Him.

(Mark 14:47) 
One of the bystanders drew his sword, struck the servant of the high priest, and cut off his ear.

(Mark 14:48) 
Jesus said to them in reply, “Have you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs, to seize Me?

(Mark 14:49) 
Day after day I was with you in the temple teaching, and you did not arrest Me; but that the Scriptures may be fulfilled.”

(Mark 14:50) 
And they all left Him and fled.

(Mark 14:51) 
Now a young man followed Him, wearing nothing but a linen cloth about his body. They tried to seize him,

(Mark 14:52) 
but he left the linen cloth behind and ran off naked.

(Mark 14:53) 
They led Jesus away to the high priest, and all the chief priests and the elders and the scribes came together.

(Mark 14:54) 
Peter followed Him at a distance, right into the high priest's courtyard, where he sat with the guards and warmed himself by the fire.

(Mark 14:55) 
The chief priests and the whole Sanhedrin were seeking testimony against Jesus so they could put Him to death, but they found none.

(Mark 14:56) 
Many gave false testimony against Him, but their testimonies did not agree.

(Mark 14:57) 
Some began to give false testimony against Him, saying,

(Mark 14:58) 
“We heard Him say, ‘I will destroy this temple made with hands and within three days I will build another not made with hands.’”

(Mark 14:59) 
But not even so did their testimony agree.

(Mark 14:60) 
The high priest rose before them and questioned Jesus, saying, “Have you no answer? What are these men testifying against you?”

(Mark 14:61) 
But He remained silent and answered nothing. Again the high priest questioned Him and said to Him, “Are you the Christ, the Son of the Blessed One?”

(Mark 14:62) 
Jesus said, “I AM; and you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of the Power and coming with the clouds of the sky.”

(Mark 14:63) 
The high priest tore his garments and said, “What further need have we of witnesses?

(Mark 14:64) 
You have heard the blasphemy. What do you think?” They all condemned Him as deserving to die.

(Mark 14:65) 
Some began to spit on Him. They blindfolded Him and began to beat Him, and to say to Him, “Prophesy!”

(Mark 14:66) 
The guards also took Him and beat Him.

(Mark 14:67) 
While Peter was below in the courtyard, one of the high priest’s maids came.

(Mark 14:68) 
Seeing Peter warming himself, she looked intently at him and said, “You too were with Jesus of Nazareth.”

(Mark 14:69) 
But he denied it, saying, “I neither know nor understand what you are saying.” And he went out to the forecourt, and the cock crowed.

(Mark 14:70) 
The maid saw him and began again to say to the bystanders, “This man is one of them.”

(Mark 14:71) 
He again denied it. After a little while the bystanders again said to Peter, “Surely you are one of them; for you are a Galilean.”

(Mark 14:72) 
He began to curse and to swear, “I do not know this man about whom you are speaking.”

(Mark 14:73) 
Immediately the cock crowed a second time. Peter remembered the word that Jesus had said to him, “Before the cock crows twice, you will deny Me three times.” And he broke down and wept.

(Mark 15:1) 
Early in the morning, the high priests, elders, scribes, and the entire council made a plan. They bound Jesus, brought Him, and handed Him over to Pilate.

(Mark 15:2) 
Pilate questioned Him, asking: “Are you the king of the Jews?” He replied: “You say so.”

(Mark 15:3) 
And many accused Him of many things.

(Mark 15:4) 
Pilate questioned Him again, saying: “Won’t you answer? See how many things they are accusing you of?”

(Mark 15:5) 
But Jesus still did not reply, so Pilate was amazed.

(Mark 15:6) 
Now, it was customary for him to release one prisoner at the feast, whomever they requested.

(Mark 15:7) 
There was a man called Barabbas, who was imprisoned with those who had started a revolt and committed murder during the revolt.

(Mark 15:8) 
The crowd then came up and began to request that he do for them what he always did.

(Mark 15:9) 
Pilate answered them, saying: “Do you want me to release for you the king of the Jews?”

(Mark 15:10) 
For he knew that the high priests had handed Him over out of envy.

(Mark 15:11) 
The high priests stirred up the crowd so that he would release Barabbas for them instead.

(Mark 15:12) 
Pilate answered them again, saying: “Then what do you want me to do with the king of the Jews?”

(Mark 15:13) 
They shouted back: “Crucify him!”

(Mark 15:14) 
Pilate said to them: “Why, what wrong has he done?” But they shouted all the louder: “Crucify him!”

(Mark 15:15) 
Pilate, wanting to satisfy the crowd, released Barabbas for them and handed Jesus over to be scourged and crucified.

(Mark 15:16) 
The soldiers then brought Him into the courtyard, that is, the praetorium, and called together the entire cohort.

(Mark 15:17) 
They put a purple cloak on Him, and twisted a crown of thorns and placed it on Him.

(Mark 15:18) 
Then they began to salute Him: “Hail, king of the Jews!”

(Mark 15:19) 
And they struck Him on the head with a reed. They spat on Him, and bowing their knees, they worshipped Him.

(Mark 15:20) 
After mocking Him, they took the purple cloak off Him and put His own clothes back on. Then they led Him out to crucify Him.

(Mark 15:21) 
They compelled a certain passer-by, Simon of Cyrene, who was coming from the country, the father of Alexander and Rufus, to carry His cross.

(Mark 15:22) 
They brought Him to the place Golgotha, which means, the place of the skull.

(Mark 15:23) 
They offered Him wine mixed with myrrh, but He didn’t take it.

(Mark 15:24) 
And they crucified Him, and divided His garments among them, casting lots for them to see what each one would take.

(Mark 15:25) 
It was the third hour when they crucified Him.

(Mark 15:26) 
The inscription of the charge against Him was written: “The King of the Jews.”

(Mark 15:27) 
With Him, they crucified two thieves, one on His right and the other on His left.

(Mark 15:28) 
And the Scripture was fulfilled which says, “And he was counted among the wicked.”

(Mark 15:29) 
Those who passed by blasphemed Him, shaking their heads and saying, “Aha! You who destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days,

(Mark 15:30) 
save yourself by coming down from the cross!”

(Mark 15:31) 
In the same way, the high priests mocked Him among themselves with the scribes, saying, “He saved others; He can’t save Himself.”

(Mark 15:32) 
“Let Christ, the king of Israel, come down now from the cross, so that we may see and believe.” Even those who were crucified with Him reviled Him.

(Mark 15:33) 
When the sixth hour came, darkness fell over the whole earth until the ninth hour.

(Mark 15:34) 
At the ninth hour, Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, “Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani?” which means, “My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?”

(Mark 15:35) 
Some of the bystanders, hearing this, said: “Look, he’s calling for Elijah.”

(Mark 15:36) 
Someone ran and filled a sponge with vinegar, put it on a reed, and offered it to Him to drink, saying, “Wait! Let us see if Elijah comes to take Him down.”

(Mark 15:37) 
Then Jesus, uttering a loud cry, breathed His last.

(Mark 15:38) 
And the veil of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom.

(Mark 15:39) 
When the centurion who stood facing Him saw that He had breathed His last in this way, he said, “Truly this man was the Son of God.”

(Mark 15:40) 
There were also women looking on from a distance, among whom were Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James the younger and of Joses, and Salome.

(Mark 15:41) 
They had followed Him when He was in Galilee, ministering to Him, and there were many other women who had come up with Him to Jerusalem.

(Mark 15:42) 
When evening had come, because it was the Preparation Day, that is, the day before the Sabbath,

(Mark 15:43) 
Joseph of Arimathaea, a respected member of the council, who was also waiting for the kingdom of God, took courage and went to Pilate to ask for the body of Jesus.

(Mark 15:44) 
Pilate was surprised that He was already dead, and summoning the centurion, he asked him if He was already dead.

(Mark 15:45) 
When he learned this from the centurion, he granted the body to Joseph.

(Mark 15:46) 
Having bought a linen shroud, Joseph took Him down, wrapped Him in the linen, and laid Him in a tomb that had been cut out of the rock. Then he rolled a stone against the entrance of the tomb.

(Mark 15:47) 
Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses were looking on where He was laid.

(Mark 16:1) 
After the Sabbath was over, Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought perfumed oils, so that when they came to the tomb, they could anoint Jesus.

(Mark 16:2) 
And very early on the first day of the week, they came to the tomb. The sun had just risen.

(Mark 16:3) 
And they were saying to one another: "Who will roll away the stone from the entrance of the tomb?"

(Mark 16:4) 
But looking up, they saw that the stone had been rolled away. It was very large.

(Mark 16:5) 
And entering into the tomb, they saw a young man sitting on the right, wearing a white robe, and they were astonished.

(Mark 16:6) 
The young man said to them: "Do not be terrified. You are seeking Jesus of Nazareth, who was crucified. He has risen; He is not here. See the place where they laid Him.

(Mark 16:7) 
But go, tell His disciples and Peter, that He goes before you into Galilee. There you will see Him, as He said to you."

(Mark 16:8) 
And they went out and fled from the tomb, for trembling and fear had seized them. And they said nothing to anyone, for they were afraid.

(Mark 16:9) 
Now when Jesus rose early on the first day of the week, He appeared first to Mary Magdalene, from whom He had cast out seven demons.

(Mark 16:10) 
She went and announced the news to those who had been with Him, who were mourning and weeping.

(Mark 16:11) 
And when they heard that He was alive and had been seen by her, they did not believe.

(Mark 16:12) 
After this, He appeared in a different form to two of them while they were walking to the country.

(Mark 16:13) 
And they went and told the others, and they did not believe them.

(Mark 16:14) 
Finally, as they were reclining at table, He appeared to the eleven. And He rebuked their unbelief and hardness of heart because they had not believed those who saw Him after He had risen.

(Mark 16:15) 
And He said to them: "Go into the entire world and preach the Gospel to every creature.

(Mark 16:16) 
Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved, but whoever does not believe will be condemned.

(Mark 16:17) 
And these signs will accompany those who believe: In My name they will cast out demons; they will speak in new tongues;

(Mark 16:18) 
they will pick up serpents, and if they drink any deadly thing, it will not harm them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will recover."

(Mark 16:19) 
So then, after the Lord had spoken to them, He was taken up into the sky and sat at the right hand of God.

(Mark 16:20) 
And they went forth and preached everywhere, while the Lord worked with them and confirmed the word by the signs that followed.

(Luke 1:1) 
Many have undertaken to draw up an account of the events that have been fulfilled among us,

(Luke 1:2) 
as they were handed down to us by those who from the beginning were eyewitnesses and servants of the word.

(Luke 1:3) 
Therefore, since I myself have carefully investigated everything from the beginning, it seemed good also to me to write an orderly account for you, most excellent Theophilus,

(Luke 1:4) 
so that you may know the certainty of the things you have been taught.

(Luke 1:5) 
In the time of Herod king of Judea, there was a priest named Zechariah, of the division of Abijah; and his wife was a descendant of Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.

(Luke 1:6) 
Both of them were righteous before God, walking in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blamelessly.

(Luke 1:7) 
But they had no children, because Elizabeth was barren, and both were advanced in years.

(Luke 1:8) 
Once when Zechariah was serving as priest before God in the order of his division,

(Luke 1:9) 
according to the custom of the priesthood, he was chosen by lot to enter the temple of the Lord and burn incense.

(Luke 1:10) 
And the whole multitude of the people were praying outside at the hour of incense.

(Luke 1:11) 
Then there appeared to him an angel of the Lord, standing on the right side of the altar of incense.

(Luke 1:12) 
When Zechariah saw him, he was startled and was gripped with fear.

(Luke 1:13) 
But the angel said to him: “Do not be afraid, Zechariah, for your prayer has been heard, and your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you will call his name John.

(Luke 1:14) 
And you will have joy and gladness, and many will rejoice at his birth,

(Luke 1:15) 
because he will be great in the sight of the Lord. He will drink neither wine nor strong drink, and he will be filled with the Holy Spirit, even from his mother’s womb.

(Luke 1:16) 
And he will turn many of the children of Israel to the Lord their God.

(Luke 1:17) 
And he will go on before Him in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of parents to their children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the righteous, to make ready for the Lord a people prepared.”

(Luke 1:18) 
And Zechariah said to the angel, “How shall I know this? For I am an old man, and my wife is advanced in years.”

(Luke 1:19) 
And the angel answering said to him: “I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God, and was sent to speak to you and bring you this good news.

(Luke 1:20) 
And behold, you will be silent and unable to speak until the day that these things take place, because you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time.”

(Luke 1:21) 
And the people were waiting for Zechariah, and they were wondering at his delay in the temple.

(Luke 1:22) 
When he came out, he was unable to speak to them, and they realized that he had seen a vision in the temple. And he kept making signs to them and remained mute.

(Luke 1:23) 
And it came to pass that, as soon as the days of his service were completed, he departed to his own house.

(Luke 1:24) 
After those days his wife Elizabeth conceived, and for five months she kept herself hidden, saying,

(Luke 1:25) 
“Thus the Lord has done for me in the days when He looked on me, to take away my reproach among people.”

(Luke 1:26) 
In the sixth month, the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a city of Galilee named Nazareth,

(Luke 1:27) 
to a virgin betrothed to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David; and the virgin's name was Mary.

(Luke 1:28) 
And the angel came to her and said, “Hail, full of grace, the Lord is with you.” Blessed are you among women.

(Luke 1:29) 
But she was greatly troubled at the saying, and considered what sort of greeting this might be.

(Luke 1:30) 
Then the angel said to her, “Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God.

(Luke 1:31) 
And behold, you will conceive in your womb and bear a son, and you will call his name Jesus.

(Luke 1:32) 
He will be great, and will be called the Son of the Most High. And the Lord God will give to Him the throne of His father David,

(Luke 1:33) 
and He will reign over the house of Jacob forever, and of His kingdom there will be no end.”

(Luke 1:34) 
And Mary said to the angel, “How will this be, since I do not know a man?”

(Luke 1:35) 
And the angel answered her, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you; therefore the child to be born will be holy—he will be called the Son of God.

(Luke 1:36) 
And behold, your relative Elizabeth in her old age has also conceived a son; and this is the sixth month for her who was called barren.

(Luke 1:37) 
For nothing will be impossible with God.”

(Luke 1:38) 
And Mary said, “Behold, I am the servant of the Lord; let it be to me according to your word.” And the angel departed from her.

(Luke 1:39) 
In those days Mary arose and went with haste into the hill country, to a city of Judah,

(Luke 1:40) 
and she entered the house of Zechariah and greeted Elizabeth.

(Luke 1:41) 
And when Elizabeth heard the greeting of Mary, the infant leaped in her womb; and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit,

(Luke 1:42) 
and she cried out with a loud voice and said, “Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the fruit of your womb!

(Luke 1:43) 
And why is this granted to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?

(Luke 1:44) 
For behold, as soon as the sound of your greeting came to my ears, the infant in my womb leaped for joy.

(Luke 1:45) 
And blessed is she who believed that there would be a fulfillment of what was spoken to her from the Lord.”

(Luke 1:46) 
And Mary said, “My soul magnifies the Lord,

(Luke 1:47) 
and my spirit rejoices in God my Savior,

(Luke 1:48) 
for He has looked on the humble estate of His servant. For behold, from now on all generations will call me blessed;

(Luke 1:49) 
for He who is mighty has done great things for me, and holy is His name.

(Luke 1:50) 
And His mercy is for those who fear Him from generation to generation.

(Luke 1:51) 
He has shown strength with His arm; He has scattered the proud in the imagination of their hearts,

(Luke 1:52) 
He has brought down the mighty from their thrones and has exalted those of humble estate;

(Luke 1:53) 
He has filled the hungry with good things, and the rich He has sent away empty.

(Luke 1:54) 
He has helped His servant Israel, in remembrance of His mercy,

(Luke 1:55) 
as He spoke to our fathers, to Abraham and to his offspring forever.”

(Luke 1:56) 
And Mary remained with her about three months and returned to her home.

(Luke 1:57) 
Now the time came for Elizabeth to give birth, and she bore a son.

(Luke 1:58) 
And her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown great mercy to her, and they rejoiced with her.

(Luke 1:59) 
And on the eighth day they came to circumcise the child, and they were going to call him by the name of his father Zechariah,

(Luke 1:60) 
and his mother answered, “No; he shall be called John.”

(Luke 1:61) 
And they said to her, “But there is no one among your relatives who is called by this name.”

(Luke 1:62) 
And they made signs to his father, inquiring what he wanted him to be called.

(Luke 1:63) 
And he asked for a writing tablet and wrote, “His name is John.” And they all marveled.

(Luke 1:64) 
And immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue loosed, and he spoke, blessing God.

(Luke 1:65) 
And fear came upon all their neighbors, and all these things were talked about throughout all the hill country of Judea.

(Luke 1:66) 
And all who heard them laid them up in their hearts, saying, “What then will this child be?” For the hand of the Lord was with him.

(Luke 1:67) 
And his father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit, and prophesied, saying,

(Luke 1:68) 
“Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, for He has visited and redeemed His people

(Luke 1:69) 
and has raised up a horn of salvation for us in the house of His servant David,

(Luke 1:70) 
as He spoke by the mouth of His holy prophets from of old,

(Luke 1:71) 
that we should be saved from our enemies and from the hand of all who hate us;

(Luke 1:72) 
to show mercy to our fathers and to remember His holy covenant,

(Luke 1:73) 
the oath that He swore to our father Abraham, to grant us

(Luke 1:74) 
that we, being delivered from the hand of our enemies, might serve Him without fear,

(Luke 1:75) 
in holiness and righteousness before Him all our days.

(Luke 1:76) 
And you, child, will be called the prophet of the Most High; for you will go before the Lord to prepare His ways,

(Luke 1:77) 
to give knowledge of salvation to His people in the forgiveness of their sins,

(Luke 1:78) 
because of the tender mercy of our God, whereby the sunrise shall visit us from on high

(Luke 1:79) 
to give light to those who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the way of peace.”

(Luke 1:80) 
And the child grew and became strong in spirit, and he was in the wilderness until the day of his appearing to Israel.

(Luke 2:1) 
In those days, Caesar Augustus gave a decree for a census to be taken of the entire world.

(Luke 2:2) 
This first census took place when Quirinius was governor of Syria.

(Luke 2:3) 
And everyone went to be registered, each person to their own city.

(Luke 2:4) 
So Joseph went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to the city of David, called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and lineage of David,

(Luke 2:5) 
to be registered with Mary, his espoused wife, who was pregnant.

(Luke 2:6) 
And it came to pass that, while they were there, the days were fulfilled for her to give birth.

(Luke 2:7) 
She brought forth her firstborn Son, wrapped Him in swaddling clothes, and laid Him in a manger, because there was no room for them in the inn.

(Luke 2:8) 
And there were shepherds in the same region, keeping watch and guarding the night over their flock.

(Luke 2:9) 
And behold, an angel of the Lord stood next to them, and the glory of God shone round about them, and they were greatly afraid.

(Luke 2:10) 
Then the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid, for behold, I bring you good news of great joy that will be for all the people:

(Luke 2:11) 
For to you is born this day in the city of David a Savior, who is Christ the Lord.

(Luke 2:12) 
And this is a sign for you: you will find a baby wrapped in swaddling clothes and lying in a manger.”

(Luke 2:13) 
And suddenly there appeared with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God and saying:

(Luke 2:14) 
“Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace to those He favors.”

(Luke 2:15) 
And it came to pass, when the angels went away from them into the sky, that the shepherds said to one another, “Let us go over to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has made known to us.”

(Luke 2:16) 
And they went with haste and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby lying in a manger.

(Luke 2:17) 
When they had seen, they made known the saying which was told them concerning this Child.

(Luke 2:18) 
And all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds told them.

(Luke 2:19) 
But Mary kept all these things, pondering them in her heart.

(Luke 2:20) 
And the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all they had heard and seen, as it was told them.

(Luke 2:21) 
And when eight days were fulfilled for circumcising the Child, His name was called Jesus, the name given by the angel before He was conceived in the womb.

(Luke 2:22) 
And when the days of her purification according to the Law of Moses were fulfilled, they brought Him to Jerusalem to present Him to the Lord,

(Luke 2:23) 
(as it is written in the Law of the Lord, “Every male who opens the womb shall be called holy to the Lord,”)

(Luke 2:24) 
and to offer a sacrifice according to what is said in the Law of the Lord, “a pair of turtledoves or two young pigeons.”

(Luke 2:25) 
And behold, there was a man in Jerusalem whose name was Simeon, and this man was righteous and devout, looking for the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was upon him.

(Luke 2:26) 
And it had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he would not see death before he had seen the Lord’s Christ.

(Luke 2:27) 
And he came in the Spirit into the temple. And when the parents brought in the Child Jesus to do for Him according to the custom of the Law,

(Luke 2:28) 
he took Him up in his arms and blessed God and said:

(Luke 2:29) 
“Now, Lord, You are letting Your servant depart in peace, according to Your word;

(Luke 2:30) 
For my eyes have seen Your salvation

(Luke 2:31) 
Which You have prepared before the face of all peoples,

(Luke 2:32) 
A light for revelation to the Gentiles, and the glory of Your people Israel.”

(Luke 2:33) 
And his father and mother were marveling at the things spoken concerning Him.

(Luke 2:34) 
And Simeon blessed them and said to Mary His mother, “Behold, this Child is destined for the fall and rising of many in Israel, and for a sign which will be spoken against

(Luke 2:35) 
and a sword will pierce through your own soul also, that the thoughts of many hearts may be revealed.”

(Luke 2:36) 
And there was a prophetess, Anna, the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Asher. She was advanced in years, having lived with her husband seven years from her virginity,

(Luke 2:37) 
and then as a widow until she was eighty-four years old. She did not depart from the temple, serving God with fastings and prayers night and day.

(Luke 2:38) 
And coming up at that very hour, she gave thanks to God and spoke of Him to all those who were looking for the redemption of Jerusalem.

(Luke 2:39) 
And when they had performed everything according to the Law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee, to their own city of Nazareth.

(Luke 2:40) 
And the Child continued to grow and become strong, filled with wisdom, and the favor of God was upon Him.

(Luke 2:41) 
Now His parents went to Jerusalem every year at the Feast of the Passover.

(Luke 2:42) 
And when He was twelve years old, they went up to Jerusalem according to the custom of the Feast,

(Luke 2:43) 
and as they were returning, after spending the full number of days, the boy Jesus remained in Jerusalem, but His parents did not know it.

(Luke 2:44) 
Assuming Him to be in the caravan, they went a day’s journey, and they began looking for Him among their relatives and acquaintances.

(Luke 2:45) 
When they did not find Him, they returned to Jerusalem, looking for Him.

(Luke 2:46) 
After three days they found Him in the temple, sitting in the midst of the teachers, both listening to them and asking them questions.

(Luke 2:47) 
And all who heard Him were amazed at His understanding and His answers.

(Luke 2:48) 
When they saw Him, they were astonished; and His mother said to Him, “Son, why have You treated us like this? Behold, Your father and I have been anxiously looking for You.”

(Luke 2:49) 
And He said to them, “Why were you looking for Me? Did you not know that I must be about My Father’s business?”

(Luke 2:50) 
But they did not understand the statement which He spoke to them.

(Luke 2:51) 
And He went down with them and came to Nazareth, and was subject to them, and His mother kept all these things in her heart.

(Luke 2:52) 
And Jesus kept increasing in wisdom and stature, and in favor with God and men.

(Luke 3:1) 
In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, when Pontius Pilate was governing Judea, Herod was tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip was tetrarch of Ituraea and the region of Trachonitis, and Lysanias was tetrarch of Abilene,

(Luke 3:2) 
during the high priesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of the Lord came to John, the son of Zechariah, in the desert.

(Luke 3:3) 
And he went into all the country around the Jordan, preaching the baptism of repentance for the remission of sins.

(Luke 3:4) 
As it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet: "The voice of one crying in the desert: 'Prepare the way of the Lord, make straight his paths.'

(Luke 3:5) 
'Every valley shall be filled, and every mountain and hill shall be brought low: and the crooked shall be made straight, and the rough ways shall be made smooth.'

(Luke 3:6) 
'And all flesh shall see the salvation of God.'

(Luke 3:7) 
He therefore said to the crowds that went out to be baptized by him: "Offspring of vipers, who has shown you how to flee from the wrath to come?

(Luke 3:8) 
Bring forth therefore fruits worthy of repentance; and do not begin to say, 'We have Abraham for our father.' For I tell you that God is able, even from these stones, to raise up children to Abraham.

(Luke 3:9) 
For now the axe is laid to the root of the trees. Every tree therefore that does not produce good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.

(Luke 3:10) 
And the crowds were questioning him, saying: "What then should we do?

(Luke 3:11) 
And he answering, said to them: "He that has two coats, let him give to him that has none; and he that has food, let him do in like manner.

(Luke 3:12) 
And the publicans also came to be baptized; and they said to him: "Master, what shall we do?

(Luke 3:13) 
But he said to them: "Do nothing more than that which is appointed to you.

(Luke 3:14) 
And the soldiers also questioned him, saying: "And we, what shall we do?" And he said to them: "Do violence to no one, nor accuse anyone falsely; and be content with your pay.

(Luke 3:15) 
Now as the people were in expectation, and all were thinking in their hearts of John, if perhaps he were Christ,

(Luke 3:16) 
John, answering, said to them all: "I indeed baptize you with water; but there shall come one mightier than I, the strap of whose shoes I am not worthy to loose: he shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost and with fire.

(Luke 3:17) 
Whose fan is in his hand, and he will purge his floor, and will gather the wheat into his granary; but the chaff he will burn with unquenchable fire.

(Luke 3:18) 
And many other things, exhorting, he preached to the people.

(Luke 3:19) 
But Herod the tetrarch, when he was reproved by him for Herodias his brother's wife, and for all the evils that Herod had done,

(Luke 3:20) 
added this also above all, and shut up John in prison.

(Luke 3:21) 
Now it came to pass, when all the people were baptized, that Jesus also being baptized and praying, heaven was opened;

(Luke 3:22) 
And the Holy Ghost descended in a bodily shape, as a dove upon him; and a voice came from heaven: "Thou art my beloved Son; in thee I am well pleased.

(Luke 3:23) 
And Jesus himself was beginning about thirty years old, being (as was supposed) the son of Joseph, who was of Heli,

(Luke 3:24) 
who was of Matthath, who was of Levi, who was of Melchi, who was of Janna, who was of Joseph,

(Luke 3:25) 
who was of Mattathias, who was of Amos, who was of Nahum, who was of Esli, who was of Naggae,

(Luke 3:26) 
who was of Maath, who was of Mattathias, who was of Semei, who was of Josech, who was of Joda,

(Luke 3:27) 
who was of Joannan, who was of Rhesa, who was of Zorobabel, who was of Salaathiel, who was of Neri,

(Luke 3:28) 
who was of Melchi, who was of Addi, who was of Chosam, who was of Elmodam, who was of Her,

(Luke 3:29) 
who was of Jose, who was of Eliezer, who was of Jorim, who was of Matthath, who was of Levi,

(Luke 3:30) 
who was of Simeon, who was of Juda, who was of Joseph, who was of Jona, who was of Eliachim,

(Luke 3:31) 
who was of Melea, who was of Menna, who was of Matthata, who was of Nathan, who was of David,

(Luke 3:32) 
who was of Isai, who was of Obed, who was of Booz, who was of Sela, who was of Aram,

(Luke 3:33) 
who was of Aminadab, who was of Admin, who was of Arni, who was of Esrom, who was of Phares, who was of Juda,

(Luke 3:34) 
who was of Jacob, who was of Isaac, who was of Abraham, who was of Thare, who was of Nachor,

(Luke 3:35) 
who was of Seruch, who was of Ragau, who was of Phalec, who was of Heber, who was of Sale,

(Luke 3:36) 
who was of Cainan, who was of Arphaxad, who was of Sem, who was of Noe, who was of Lamech,

(Luke 3:37) 
who was of Matusala, who was of Enoch, who was of Jared, who was of Malaleel, who was of Cainan,

(Luke 3:38) 
who was of Enos, who was of Seth, who was of Adam, who was of God.

(Luke 4:1) 
Filled with the Holy Spirit, Jesus returned from the Jordan, and was led by the Spirit into the desert.

(Luke 4:2) 
There, He was tested by the Devil for forty days. And during those days, He ate nothing. When those days were over, He was hungry.

(Luke 4:3) 
The Devil said to Him, "If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become bread."

(Luke 4:4) 
Jesus answered him, "It is written: ‘Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word of God.’"

(Luke 4:5) 
Then the Devil led Him up and showed Him all the kingdoms of the world in an instant.

(Luke 4:6) 
And the Devil said to Him, "To you I will give all this power and their glory, because it has been given to me, and I give it to whomever I wish."

(Luke 4:7) 
If you worship me, then all shall be yours."

(Luke 4:8) 
Jesus answered him, "It is written: ‘You shall worship the Lord your God, and Him only shall you serve.’"

(Luke 4:9) 
Then he brought Him to Jerusalem and placed Him on the highest part of the Temple, and said to Him, "If you are the Son of God, throw Yourself down from here;

(Luke 4:10) 
for it is written, ‘He will command His angels concerning you, to guard you;’

(Luke 4:11) 
and ‘On their hands they will bear you up, lest at any time you dash your foot against a stone.’"

(Luke 4:12) 
And Jesus answering, said to him, "It is said: ‘You shall not tempt the Lord your God.’"

(Luke 4:13) 
When the Devil had finished every temptation, he departed from Him for a time.

(Luke 4:14) 
Then Jesus returned in the power of the Spirit to Galilee, and news about Him went out through all the surrounding region.

(Luke 4:15) 
And He taught in their synagogues, being glorified by all.

(Luke 4:16) 
He came to Nazareth, where He had been brought up. And, as was His custom, He went into the synagogue on the Sabbath day and stood up to read.

(Luke 4:17) 
And the book of the prophet Isaiah was handed to Him. When He had opened the book, He found the place where it was written:

(Luke 4:18) 
“The Spirit of the Lord is upon Me, because He has anointed Me to preach the Gospel to the poor; He has sent Me to heal the brokenhearted, to preach deliverance to the captives, and recovery of sight to the blind, to set at liberty those who are oppressed,

(Luke 4:19) 
to preach the acceptable year of the Lord."

(Luke 4:20) 
Then He closed the book, and gave it back to the attendant and sat down. The eyes of all those in the synagogue were fixed on Him.

(Luke 4:21) 
And He began to say to them, “Today this Scripture is fulfilled in your hearing.”

(Luke 4:22) 
And all bore witness to Him and marveled at the gracious words that proceeded out of His mouth. And they said, “Is this not the son of Joseph?”

(Luke 4:23) 
And He said to them, "You will surely quote this proverb to Me: ‘Physician, heal yourself! Whatever we have heard done in Capernaum, do also here in Your country.’"

(Luke 4:24) 
And He said, "Truly I say to you, no prophet is accepted in his own country.

(Luke 4:25) 
But I tell you truly, many widows were in Israel in the days of Elijah, when the sky was shut up for three years and six months, and when great famine was throughout all the land;

(Luke 4:26) 
and Elijah was sent to none of them except to Zarephath, in the land of Sidon, to a woman who was a widow.

(Luke 4:27) 
And many lepers were in Israel in the time of Elisha the prophet, and none of them were cleansed except Naaman the Syrian."

(Luke 4:28) 
And all those in the synagogue, when they heard these things, were filled with wrath.

(Luke 4:29) 
Then they rose up and thrust Him out of the city, and led Him to the brow of the hill on which their city was built, that they might throw Him down headlong.

(Luke 4:30) 
But He, passing through their midst, went His way.

(Luke 4:31) 
Then He went down to Capernaum, a city of Galilee, and was teaching them on the Sabbath.

(Luke 4:32) 
And they were astonished at His teaching, for His word was with authority.

(Luke 4:33) 
Now in the synagogue there was a man who had a spirit of an unclean demon, and he cried out with a loud voice,

(Luke 4:34) 
saying, “Let us alone! What have we to do with You, Jesus of Nazareth? Have You come to destroy us? I know You, who You are—the Holy One of God!”

(Luke 4:35) 
But Jesus rebuked him, saying, “Be quiet, and come out of him!” And when the demon had thrown him down in their midst, it came out of him, without hurting him.

(Luke 4:36) 
Then they were all amazed, and they spoke among themselves, saying, “What is this word? For with authority and power He commands the unclean spirits, and they come out.”

(Luke 4:37) 
And the report about Him went out into every place in the surrounding region.

(Luke 4:38) 
Then He arose from the synagogue and entered Simon’s house. Now Simon’s wife’s mother was ill with a high fever, and they made request of Him concerning her.

(Luke 4:39) 
So He stood over her and rebuked the fever, and it left her. And immediately she arose and served them.

(Luke 4:40) 
When the sun was setting, all those who had any that were sick with various diseases brought them to Him. And He laid His hands on every one of them and healed them.

(Luke 4:41) 
And demons also came out of many, crying out and saying, “You are the Son of God!” And rebuking them, He did not allow them to speak, because they knew that He was the Christ.

(Luke 4:42) 
Now when day came, He departed and went into a desolate place. And the crowds were looking for Him, and came to Him, and tried to keep Him from going away from them;

(Luke 4:43) 
but He said to them, “I must preach the kingdom of God to the other cities also, because for this reason I have been sent."

(Luke 4:44) 
And He was preaching in the synagogues of Galilee.

(Luke 5:1) 
It came to pass that when the crowds pressed in on Him, wanting to hear the Word of God, He was standing by the lake of Gennesaret.

(Luke 5:2) 
He saw two boats standing by the lake, but the fishermen had left them and were washing their nets.

(Luke 5:3) 
And He, entering into one of the boats, which was Simon's, asked him to move the boat a little from the land. And, sitting down, He taught the crowds from the boat.

(Luke 5:4) 
When He had finished speaking, He said to Simon, “Launch out into the deep, and let down your nets for a catch.”

(Luke 5:5) 
And Simon answering, said to Him: “Master, we have toiled all night and taken nothing; but at your word, I will let down the net.”

(Luke 5:6) 
And when they had done this, they enclosed a great multitude of fish, and their nets were breaking.

(Luke 5:7) 
And they beckoned to their partners in the other boat to come and help them. And they came and filled both boats, so that they were almost sinking.

(Luke 5:8) 
Which when Simon Peter saw, he fell down at Jesus' knees, saying: “Depart from me, for I am a sinful man, O Lord.”

(Luke 5:9) 
For he was astonished, and all who were with him, at the catch of the fish that they had taken.

(Luke 5:10) 
And so also James and John, the sons of Zebedee, who were Simon's partners. And Jesus said to Simon, “Do not fear; from now on you will be catching men.”

(Luke 5:11) 
And when they had brought the boats to land, they left everything and followed Him.

(Luke 5:12) 
And it came to pass that when He was in one of the cities, behold, a man full of leprosy; and seeing Jesus, he fell on his face and besought Him, saying: “Lord, if You will, You can make me clean.”

(Luke 5:13) 
And extending His hand, He touched him, saying: “I will; be clean.” And immediately the leprosy left him.

(Luke 5:14) 
And He charged him to tell no one, but “Go, show yourself to the priest, and offer for your cleansing as Moses commanded, for a testimony to them.”

(Luke 5:15) 
But so much the more the report about Him spread, and great multitudes came together to hear, and to be healed of their infirmities.

(Luke 5:16) 
But He was withdrawing to the deserts and praying.

(Luke 5:17) 
And it came to pass on one of those days, that He was teaching, and there were Pharisees and doctors of the law sitting by, who had come out of every town of Galilee and Judea and Jerusalem; and the power of the Lord was present to heal them.

(Luke 5:18) 
And behold, men were carrying a man on a bed who was paralyzed; and they were seeking to bring him in and to set him before Him.

(Luke 5:19) 
And not finding by what way they might bring him in because of the crowd, they went upon the housetop, and let him down with the bed through the tiles into the midst before Jesus.

(Luke 5:20) 
When He saw their faith, He said: “Man, your sins are forgiven you.”

(Luke 5:21) 
And the scribes and the Pharisees began to question, saying: “Who is this that speaks blasphemies? Who can forgive sins, but God alone?”

(Luke 5:22) 
But Jesus, knowing their thoughts, answering, said to them: “What do you question in your hearts?

(Luke 5:23) 
Which is easier, to say: ‘Your sins are forgiven you,’ or to say: ‘Rise and walk’?

(Luke 5:24) 
But that you may know that the Son of Man has the power on earth to forgive sins, He said to the paralytic: “I say to you, arise, take up your bed, and go to your house.”

(Luke 5:25) 
And immediately rising up before them, and taking up the bed on which he was lying, he went to his own house, glorifying God.

(Luke 5:26) 
And amazement took hold of all, and they glorified God; and they were filled with fear, saying: “We have seen wonderful things today.”

(Luke 5:27) 
And after these things, He went out and saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at the tax office, and He said to him: “Follow Me.”

(Luke 5:28) 
And leaving everything, he arose and followed Him.

(Luke 5:29) 
And Levi made Him a great feast in his own house; and there was a large crowd of tax collectors and others who were reclining with them.

(Luke 5:30) 
And the Pharisees and their scribes murmured against His disciples, saying: “Why do you eat and drink with the tax collectors and sinners?”

(Luke 5:31) 
And Jesus answering, said to them: “Those who are well do not need a physician, but those who are sick.”

(Luke 5:32) 
“I have not come to call the just, but sinners to repentance.”

(Luke 5:33) 
And they said to Him: “The disciples of John fast often and make supplications; likewise, the Pharisees do; but Yours eat and drink.”

(Luke 5:34) 
To whom Jesus said: “Can you make the sons of the bridegroom fast while the bridegroom is with them?

(Luke 5:35) 
“But the days will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them; then they will fast in those days.”

(Luke 5:36) 
He spoke also a parable to them: “No one puts a piece from a new garment onto an old garment; otherwise, the new will tear, and the piece from the new will not match the old.”

(Luke 5:37) 
“And no one puts new wine into old wineskins; otherwise, the new wine will burst the wineskins, and it will be spilled, and the wineskins will be ruined.

(Luke 5:38) 
“But new wine must be put into fresh wineskins; then both are preserved.”

(Luke 5:39) 
And no one, drinking the old, wants the new immediately; for he says, ‘The old is better.’”

(Luke 6:1) 
One Sabbath day, Jesus went out through a field of grain. His disciples began to pluck some heads of grain, rubbing them in their hands.

(Luke 6:2) 
Some Pharisees said, “Why are you doing things that are not allowed on the Sabbath?”

(Luke 6:3) 
Jesus answered, “Haven’t you read about how David and those who were with him did when they were hungry?

(Luke 6:4) 
He went into God’s house, and took the bread offered to God, and ate it, and gave it to his companions. He was not permitted to eat this bread because it was only for the priests.

(Luke 6:5) 
Then He told them, “The Son of Man is Lord, even of the Sabbath.”

(Luke 6:6) 
On another Sabbath, Jesus entered the synagogue and began to teach. There was a man there whose right hand was shriveled.

(Luke 6:7) 
The scribes and the Pharisees watched Him closely to see if He would heal on the Sabbath, so they could accuse Him.

(Luke 6:8) 
Jesus knew what they were thinking. He said to the man with the shriveled hand, “Get up and stand in the middle.” He got up and stood there.

(Luke 6:9) 
Jesus then said to them, “I ask you, is it lawful to do good on the Sabbath, or to do evil? To save a life, or to destroy it?”

(Luke 6:10) 
Then He looked around at everyone. He said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” The man did so, and his hand was restored.

(Luke 6:11) 
But they were filled with rage, and began to talk about what they should do to Jesus.

(Luke 6:12) 
In these days, Jesus went out to the mountain to pray, and He spent the night in prayer to God.

(Luke 6:13) 
When the sun rose, He called His disciples and chose twelve of them, whom He also named Apostles.

(Luke 6:14) 
Simon, whom He named Peter, and Andrew, his brother; James and John, Philip and Bartholomew,

(Luke 6:15) 
Matthew and Thomas; James the son of Alphaeus, and Simon, who is called the Zealot,

(Luke 6:16) 
Judas the son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who was a traitor.

(Luke 6:17) 
He came down with them and stood on a level place, and a large crowd of His disciples, and a great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon.

(Luke 6:18) 
They had come to hear Him and be healed of their diseases. Those tormented by evil spirits were cured.

(Luke 6:19) 
And all the crowd were trying to touch Him, because power was coming from Him that was healing everyone.

(Luke 6:20) 
Then Jesus looked at His disciples and said: “Blessed are you who are poor, because yours is the kingdom of God.

(Luke 6:21) 
Blessed are you who hunger now, because you will be filled. Blessed are you who weep now, because you will laugh.

(Luke 6:22) 
Blessed are you when people hate you, and when they exclude you and revile you, and reject your name as evil, on account of the Son of Man.

(Luke 6:23) 
Rejoice on that day and leap for joy, because your reward is great in the universe. Their ancestors treated the prophets in the same way.

(Luke 6:24) 
But woe to you who are rich, because you have received your consolation.

(Luke 6:25) 
Woe to you who are full now, because you will be hungry. Woe to you who laugh now, because you will mourn and weep.

(Luke 6:26) 
Woe to you when all speak well of you, for their ancestors treated the false prophets in the same way.

(Luke 6:27) 
But I say to you who hear: Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you.

(Luke 6:28) 
Bless those who curse you, and pray for those who mistreat you.

(Luke 6:29) 
To the one who strikes you on the cheek, offer the other also. From the one who takes away your cloak, do not withhold your tunic either.

(Luke 6:30) 
Give to everyone who asks you, and do not ask for your belongings back from the one who takes them away.

(Luke 6:31) 
And as you want people to do to you, do the same to them.

(Luke 6:32) 
If you love those who love you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners love those who love them.

(Luke 6:33) 
If you do good to those who do good to you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners do that.

(Luke 6:34) 
And if you lend to those from whom you expect to receive, what credit is that to you? Even sinners lend to sinners to get back the same amount.

(Luke 6:35) 
But love your enemies, do good, and lend, expecting nothing in return. Your reward will be great, and you will be children of the Most High, for He is kind to the ungrateful and the wicked.

(Luke 6:36) 
Be merciful, just as your Father is merciful.

(Luke 6:37) 
Do not judge, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn, and you will not be condemned. Forgive, and you will be forgiven.

(Luke 6:38) 
Give, and it will be given to you. A good measure, pressed down, shaken together, and overflowing, will be poured into your lap. For with the measure you use, it will be measured to you.”

(Luke 6:39) 
He also told them this parable: “Can a blind man lead a blind man? Will they not both fall into a pit?

(Luke 6:40) 
A disciple is not above his teacher, but everyone who is fully trained will be like their teacher.

(Luke 6:41) 
Why do you see the speck that is in your brother’s eye, but do not notice the log that is in your own eye?

(Luke 6:42)
