we are persecuted, but we are not abandoned; we are cast down, but we don't perish:

(2 Corinthians 4:10) 
always carrying about in our body the mortification of Jesus: so that the life of Jesus may be revealed in our bodies.

(2 Corinthians 4:11) 
For we who live are always delivered to death for Jesus' sake: so that the life of Jesus may be revealed in our mortal flesh.

(2 Corinthians 4:12) 
Therefore, death is at work in us, but life in you.

(2 Corinthians 4:13) 
But having the same spirit of faith, as it is written: "I believed, therefore I spoke," we also believe, therefore we speak:

(2 Corinthians 4:14) 
knowing that He who raised up Jesus will raise us also with Jesus and place us with you.

(2 Corinthians 4:15) 
For all things are for you, so that the abundance of grace, by many thanksgivings, may abound to the glory of God.

(2 Corinthians 4:16) 
Therefore we don't give up: but even though our outer man is decaying, our inner man is renewed day by day.

(2 Corinthians 4:17) 
For that which is at present momentary and light of our tribulation, works for us, above all measure, an eternal weight of glory:

(2 Corinthians 4:18) 
as we don't look at the things that are seen, but at the things that are not seen. For the things that are seen are temporal, but the things that are not seen are eternal.

(2 Corinthians 5:1) 
We know that when our earthly body dies, God has a building prepared for us. It's not made by human hands but eternal in heaven.

(2 Corinthians 5:2) 
We groan in our bodies, longing to be clothed in a heavenly dwelling.

(2 Corinthians 5:3) 
We hope that when we are clothed, we are not found naked of good works.

(2 Corinthians 5:4) 
Indeed, we groan under the weight of this tent we call our body. Not that we want to be unclothed but rather clothed in new life, so that what is mortal is swallowed up by life eternal.

(2 Corinthians 5:5) 
God, who prepared us for this, has given us the Holy Spirit as a pledge.

(2 Corinthians 5:6) 
So we are always confident, knowing that while we are in the body, we are away from the Lord.

(2 Corinthians 5:7) 
We walk by faith, not by sight.

(2 Corinthians 5:8) 
We are confident and prefer to be away from the body and at home with the Lord.

(2 Corinthians 5:9) 
So we make it our aim to please Him, whether at home or away.

(2 Corinthians 5:10) 
For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each one may receive what he has done in the body, whether good or bad.

(2 Corinthians 5:11) 
Knowing the fear of the Lord, we try to persuade people, and God knows our hearts. I hope that you understand us too.

(2 Corinthians 5:12) 
We are not commending ourselves to you again, but we are giving you an opportunity to be proud of us, so you can answer those who boast about outward appearance and not their inner hearts.

(2 Corinthians 5:13) 
For whether we are out of our minds, it is for God; or whether we are sober, it is for you.

(2 Corinthians 5:14) 
The love of Christ compels us, because we are convinced that one died for all; therefore all have died.

(2 Corinthians 5:15) 
And He died for all, so that those who live should no longer live for themselves but for Him who died for them and was raised.

(2 Corinthians 5:16) 
From now on, therefore, we regard no one according to the flesh. Even though we once knew Christ according to the flesh, we no longer know Him that way.

(2 Corinthians 5:17) 
Therefore, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has passed away; behold, the new has come.

(2 Corinthians 5:18) 
All this is from God, who reconciled us to Himself through Christ and gave us the ministry of reconciliation.

(2 Corinthians 5:19) 
God was reconciling the world to Himself in Christ, not counting people’s sins against them. And He has committed to us the word of reconciliation.

(2 Corinthians 5:20) 
Therefore, we are ambassadors for Christ, God making His appeal through us. We implore you on behalf of Christ, be reconciled to God.

(2 Corinthians 5:21) 
For our sake He made Him to be sin who knew no sin, so that in Him we might become the righteousness of God.

(2 Corinthians 6:1) 
We are working together, and we urge you not to receive the grace of God in vain.

(2 Corinthians 6:2) 
For He says, "In an acceptable time, I have heard you, and in the day of salvation, I have helped you." Behold, now is the acceptable time; behold, now is the day of salvation.

(2 Corinthians 6:3) 
We give no offense to anyone, so that the ministry may not be blamed.

(2 Corinthians 6:4) 
But in everything, we are showing ourselves to be ministers of God: through much patience, in tribulations, in needs, in distresses,

(2 Corinthians 6:5) 
in beatings, in imprisonments, in riots, in labors, in watchings, in fastings,

(2 Corinthians 6:6) 
in purity, in knowledge, in longsuffering, in kindness, in the Holy Spirit, in love unfeigned,

(2 Corinthians 6:7) 
in the word of truth, in the power of God: through the weapons of justice on the right and on the left,

(2 Corinthians 6:8) 
through glory and dishonor, through ill repute and good repute. We are treated as deceivers, and yet we are truthful;

(2 Corinthians 6:9) 
as unknown, and yet we are well-known; as dying, and behold, we live; as punished, and yet not killed;

(2 Corinthians 6:10) 
as sorrowful, yet always rejoicing; as poor, yet enriching many; as having nothing, and yet possessing everything.

(2 Corinthians 6:11) 
Our mouth is open to you, O Corinthians; our heart is enlarged.

(2 Corinthians 6:12) 
You are not limited in us, but you are limited in your own affections.

(2 Corinthians 6:13) 
Now for the same recompense (I speak as to my children), be you also enlarged.

(2 Corinthians 6:14) 
Do not be yoked with unbelievers. For what partnership has righteousness with lawlessness? Or what fellowship does light have with darkness?

(2 Corinthians 6:15) 
What harmony does Christ have with Belial? Or what does a believer share with an unbeliever?

(2 Corinthians 6:16) 
What agreement does the temple of God have with idols? For you are the temple of the living God, as God has said: "I will dwell in them and walk among them, and I will be their God, and they will be my people."

(2 Corinthians 6:17) 
Therefore, "Come out from among them, and be separate," says the Lord, "and touch no unclean thing. And I will receive you,"

(2 Corinthians 6:18) 
"And I will be a Father to you, and you will be sons and daughters to me," says the Lord Almighty.

(2 Corinthians 7:1) 
Since we have God's promises, beloved ones, let us purify ourselves from all sin, which stains the flesh and the soul. Let us finish the work of spiritual growth, which is born of reverent fear of God.

(2 Corinthians 7:2) 
Open up your hearts to us. We haven’t harmed anyone. We haven’t corrupted anyone. We haven’t taken advantage of anyone.

(2 Corinthians 7:3) 
I don’t mean to accuse anyone. I’ve already said that you have a place in our hearts, for us to live and die with.

(2 Corinthians 7:4) 
I have great confidence in you. I am very proud of you. I am overflowing with consolation, and I am filled with joy in the midst of all our suffering.

(2 Corinthians 7:5) 
Because when we came to Macedonia, we got no rest. We were attacked on all sides. There was conflict all around us, and anxiety within.

(2 Corinthians 7:6) 
But God, who comforts the afflicted, comforted us when Titus arrived.

(2 Corinthians 7:7) 
His arrival wasn’t the only comfort, but we were consoled by the comfort he received from you. He told us about your longing to see us, your grief, and your zeal for me, so that I was even more joyful.

(2 Corinthians 7:8) 
Even though I saddened you in the letter, I don’t regret it. I do regret it, because that letter, although it was painful for a time, did sadden you.

(2 Corinthians 7:9) 
Now I am joyful, not because you were saddened, but because you were saddened to the point of repentance. Because you were saddened in the right way, according to God's will, so that you suffered no loss from us.

(2 Corinthians 7:10) 
For grief that is according to God brings repentance that leads to salvation, which will never be regretted. But the grief of the world brings death.

(2 Corinthians 7:11) 
See what this very thing—that you were saddened in the right way, according to God's will—has produced in you: great diligence, a defense of your character, indignation against sin, fear of God, longing to be reconciled, zeal for doing good, and a readiness to punish the offender. You have shown yourselves to be blameless in the matter.

(2 Corinthians 7:12) 
So, even though I wrote the letter, it wasn’t for the sake of the one who did wrong or the one who was wronged. I wrote so that you might understand the great care we have for you, as shown in the sight of God.

(2 Corinthians 7:13) 
This is why we were comforted. And in our comfort, we rejoiced even more because of Titus’s joy, for his spirit was refreshed by you all.

(2 Corinthians 7:14) 
For if I had boasted to him about you, I was not ashamed, but just as everything we said to you was true, so also our boasting about you to Titus has also proven to be true.

(2 Corinthians 7:15) 
And his heart is overflowing with affection for you as he remembers the obedience of you all, how you received him with fear and trembling.

(2 Corinthians 7:16) 
I am rejoicing that I have complete confidence in you in every way.

(2 Corinthians 8:1) 
We want you to know, brothers, about the grace of God given to the churches in Macedonia:

(2 Corinthians 8:2) 
During their great suffering, the overflowing joy and their extreme poverty were able to abound in the riches of their generosity.

(2 Corinthians 8:3) 
For I testify that they gave according to their ability and even beyond their ability; they were willing, even beyond their means,

(2 Corinthians 8:4) 
begging us with great insistence for the grace of participating in the service to the saints.

(2 Corinthians 8:5) 
And this was more than we expected, because they gave themselves first to God and then to us, by the will of God.

(2 Corinthians 8:6) 
So we urged Titus to finish what he had started. He was the one who started the grace of giving.

(2 Corinthians 8:7) 
But since you abound in everything, in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in all diligence, and in your love for us, may you also abound in this grace.

(2 Corinthians 8:8) 
I am not commanding you, but I am testing the sincerity of your love by comparing it to the diligence of others.

(2 Corinthians 8:9) 
For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ; though He was rich, for your sake He became poor, so that through His poverty you might become rich.

(2 Corinthians 8:10) 
And I give my judgment in this matter: it is to your advantage to finish what you began a year ago, and to do so with enthusiasm.

(2 Corinthians 8:11) 
Now, finish doing it, so that your readiness to give may be matched by your eagerness to give out of what you have.

(2 Corinthians 8:12) 
If the willingness is there, the offering is acceptable according to what one has, not according to what one does not have.

(2 Corinthians 8:13) 
For I do not want you to be burdened while others are relieved, but that there should be equality.

(2 Corinthians 8:14) 
At the present time, your abundance should supply their need, so that their abundance may also supply your need; then there will be equality.

(2 Corinthians 8:15) 
As it is written, “The one who gathered much did not have too much, and the one who gathered little did not have too little.”

(2 Corinthians 8:16) 
But thanks be to God, who put the same diligence for you into the heart of Titus.

(2 Corinthians 8:17) 
For he accepted the exhortation, but he is even more diligent and comes to you of his own accord.

(2 Corinthians 8:18) 
We are sending along with him the brother who is praised by all the churches for his work in the Gospel.

(2 Corinthians 8:19) 
Moreover, he was appointed by the churches to travel with us as we administer this grace for the glory of the Lord and to show our eagerness to help.

(2 Corinthians 8:20) 
We are careful to avoid any criticism of the way we administer this generous offering.

(2 Corinthians 8:21) 
We are taking pains to do what is right, not only in the eyes of the Lord but also in the eyes of others.

(2 Corinthians 8:22) 
We are sending along with them our brother, whom we have often tested in many matters and found eager, but who is now even more eager because of his great trust in you.

(2 Corinthians 8:23) 
As for Titus, he is my partner and fellow worker for your benefit. As for our brothers, they are apostles of the churches, the glory of Christ.

(2 Corinthians 8:24) 
Therefore, show these men the proof of your love and of our reason for boasting about you, before the face of the churches.

(2 Corinthians 9:1) 
Now concerning the ministry to the saints, it's unnecessary for me to write to you about it.

(2 Corinthians 9:2) 
For I know your willing spirit, of which I boast about you to the Macedonians, that Achaia has been ready since last year. And your enthusiasm has stirred up many others.

(2 Corinthians 9:3) 
I sent the brothers so that our boasting about you might not be in vain in this regard, but that, as I said, you might be prepared.

(2 Corinthians 9:4) 
Otherwise, when I come with the Macedonians and find you unprepared, we (not to say you) would be ashamed in this matter.

(2 Corinthians 9:5) 
Therefore, I considered it necessary to ask the brothers to go ahead of you to you, and prepare this promised blessing, so that it may be ready as a blessing and not as a matter of greed.

(2 Corinthians 9:6) 
I say this: The one who sows sparingly will also reap sparingly; and the one who sows generously will also reap generously.

(2 Corinthians 9:7) 
Each one must give as they have determined in their heart, not reluctantly or out of compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver.

(2 Corinthians 9:8) 
And God is able to make all grace abound toward you, so that in all things at all times, having all that you need, you may abound in every good work.

(2 Corinthians 9:9) 
As it is written, "He has scattered abroad, He has given to the poor; His righteousness endures forever."

(2 Corinthians 9:10) 
Now He who supplies seed to the sower and bread for food will supply and multiply your seed for sowing and increase the harvest of your righteousness.

(2 Corinthians 9:11) 
You will be enriched in every way so that you can be generous on every occasion, and through us your generosity will result in thanksgiving to God.

(2 Corinthians 9:12) 
For this service of ministering to the needs of the saints is not only supplying the needs of the saints but is also abounding with many thanksgivings to God.

(2 Corinthians 9:13) 
Through the proof of this service, they will glorify God for your obedience to the confession of the Gospel of Christ, and for your generosity in sharing with them and with everyone.

(2 Corinthians 9:14) 
And in their prayers for you, they long for you because of the surpassing grace of God in you.

(2 Corinthians 9:15) 
Thanks be to God for His inexpressible gift!

(2 Corinthians 10:1) 
And I, Paul, now implore you by the gentleness and humility of Christ. Some people say I seem weak when I am with you in person, but in my absence, I am a stern teacher.

(2 Corinthians 10:2) 
I beg you not to force me to be bold in my teaching. Some say I walk in worldly ways.

(2 Corinthians 10:3) 
Even though we live in the flesh, we do not wage war according to the flesh.

(2 Corinthians 10:4) 
The weapons we fight with are not those of this world, but they have divine power to demolish strongholds. We demolish arguments,

(2 Corinthians 10:5) 
and every pretension that is raised up against the knowledge of God, and we take captive every thought to make it obedient to Christ.

(2 Corinthians 10:6) 
And we will be ready to punish every act of disobedience when your obedience is complete.

(2 Corinthians 10:7) 
You are judging by mere appearances. If anyone is confident that they belong to Christ, they should consider again that we belong to Christ just as much as they do.

(2 Corinthians 10:8) 
Even if I boast somewhat more about the authority the Lord gave us for building you up rather than tearing you down, I will not be ashamed.

(2 Corinthians 10:9) 
I do not want you to think I am trying to frighten you with my letters.

(2 Corinthians 10:10) 
Some say, “His letters are weighty and forceful, but in person, he is weak, and his speech is of no account.”

(2 Corinthians 10:11) 
Such people should realize that what we are in our letters when we are absent, we will be in our actions when we are present.

(2 Corinthians 10:12) 
We do not dare to classify or compare ourselves with some who commend themselves. When they measure themselves by themselves and compare themselves with themselves, they are not wise.

(2 Corinthians 10:13) 
We, however, will not boast beyond measure, but will keep within the limits of the sphere God has assigned to us, a sphere that reaches even to you.

(2 Corinthians 10:14) 
We are not going too far in our boasting, since we were the first to come to you with the gospel of Christ.

(2 Corinthians 10:15) 
We do not boast beyond measure of other people’s labor, but we hope that as your faith increases, our sphere of activity among you will be enlarged.

(2 Corinthians 10:16) 
We want to preach the gospel to you even more, and go to places beyond you, without boasting in what has already been done in someone else's sphere.

(2 Corinthians 10:17) 
Let the one who boasts, boast in the Lord.

(2 Corinthians 10:18) 
For it is not the one who commends himself who is approved, but the one whom the Lord commends.

(2 Corinthians 11:1) 
I wish you would put up with just a little bit of my foolishness! But please bear with me.

(2 Corinthians 11:2) 
I am zealous for you with the zeal of God. I betrothed you to one husband, to present you as a chaste virgin to Christ.

(2 Corinthians 11:3) 
But I am afraid that, as the serpent deceived Eve by his cunning, your thoughts may be corrupted and led astray from a sincere and pure devotion to Christ.

(2 Corinthians 11:4) 
For if anyone comes and preaches another Jesus, whom we did not preach, or if you receive a different spirit from the one you received, or a different gospel from the one you accepted, you put up with it very well.

(2 Corinthians 11:5) 
For I consider that I am in no way inferior to these super-apostles.

(2 Corinthians 11:6) 
Even if I am unskilled in speech, I am not unskilled in knowledge. But in every way we have been fully manifested among you.

(2 Corinthians 11:7) 
Or did I commit a sin by humbling myself so that you might be exalted, because I preached the Gospel of God to you free of charge?

(2 Corinthians 11:8) 
I robbed other churches, taking wages from them to serve you.

(2 Corinthians 11:9) 
And when I was present with you and was in need, I did not burden anyone. The brothers who came from Macedonia supplied what I lacked, and in everything I have kept myself, and will keep myself, from being a burden to you.

(2 Corinthians 11:10) 
As the truth of Christ is in me, this boasting will not be silenced in me in the regions of Achaia.

(2 Corinthians 11:11) 
Why? Because I do not love you? God knows!

(2 Corinthians 11:12) 
But what I am doing, I will continue to do, in order to cut off the opportunity of those who want an opportunity to be regarded as we are in what they boast about.

(2 Corinthians 11:13) 
For such men are false apostles, deceitful workmen, disguising themselves as apostles of Christ.

(2 Corinthians 11:14) 
And no wonder, for even Satan disguises himself as an angel of light.

(2 Corinthians 11:15) 
So it is no surprise if his servants also disguise themselves as servants of righteousness, whose end will be according to their works.

(2 Corinthians 11:16) 
I say again: Let no one think me foolish. But if you do, then receive me as a fool, so that I too may boast a little.

(2 Corinthians 11:17) 
What I am saying, I am not saying as the Lord would, but as it were, in foolishness, in this confidence of boasting.

(2 Corinthians 11:18) 
Since many boast according to the flesh, I too will boast.

(2 Corinthians 11:19) 
For you gladly put up with fools, being as you are so wise!

(2 Corinthians 11:20) 
For you put up with it if anyone enslaves you, if anyone devours you, if anyone takes advantage of you, if anyone exalts himself, if anyone strikes you in the face.

(2 Corinthians 11:21) 
I say this to my shame, as though we were weak. But in whatever anyone dares to boast (I am speaking in foolishness), I also dare to boast.

(2 Corinthians 11:22) 
Are they Hebrews? So am I. Are they Israelites? So am I. Are they descendants of Abraham? So am I.

(2 Corinthians 11:23) 
Are they servants of Christ? (I am speaking as a fool.) I am more so, with far greater labors, with far more imprisonments, with countless beatings, and often near death.

(2 Corinthians 11:24) 
Five times I received from the Jews the forty lashes minus one.

(2 Corinthians 11:25) 
Three times I was beaten with rods, I was stoned once, three times I was shipwrecked, and I have spent a night and a day in the open sea.

(2 Corinthians 11:26) 
In journeys often, dangers from rivers, dangers from robbers, dangers from my own people, dangers from Gentiles, dangers in the city, dangers in the wilderness, dangers at sea, dangers among false brothers.

(2 Corinthians 11:27) 
In labor and hardship, through sleepless nights, in hunger and thirst, often in fasting, in cold and nakedness.

(2 Corinthians 11:28) 
And besides other things, there is the daily pressure on me of my anxiety for all the churches.

(2 Corinthians 11:29) 
Who is weak, and I am not weak? Who is led into sin, and I do not burn with anger?

(2 Corinthians 11:30) 
If I must boast, I will boast of the things that show my weakness.

(2 Corinthians 11:31) 
The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who is blessed forever, knows that I am not lying.

(2 Corinthians 11:32) 
In Damascus the governor under King Aretas was guarding the city of Damascus in order to arrest me.

(2 Corinthians 11:33) 
But I was let down in a basket through a window in the wall and escaped his hands.

(2 Corinthians 12:1) 
It is necessary for me to boast, though I shouldn't. But I will now speak about the visions and revelations of the Lord.

(2 Corinthians 12:2) 
I know a man in Christ, who was taken up fourteen years ago to the third atmosphere—I do not know whether in the body, or out of the body, God knows.

(2 Corinthians 12:3) 
And I know that this man, whether in the body or out of the body, I do not know, God knows,

(2 Corinthians 12:4) 
was snatched up into Paradise. He heard things that cannot be spoken, that no man is allowed to utter.

(2 Corinthians 12:5) 
I will boast about this man. I will not boast about myself, except in my weaknesses.

(2 Corinthians 12:6) 
For even if I wanted to boast, I would not be foolish, for I will speak the truth. But I forbear, lest any man should think of me above that which he sees in me, or that he hears of me.

(2 Corinthians 12:7) 
And lest the magnitude of the revelations should lift me up, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, an angel of Satan, to buffet me.

(2 Corinthians 12:8) 
Concerning this, I besought the Lord thrice, that it might depart from me.

(2 Corinthians 12:9) 
And He said to me: “My grace is sufficient for you, for power is made perfect in weakness.” Gladly therefore will I glory in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may dwell in me.

(2 Corinthians 12:10) 
Therefore, I take pleasure in infirmities, in reproaches, in necessities, in persecutions, in distresses for Christ's sake. For when I am weak, then I am strong.

(2 Corinthians 12:11) 
I have become foolish, you have compelled me. For I ought to have been recommended by you: for I was no way inferior to the most eminent apostles, although I am nothing.

(2 Corinthians 12:12) 
For the signs of an apostle were wrought among you, in all patience, in signs, and wonders, and mighty deeds.

(2 Corinthians 12:13) 
For what is there that you were inferior to other churches? Except that I myself have not been a burden to you. Forgive me this injury.

(2 Corinthians 12:14) 
Behold, I am ready to come to you the third time, and I will not be a burden to you. For I seek not yours, but you. For neither ought the children to lay up for the parents, but the parents for the children.

(2 Corinthians 12:15) 
But I most gladly will spend and be spent for your souls. Though loving you more, I am loved less.

(2 Corinthians 12:16) 
But be it so: I did not burden you: but, being crafty, I caught you with guile.

(2 Corinthians 12:17) 
Did I then make a gain of you by any of them whom I sent to you?

(2 Corinthians 12:18) 
I desired Titus, and I sent a brother with him: did Titus make a gain of you? Did we not walk in the same spirit? Did we not walk in the same steps?

(2 Corinthians 12:19) 
Do you think that all along we are excusing ourselves to you? In the sight of God we speak in Christ: but all things, dearly beloved, for your edification.

(2 Corinthians 12:20) 
For I fear lest, when I come, I shall not find you such as I would, and that I shall be found by you such as you would not. Lest perhaps contentions, jealousies, angers, quarrels, detractions, whisperings, swellings of pride, seditions:

(2 Corinthians 12:21) 
Lest, when I come again, God humiliate me among you: and I mourn many of those who before have sinned and have not done penance for the uncleanness and fornication and lasciviousness that they have committed.

(2 Corinthians 13:1) 
This is the third time I am coming to you. Every matter must be confirmed by the word of two or three witnesses.

(2 Corinthians 13:2) 
I have said this before to those present, and I will say it again to those who are not here, that if I come again, I will not spare you,

(2 Corinthians 13:3) 
because you seek proof that Christ is speaking through me. Christ is not weak in you, but rather, He is strong in you.

(2 Corinthians 13:4) 
For even though He was crucified in weakness, He lives by the power of God. For we also are weak in Him, but we will live with Him by the power of God within you.

(2 Corinthians 13:5) 
Test yourselves to see if you are living in the faith. Examine yourselves. Or do you not know this about yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you, unless you are reprobate?

(2 Corinthians 13:6) 
But I trust that you will recognize that we are not reprobate.

(2 Corinthians 13:7) 
And we pray to God that you may do no evil, not that we should appear approved, but rather, that you should do what is good, even if we are considered reprobate.

(2 Corinthians 13:8) 
For we can do nothing against the truth, but only for the truth.

(2 Corinthians 13:9) 
For we rejoice when we are weak: we pray for your perfection.

(2 Corinthians 13:10) 
Therefore, I write these things while absent, so that when I am present, I do not have to act severely, according to the power which the Lord gave me for building up, and not for destroying.

(2 Corinthians 13:11) 
Finally, brothers, rejoice, be perfect, be comforted, be of one mind, have peace, and the God of peace and love will be with you.

(2 Corinthians 13:12) 
Greet one another with a holy kiss.

(2 Corinthians 13:13) 
All the saints greet you.

(2 Corinthians 13:14) 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all. Amen.

(Galatians 1:1) 
Paul, a sent one (not appointed by humans, nor through a human intermediary, but through Jesus Christ and God the Father, who raised him from the dead),

(Galatians 1:2) 
and all the brothers who are with me, to the churches of Galatia.

(Galatians 1:3) 
May grace and peace be given to you from God the Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ,

(Galatians 1:4) 
who gave Himself to atone for our sins so that we might be rescued from this present evil world, according to the will of God our Father,

(Galatians 1:5) 
to whom be the glory forever and ever. Amen.

(Galatians 1:6) 
I am astonished that you are so quickly deserting Him who called you to experience the grace of Christ, in order to follow a different gospel;

(Galatians 1:7) 
which is not really a gospel at all; some people are troubling you, and want to change the gospel of Christ.

(Galatians 1:8) 
But even if we, or an angel from heaven, were to evangelize to you anything other than what we evangelized to you, may he be cursed.

(Galatians 1:9) 
As we have said before, so I now say again: If anyone evangelizes to you anything beyond what you have already received, may he be cursed.

(Galatians 1:10) 
Am I now trying to win the favor of men, or of God? Or am I striving to please men? If I were still trying to please men, I would not be a servant of Christ.

(Galatians 1:11) 
For I would have you know, brothers, that the gospel that was evangelized by me is not a human invention.

(Galatians 1:12) 
I did not receive it from any human, nor was I taught it, but it came through a revelation of Jesus Christ.

(Galatians 1:13) 
For you have heard of my former way of life in Judaism: how I persecuted the Church of God beyond measure and tried to destroy it.

(Galatians 1:14) 
And I was advancing in Judaism beyond many of my own age among my people, being more exceedingly zealous for the traditions of my fathers.

(Galatians 1:15) 
But when it pleased Him Who set me apart from birth, and called me through His grace,

(Galatians 1:16) 
to reveal His Son in me, so that I might evangelize Him among the Gentiles, I did not immediately consult with flesh and blood,

(Galatians 1:17) 
nor did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me; rather, I went away into Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.

(Galatians 1:18) 
Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to see Peter, and stayed with him for fifteen days.

(Galatians 1:19) 
But I saw none of the other apostles except James, the brother of the Lord.

(Galatians 1:20) 
In what I am writing to you, before God, I do not lie.

(Galatians 1:21) 
Then I went into the regions of Syria and Cilicia.

(Galatians 1:22) 
And I was still unknown in face to the churches of Judea that were in Christ:

(Galatians 1:23) 
they only heard: “The one who formerly persecuted us is now evangelizing the faith that he once tried to destroy.”

(Galatians 1:24) 
And they were glorifying God in me.

(Galatians 2:1) 
Then after fourteen years, I returned to Jerusalem with Barnabas, bringing along Titus as well.

(Galatians 2:2) 
I went up because of a revelation. I presented the Gospel that I preach to the Gentiles, but I did so privately to those who seemed to be important leaders, to be certain that I wasn't running in vain.

(Galatians 2:3) 
But even Titus, who was with me, was not forced to be circumcised, even though he was a Greek.

(Galatians 2:4) 
This was because of certain false brothers who were secretly brought in. They were trying to find out about the freedom we have in Christ Jesus, to put us back into slavery.

(Galatians 2:5) 
We did not yield to these men for a single hour, nor did we give in to them. We did this so the truth of the Gospel would remain with you.

(Galatians 2:6) 
And from those who seemed to be something, it makes no difference to me what they once were—God shows no partiality. These so-called leaders added nothing to my Gospel.

(Galatians 2:7) 
On the contrary, they saw that I had been entrusted with the Gospel for the uncircumcised, just as Peter had been entrusted with the Gospel for the circumcised.

(Galatians 2:8) 
(For the one who worked through Peter in his ministry to the circumcised also worked through me among the Gentiles:)

(Galatians 2:9) 
And when James, Cephas, and John, who seemed to be pillars, recognized the grace that had been given to me, they gave to Barnabas and me the right hand of fellowship. They agreed that we should go to the Gentiles, and they to the circumcised.

(Galatians 2:10) 
All they asked was that we should remember the poor, which is what I was very eager to do.

(Galatians 2:11) 
But when Cephas came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face, because he stood condemned.

(Galatians 2:12) 
Before certain men came from James, Peter used to eat with the Gentiles. But when they arrived, he began to draw back and separate himself, because he was afraid of those who belonged to the circumcision group.

(Galatians 2:13) 
The other Jews joined him in his hypocrisy, so that even Barnabas was led astray by their hypocrisy.

(Galatians 2:14) 
When I saw that they were not acting in line with the truth of the Gospel, I said to Cephas in front of everyone, “If you, who are a Jew, live like a Gentile and not like a Jew, how can you force Gentiles to live like Jews?

(Galatians 2:15) 
We are Jews by birth, and not sinners from among the Gentiles;

(Galatians 2:16) 
yet we know that a person is not justified by the works of the law, but by faith in Jesus Christ. So we, too, have believed in Christ Jesus, that we may be justified by faith in Christ and not by the works of the law, because by the works of the law no one will be justified.

(Galatians 2:17) 
But if, in seeking to be justified in Christ, we ourselves are found to be sinners, then does that mean Christ promotes sin? Absolutely not!

(Galatians 2:18) 
For if I rebuild what I have destroyed, I become a transgressor.

(Galatians 2:19) 
For through the law I died to the law, so that I might live for God. I have been crucified with Christ.

(Galatians 2:20) 
It is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me. And the life I now live in the flesh I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave himself for me.

(Galatians 2:21) 
I do not set aside the grace of God, for if righteousness could be gained through the law, Christ died for nothing!

(Galatians 3:1) 
O you foolish Galatians! Who has bewitched you, that you should not obey the truth, before whose eyes Jesus Christ was presented, crucified among you?

(Galatians 3:2) 
This only I want to learn from you: Did you receive the Spirit by the works of the Law, or by the hearing of faith?

(Galatians 3:3) 
Are you so foolish? Having begun in the Spirit, are you now being perfected by the flesh?

(Galatians 3:4) 
Have you suffered so many things in vain? If it is indeed in vain.

(Galatians 3:5) 
He therefore who supplies the Spirit to you and works miracles among you, does He do it by the works of the Law, or by the hearing of faith?

(Galatians 3:6) 
As Abraham believed God, and it was accounted to him for righteousness.

(Galatians 3:7) 
Know therefore that those who are of faith, are the sons of Abraham.

(Galatians 3:8) 
And the Scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, announced to Abraham: “In you shall all the nations be blessed.”

(Galatians 3:9) 
Therefore those who are of faith are blessed with faithful Abraham.

(Galatians 3:10) 
For as many as are of the works of the Law are under a curse; for it is written: “Cursed is everyone who does not continue in all things which are written in the book of the Law, to do them.”

(Galatians 3:11) 
But that by the Law no one is justified with God is clear, for “the just man lives by faith.”

(Galatians 3:12) 
But the Law is not of faith, but “he who does them shall live in them.”

(Galatians 3:13) 
Christ has redeemed us from the curse of the Law, having been made a curse for us, for it is written: “Cursed is everyone who hangs on a tree,”

(Galatians 3:14) 
so that the blessing of Abraham might come upon the Gentiles in Christ Jesus, that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.

(Galatians 3:15) 
Brothers, I speak in human terms: even though it is only a man’s covenant, when it has been ratified, no one annuls it or adds to it.

(Galatians 3:16) 
Now to Abraham and his seed were the promises made. He does not say, “And to seeds,” as referring to many, but as to one, “And to your seed,” who is Christ.

(Galatians 3:17) 
Now I say this: The Law, which came four hundred and thirty years later, does not annul a covenant previously ratified by God, so as to make the promise invalid.

(Galatians 3:18) 
For if the inheritance is of the Law, it is no longer of promise; but God granted it to Abraham through promise.

(Galatians 3:19) 
Why then the Law? It was added because of transgressions, until the Seed should come to whom the promise was made, having been ordained through angels in the hand of a mediator.

(Galatians 3:20) 
Now a mediator is not for one only, but God is one.

(Galatians 3:21) 
Is the Law then against the promises of God? By no means! For if a law had been given which could give life, then righteousness would indeed be by the Law.

(Galatians 3:22) 
But the Scripture has confined all things under sin, that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe.

(Galatians 3:23) 
But before faith came, we were kept under the Law, confined until the faith which was to be revealed would come.

(Galatians 3:24) 
Therefore the Law was our tutor in Christ, that we might be justified by faith.

(Galatians 3:25) 
But now that faith has come, we are no longer under a tutor.

(Galatians 3:26) 
For you are all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus.

(Galatians 3:27) 
For as many of you as were baptized into Christ, have put on Christ.

(Galatians 3:28) 
There is neither Jew nor Greek; there is neither slave nor free; there is neither male nor female; for you are all one in Christ Jesus.

(Galatians 3:29) 
And if you are Christ’s, then you are Abraham’s seed, and heirs according to the promise.

(Galatians 4:1) 
I mean, as long as the heir is a child, he is no different from a servant, even though he owns everything,

(Galatians 4:2) 
but he is under guardians and managers until the time fixed by his father.

(Galatians 4:3) 
So too, when we were children, we were enslaved to the basic principles of this world.

(Galatians 4:4) 
But when the time had fully come, God sent forth the Son on a mission by God, born of a woman, born under the Law,

(Galatians 4:5) 
to redeem those who were under the Law, so that we might receive adoption as sons.

(Galatians 4:6) 
And because you are sons, God sent the Spirit of His Son on a mission by God into our hearts, crying out, “Abba! Father!”

(Galatians 4:7) 
So you are no longer a slave, but a son; and if a son, then an heir through God.

(Galatians 4:8) 
However, formerly, when you did not know God, you were enslaved to those who by nature are not gods.

(Galatians 4:9) 
But now that you have known God, or rather have been known by God, how can you turn back again to the weak and beggarly elemental spirits? Do you want to be enslaved to them again?

(Galatians 4:10) 
You observe days and months and seasons and years.

(Galatians 4:11) 
I fear for you, that perhaps I have labored over you in vain.

(Galatians 4:12) 
Become like me, because I also became like you, brothers. I beg you: you have done me no wrong.

(Galatians 4:13) 
You know that because of a physical illness I preached the gospel to you at first.

(Galatians 4:14) 
And though my condition was a trial for you, you did not despise or reject me, but received me as an angel of God, as Christ Jesus.

(Galatians 4:15) 
What has become of your blessedness? For I testify that, if possible, you would have plucked out your eyes and given them to me.

(Galatians 4:16) 
So have I become your enemy by telling you the truth?

(Galatians 4:17) 
They make much of you, but not in a good way; they want to shut you out, so that you will make much of them.

(Galatians 4:18) 
It is always good to be made much of, in a good way, and not only when I am present with you,

(Galatians 4:19) 
My children, for whom I am again in the pain of childbirth until Christ is formed in you!

(Galatians 4:20) 
I wish I could be present with you now and change my tone, because I am perplexed about you.

(Galatians 4:21) 
Tell me, you who want to be under the Law, do you not listen to the Law?

(Galatians 4:22) 
For it is written that Abraham had two sons, one by a slave woman and one by a free woman.

(Galatians 4:23) 
But the son of the slave woman was born according to the flesh, while the son of the free woman was born through promise.

(Galatians 4:24) 
This is an allegory: for these women are two covenants. One is from Mount Sinai, bearing children for slavery; she is Hagar.

(Galatians 4:25) 
Now Hagar is Mount Sinai in Arabia; she corresponds to the present Jerusalem, for she is in slavery with her children.

(Galatians 4:26) 
But the Jerusalem above is free, and she is our mother.

(Galatians 4:27) 
For it is written, “Rejoice, O barren one who does not bear; break forth and cry aloud, you who are not in labor; for the children of the desolate one are more than those of the one who has a husband.”

(Galatians 4:28) 
Now you, brothers, like Isaac, are children of promise.

(Galatians 4:29) 
But just as at that time he who was born according to the flesh persecuted him who was born according to the Spirit, so also now.

(Galatians 4:30) 
But what does the Scripture say? “Cast out the slave woman and her son, for the son of the slave woman shall not inherit with the son of the free woman.”

(Galatians 4:31) 
So, brothers, we are not children of the slave woman but of the free woman.

(Galatians 5:1) 
Be free, therefore! Christ freed us. Do not be enslaved again.

(Galatians 5:2) 
I, Paul, say this: if you are circumcised, Christ will not benefit you in any way.

(Galatians 5:3) 
I testify again to any man who is circumcised that he is obligated to keep the whole Law.

(Galatians 5:4) 
You have been severed from Christ, all of you who try to become justified by the Law; you have fallen from grace.

(Galatians 5:5) 
We eagerly await through the Spirit, by faith, the hope of righteousness.

(Galatians 5:6) 
For in Christ Jesus, neither circumcision nor uncircumcision counts for anything, but only faith working through love.

(Galatians 5:7) 
You were running well. Who stopped you from obeying the truth?

(Galatians 5:8) 
This kind of persuasion does not come from the One who called you.

(Galatians 5:9) 
A little bit of yeast leavens the whole lump.

(Galatians 5:10) 
I am confident in you in the Lord that you will think in no other way; but the one who is troubling you will pay the penalty, whoever he may be.

(Galatians 5:11) 
As for me, brothers, if I still preach circumcision, why am I still persecuted? Then the stumbling block of the cross has been removed.

(Galatians 5:12) 
I wish those who unsettle you would castrate themselves!

(Galatians 5:13) 
For you were called to freedom, brothers. But do not use this freedom as an opportunity for the flesh; rather, serve one another through love.

(Galatians 5:14) 
For the whole Law is fulfilled in one statement: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”

(Galatians 5:15) 
But if you bite and devour one another, see that you are not consumed by one another.

(Galatians 5:16) 
But I say: walk in the Spirit, and do not gratify the desires of the flesh.

(Galatians 5:17) 
For the flesh has desires against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh; for these are opposed to each other, so that you do not do what you want.

(Galatians 5:18) 
But if you are led by the Spirit, you are not under the Law.

(Galatians 5:19) 
Now the works of the flesh are obvious: immorality, impurity, licentiousness,

(Galatians 5:20) 
idolatry, sorcery, hatreds, rivalry, jealousy, outbursts of anger, selfish ambitions, dissensions, factions,

(Galatians 5:21) 
envy, drunkenness, carousing, and things like these. I am warning you, as I warned you before: those who do such things will not inherit the kingdom of God.

(Galatians 5:22) 
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control;

(Galatians 5:23) 
against such things there is no law.

(Galatians 5:24) 
Now those who belong to Christ Jesus have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.

(Galatians 5:25) 
If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.

(Galatians 5:26) 
Let us not become conceited, provoking one another, envying one another.

(Galatians 6:1) 
Brothers, if a man is caught in some sin, you who are spiritual should correct him with the spirit of gentleness, being mindful of yourself, lest you also be tempted.

(Galatians 6:2) 
Carry one another's burdens, and in this way you will fulfill the law of Christ.

(Galatians 6:3) 
For if anyone thinks himself to be something when he is nothing, he deceives himself.

(Galatians 6:4) 
But let each one examine his own work, and then he will have his boasting in himself alone, and not in another.

(Galatians 6:5) 
For each one will bear his own burden.

(Galatians 6:6) 
Let the one who is taught in the word share all good things with the one who teaches.

(Galatians 6:7) 
Do not be deceived: God is not mocked. For whatever a man sows, that he will also reap.

(Galatians 6:8) 
For he who sows to his flesh will from the flesh reap corruption; but he who sows to the Spirit will from the Spirit reap eternal life.

(Galatians 6:9) 
And let us not grow weary in doing good, for at the proper time we will reap, if we do not give up.

(Galatians 6:10) 
So then, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all, but especially to those who are of the household of faith.

(Galatians 6:11) 
See with what large letters I have written to you with my own hand.

(Galatians 6:12) 
Those who want to make a good show in the flesh are the ones who try to compel you to be circumcised, simply so that they may not suffer persecution for the cross of Christ.

(Galatians 6:13) 
For even those who are circumcised do not keep the law, but they want you to be circumcised so that they may boast in your flesh.

(Galatians 6:14) 
But may it never be that I should boast except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world.

(Galatians 6:15) 
For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor uncircumcision is of any avail, but a new creation.

(Galatians 6:16) 
And as for all who will follow this rule, may peace and mercy be upon them, and upon the Israel of God.

(Galatians 6:17) 
From now on, let no one bother me; for I bear the marks of the Lord Jesus in my body.

(Galatians 6:18) 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, brothers. Amen.

(Ephesians 1:1) 
Paul, a commissioned apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, to the holy ones who are at Ephesus, and to the faithful in Christ Jesus.

(Ephesians 1:2) 
Grace to you and peace from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.

(Ephesians 1:3) 
Blessed be God and the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us with every spiritual blessing in the universe, in Christ,

(Ephesians 1:4) 
even as He chose us in Him before the beginning of the universe, that we should be holy and without blemish before Him in love,

(Ephesians 1:5) 
who predestined us to be adopted as sons through Jesus Christ to Himself, according to the purpose of His will,

(Ephesians 1:6) 
to the praise of the glory of His grace, with which He has graced us in His beloved Son.

(Ephesians 1:7) 
In Him we have redemption through His blood, the remission of sins according to the riches of His grace,

(Ephesians 1:8) 
which He poured out on us in all wisdom and prudence,

(Ephesians 1:9) 
making known to us the mystery of His will, according to His good pleasure which He purposed in Him,

(Ephesians 1:10) 
to be carried out in the fullness of time: that He would bring all things together in Christ, those in the universe and those on the earth—in Him;

(Ephesians 1:11) 
in whom also we have obtained an inheritance, having been predestined according to the purpose of Him who works all things according to the counsel of His will,

(Ephesians 1:12) 
so that we who first hoped in Christ might be to the praise of His glory.

(Ephesians 1:13) 
In Him, you also, after listening to the word of truth, the Gospel of your salvation—in Him, after you also believed, you were sealed with the Holy Spirit of promise,

(Ephesians 1:14) 
who is the pledge of our inheritance, with a view to the redemption of God's own possession, to the praise of His glory.

(Ephesians 1:15) 
For this reason I also, having heard of the faith in the Lord Jesus which is among you and your love for all the saints,

(Ephesians 1:16) 
do not cease to give thanks for you, while making mention of you in my prayers,

(Ephesians 1:17) 
that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, may give you a spirit of wisdom and revelation in the knowledge of Him,

(Ephesians 1:18) 
the eyes of your heart being enlightened, so that you may know what is the hope of His calling, what are the riches of the glory of His inheritance in the saints,

(Ephesians 1:19) 
and what is the surpassing greatness of His power toward us who believe, in accordance with the working of the strength of His might,

(Ephesians 1:20) 
which He brought about in Christ, when He raised Him from the dead and seated Him at His right hand in the universe,

(Ephesians 1:21) 
far above all rule and authority and power and dominion, and every name that is named, not only in this age but also in the one to come.

(Ephesians 1:22) 
And He put all things in subjection under His feet, and gave Him as head over all things to the Church,

(Ephesians 1:23) 
which is His body, the fullness of Him who fills all in all.

(Ephesians 2:1) 
When you were dead, because of your sins and failings,

(Ephesians 2:2) 
you lived according to the ways of the world. You followed the devil, the prince of the power of the air, the evil spirit who now works in those who do not believe,

(Ephesians 2:3) 
Like them, we all once lived in the desires of our flesh, doing what our flesh and minds wanted. We were by nature children of wrath, like everyone else.

(Ephesians 2:4) 
But God, who is rich in mercy, because of his great love for us,

(Ephesians 2:5) 
made us alive with Christ, even when we were dead in sins. God saved you by his grace.

(Ephesians 2:6) 
And God raised us up with Christ and seated us with him in the heavens,

(Ephesians 2:7) 
to show in the ages to come the immeasurable riches of his grace in kindness toward us in Christ Jesus.

(Ephesians 2:8) 
For by grace you have been saved through faith, and this is not your own doing; it is the gift of God,

(Ephesians 2:9) 
not because of works, lest anyone should boast.

(Ephesians 2:10) 
For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared beforehand, that we should walk in them.

(Ephesians 2:11) 
Therefore remember that at one time you Gentiles in the flesh, called “the uncircumcision” by what is called the circumcision, which is done in the flesh by hands,

(Ephesians 2:12) 
were at that time separated from Christ, alienated from the commonwealth of Israel and strangers to the covenants of promise, having no hope and without God in the world.

(Ephesians 2:13) 
But now in Christ Jesus you who once were far off have been brought near by the blood of Christ.

(Ephesians 2:14) 
For he himself is our peace, who has made us both one and has broken down in his flesh the dividing wall of hostility

(Ephesians 2:15) 
by abolishing the law of commandments and ordinances, that he might create in himself one new man in place of the two, so making peace,

(Ephesians 2:16) 
and might reconcile us both to God in one body through the cross, thereby killing the hostility.

(Ephesians 2:17) 
And he came and preached peace to you who were far off and peace to those who were near.

(Ephesians 2:18) 
For through him we both have access in one Spirit to the Father.

(Ephesians 2:19) 
So then you are no longer strangers and aliens, but you are fellow citizens with the saints and members of the household of God,

(Ephesians 2:20) 
built on the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Christ Jesus himself being the cornerstone,

(Ephesians 2:21) 
in whom the whole structure, being joined together, grows into a holy temple in the Lord.

(Ephesians 2:22) 
In him you also are being built together into a dwelling place for God by the Spirit.

(Ephesians 3:1) 
For this cause, I, Paul, the one imprisoned for the sake of Jesus Christ for the sake of you who are not Jews—

(Ephesians 3:2) 
Assuming you’ve heard about the special plan of God’s grace, which was given to me for your sake:

(Ephesians 3:3) 
That by a direct revelation, I have come to understand the mystery of the Church—just as I have written briefly above—

(Ephesians 3:4) 
By reading this, you will see my insight into the mystery of Christ.

(Ephesians 3:5) 
This mystery was not made known to those who lived in past generations, but now it has been revealed to the holy apostles and prophets, through the Holy Spirit:

(Ephesians 3:6) 
That the non-Jews are co-heirs and members of the same body, who share in the promises in Christ Jesus, through the Gospel:

(Ephesians 3:7) 
Of this Gospel, I have become a servant, through the gift of God’s grace, which was given to me through the working of His power.

(Ephesians 3:8) 
This grace was given to me, who is the least of all the saints: that I should announce the good news of Christ’s riches to all the non-Jewish nations.

(Ephesians 3:9) 
And to give understanding of what is the plan of this mystery, which was hidden for all time in God, who created all things.

(Ephesians 3:10) 
The purpose of this is that, now, the principalities and powers in the universe may come to know the many forms of God’s wisdom, through the Church.

(Ephesians 3:11) 
This plan was according to the eternal intention, which He made in Christ Jesus Our Lord:

(Ephesians 3:12) 
In Him we have confidence, and through faith in Him, we are free to approach God.

(Ephesians 3:13) 
So I ask that you do not be discouraged by my sufferings for your sake, which is your glory.

(Ephesians 3:14) 
Because of this, I bow my knees before the Father of Our Lord Jesus Christ,

(Ephesians 3:15) 
From whom all family in the universe, and on the earth, are named.

(Ephesians 3:16) 
May He grant that you, according to the riches of His glory, be strengthened with power through His Spirit in the inner self,

(Ephesians 3:17) 
That Christ may dwell in your hearts through faith; may you be rooted and grounded in love,

(Ephesians 3:18) 
So that you may have the power to comprehend, with all the saints, what is the breadth, and length, and height, and depth—

(Ephesians 3:19) 
To know also the surpassing love of Christ, that you may be filled with all the fullness of God.

(Ephesians 3:20) 
Now to Him who is able to do far more abundantly than all that we ask or think, according to the power at work within us,

(Ephesians 3:21) 
To Him be glory in the Church and in Christ Jesus throughout all generations, forever and ever. Amen.

(Ephesians 4:1) 
So I, a prisoner for the Lord, beg you to live a life worthy of the calling you have received.

(Ephesians 4:2) 
Be humble and gentle, be patient, bearing with one another in love,

(Ephesians 4:3) 
make every effort to keep the unity of the Spirit through the bond of peace.

(Ephesians 4:4) 
There is one body and one Spirit, just as you were called to one hope when you were called,

(Ephesians 4:5) 
one Lord, one faith, one baptism,

(Ephesians 4:6) 
one God and Father of all, who is over all, and through all, and in all.

(Ephesians 4:7) 
But to each one of us grace has been given as Christ apportioned it.

(Ephesians 4:8) 
This is why it says: “When he ascended on high, he took many captives and gave gifts to mankind.”

(Ephesians 4:9) 
(What does “he ascended” mean except that he also descended to the lower, earthly regions?

(Ephesians 4:10) 
He who descended is the very one who ascended higher than all the heavens, in order to fill the whole universe.)

(Ephesians 4:11) 
So Christ himself gave the apostles, the prophets, the evangelists, the pastors and teachers,

(Ephesians 4:12) 
to equip his people for works of service, so that the body of Christ may be built up

(Ephesians 4:13) 
until we all reach unity in the faith and in the knowledge of the Son of God, as we mature to the full measure of the stature of Christ.

(Ephesians 4:14) 
Then we will no longer be infants, tossed back and forth by the waves, and blown here and there by every wind of teaching and by the cunning and craftiness of people in their deceitful scheming.

(Ephesians 4:15) 
Instead, speaking the truth in love, we will grow to become in every respect the mature body of him who is the head, that is, Christ.

(Ephesians 4:16) 
From him the whole body, joined and held together by every supporting ligament, grows and builds itself up in love, as each part does its work.

(Ephesians 4:17) 
So I tell you this, and insist on it in the Lord, that you must no longer live as the Gentiles do, in the futility of their thinking.

(Ephesians 4:18) 
They are darkened in their understanding and separated from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them due to the hardening of their hearts.

(Ephesians 4:19) 
Having lost all sensitivity, they have given themselves over to sensuality so as to indulge in every kind of impurity, and they are full of greed.

(Ephesians 4:20) 
That, however, is not the way of life you learned

(Ephesians 4:21) 
when you heard about Christ and were taught in him in accordance with the truth that is in Jesus.

(Ephesians 4:22) 
You were taught, with regard to your former way of life, to put off your old self, which is being corrupted by its deceitful desires;

(Ephesians 4:23) 
to be made new in the attitude of your minds;

(Ephesians 4:24) 
and to put on the new self, created to be like God in true righteousness and holiness.

(Ephesians 4:25) 
Therefore each of you must put off falsehood and speak truthfully to your neighbor, for we are all members of one body.

(Ephesians 4:26) 
“In your anger do not sin”: Do not let the sun go down while you are still angry,

(Ephesians 4:27) 
and do not give the devil a foothold.

(Ephesians 4:28) 
Anyone who has been stealing must steal no longer, but must work, doing something useful with their own hands, that they may have something to share with those in need.

(Ephesians 4:29) 
Do not let any unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen.

(Ephesians 4:30) 
And do not grieve the Holy Spirit of God, with whom you were sealed for the day of redemption.

(Ephesians 4:31) 
Get rid of all bitterness, rage and anger, brawling and slander, along with every form of malice.

(Ephesians 4:32) 
Be kind and compassionate to one another, forgiving each other, just as in Christ God forgave you.

(Ephesians 5:1) 
So, become imitators of God, as beloved children.

(Ephesians 5:2) 
And walk in love, just as Christ loved us, and offered Himself for us, an offering and sacrifice to God for a pleasing fragrance.

(Ephesians 5:3) 
But fornication and every impurity or greed, let it not even be named among you, as is fitting for saints.

(Ephesians 5:4) 
Or indecency, or foolish talk, or obscenity, which are not becoming, but rather thanksgiving.

(Ephesians 5:5) 
For know and understand this: that every fornicator or impure person or the greedy, who is a servant of idols, does not have an inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God.

(Ephesians 5:6) 
Let no one deceive you with empty words, for because of these things comes the wrath of God upon the sons of disobedience.

(Ephesians 5:7) 
Therefore, do not be partakers with them.

(Ephesians 5:8) 
For you were once darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk as children of light.

(Ephesians 5:9) 
(for the fruit of light is in all goodness and justice and truth),

(Ephesians 5:10) 
proving what is pleasing to God.

(Ephesians 5:11) 
And do not share in the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather reprove them.

(Ephesians 5:12) 
For the things done by them in secret, it is shameful even to speak of.

(Ephesians 5:13) 
But all things that are reproved are made manifest by the light.

(Ephesians 5:14) 
For everything that is made manifest is light.

(Ephesians 5:15) 
Therefore, it says: "Awake, you who sleep, and arise from the dead, and Christ will enlighten you."

(Ephesians 5:16) 
See, therefore, brothers, how carefully you walk: not as unwise,

(Ephesians 5:17) 
but as wise, redeeming the time, because the days are evil.

(Ephesians 5:18) 
Therefore, do not become foolish, but understanding what the will of God is.

(Ephesians 5:19) 
And do not be drunk with wine, in which is debauchery, but be filled with the Holy Spirit,

(Ephesians 5:20) 
speaking to yourselves in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody in your hearts to the Lord,

(Ephesians 5:21) 
giving thanks always for all things in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ to God and the Father:

(Ephesians 5:22) 
Be subject to one another in the fear of Christ.

(Ephesians 5:23) 
Wives, be subject to your husbands, as to the Lord.

(Ephesians 5:24) 
For the husband is the head of the wife, as Christ is the head of the Church: He is the Savior of His body.

(Ephesians 5:25) 
But as the Church is subject to Christ, so also let wives be to their husbands in all things.

(Ephesians 5:26) 
Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the Church, and gave Himself up for her,

(Ephesians 5:27) 
that He might sanctify her, cleansing her by the washing of water with the word of life,

(Ephesians 5:28) 
that He might present her to Himself a glorious Church, not having spot or wrinkle or any such thing, but that she should be holy and without blemish.

(Ephesians 5:29) 
So also husbands should love their wives as their own bodies. He who loves his wife loves himself.

(Ephesians 5:30) 
For no one ever hated his own flesh: but nourishes and cherishes it, as also Christ does the Church:

(Ephesians 5:31) 
because we are members of His body, of His flesh and of His bones.

(Ephesians 5:32) 
“Therefore a man shall leave his father and his mother and be joined to his wife, and the two shall become one flesh.”

(Ephesians 5:33) 
This is a great mystery, and I mean in Christ and in the Church.

(Ephesians 6:1) 
Children, obey your parents in the Lord; this is right.

(Ephesians 6:2) 
“Honor your father and your mother.” This is the first commandment with a promise:

(Ephesians 6:3) 
“that it may be well with you and that you may live long on the earth.”

(Ephesians 6:4) 
And, you fathers, do not provoke your children to wrath, but bring them up in the discipline and correction of the Lord.

(Ephesians 6:5) 
Slaves, be obedient to those who are your masters according to the flesh, with fear and trembling, in the simplicity of your heart, as to Christ:

(Ephesians 6:6) 
Not serving to the eye, as pleasing men, but as servants of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart,

(Ephesians 6:7) 
Serving with good will as to the Lord, and not to men:

(Ephesians 6:8) 
Knowing that whatever good anyone does, this he will receive from the Lord, whether slave or free.

(Ephesians 6:9) 
And, you masters, do the same things to them, remitting threats, knowing that both theirs and yours is the Lord in heaven, and there is no respect of persons with Him.

(Ephesians 6:10) 
For the rest, be strengthened in the Lord and in the power of His might.

(Ephesians 6:11) 
Put on the armor of God, that you may be able to stand against the deceits of the devil.

(Ephesians 6:12) 
For we are not wrestling against flesh and blood, but against principalities and powers, against the world rulers of this darkness, against the spiritual wickedness in the high places.

(Ephesians 6:13) 
Therefore, take up the armor of God, that you may be able to resist in the evil day and, being perfect in all things, to stand.

(Ephesians 6:14) 
Stand, therefore, having your loins girt about with truth and having put on the breastplate of justice,

(Ephesians 6:15) 
And having your feet shod with the preparation of the gospel of peace:

(Ephesians 6:16) 
In all things, taking up the shield of faith, with which you may be able to extinguish all the fiery darts of the wicked one.

(Ephesians 6:17) 
And take the helmet of salvation and the sword of the Spirit (which is the word of God).

(Ephesians 6:18) 
By every prayer and supplication, praying at all times in the spirit, and in this watching with all insistence and supplication for all the saints:

(Ephesians 6:19) 
And for me, that speech may be given to me, in the opening of my mouth, with confidence to make known the mystery of the gospel:

(Ephesians 6:20) 
For which I am an ambassador in a chain, so that I may dare to speak it, as I ought to speak.

(Ephesians 6:21) 
But that you also may know the things concerning me, and what I am doing, Tychicus, the most beloved brother and a faithful minister in the Lord, will make all things known to you:

(Ephesians 6:22) 
Whom I have sent to you for this very thing, that you may know the things concerning us, and that he may comfort your hearts.

(Ephesians 6:23) 
Peace to the brethren, and love with faith from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.

(Ephesians 6:24) 
Grace with all those who love our Lord Jesus Christ in incorruption. Amen.

(Philippians 1:1) 
Paul and Timothy, servants of Jesus Christ, send greetings to all the holy ones in Christ Jesus who are at Philippi, including their overseers and those who serve them.

(Philippians 1:2) 
May grace and peace be granted to you by God our Father and by the Lord Jesus Christ.

(Philippians 1:3) 
I thank my God whenever I think of you,

(Philippians 1:4) 
always in my every prayer, I pray with joy for all of you,

(Philippians 1:5) 
because you have shared the Gospel from the very first day until now:

(Philippians 1:6) 
I am sure of this: God, who has begun this good work in you, will carry it on to completion until the day of Jesus Christ.

(Philippians 1:7) 
It is right that I should feel this way about all of you, because I hold you in my heart. You share in God’s grace with me, and you are with me in my imprisonment, and in the defense and confirmation of the Gospel.

(Philippians 1:8) 
God is my witness that I long for all of you with the deep love of Jesus Christ.

(Philippians 1:9) 
And I pray that your love may overflow more and more, with knowledge and with all insight,

(Philippians 1:10) 
so that you may discern what is best, and be pure and blameless for the day of Christ,

(Philippians 1:11) 
filled with the fruit of righteousness that comes through Jesus Christ, to the glory and praise of God.

(Philippians 1:12) 
Now I want you to know, brothers and sisters, that what has happened to me has actually served to advance the Gospel,

(Philippians 1:13) 
so that my imprisonment for Christ has become well known throughout the whole praetorian guard and to everyone else.

(Philippians 1:14) 
And because of my imprisonment, most of the brothers and sisters have been encouraged to speak the word of God more courageously and fearlessly.

(Philippians 1:15) 
It is true that some preach Christ out of envy and rivalry, but others out of goodwill.

(Philippians 1:16) 
The latter do so in love, knowing that I am put here for the defense of the Gospel.

(Philippians 1:17) 
The former preach Christ out of selfish ambition, not sincerely, supposing that they can add to my distress in my chains.

(Philippians 1:18) 
So what? The important thing is that in every way, whether from wrong motives or true, Christ is preached. And because of this I rejoice. Yes, and I will continue to rejoice,

(Philippians 1:19) 
for I know that through your prayers and God’s provision of the Spirit of Jesus Christ, what has happened to me will turn out for my deliverance.

(Philippians 1:20) 
I eagerly expect and hope that I will in no way be ashamed, but will have sufficient courage so that now as always Christ will be exalted in my body, whether by life or by death.

(Philippians 1:21) 
For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain.

(Philippians 1:22) 
If I am to go on living in the body, this will mean fruitful labor for me. Yet what shall I choose? I do not know!

(Philippians 1:23) 
I am torn between the two: I desire to depart and be with Christ, which is better by far;

(Philippians 1:24) 
but it is more necessary for you that I remain in the body.

(Philippians 1:25) 
Convinced of this, I know that I will remain and will continue with all of you for your progress and joy in the faith,

(Philippians 1:26) 
so that through my being with you again, your boasting in Christ Jesus will abound on account of me.

(Philippians 1:27) 
Whatever happens, conduct yourselves in a manner worthy of the Gospel of Christ. Then, whether I come and see you or only hear about you in my absence, I will know that you stand firm in one spirit, striving together as one for the faith of the Gospel,

(Philippians 1:28) 
without being frightened in any way by those who oppose you. This is a sign to them that they will be lost, but that you will be saved—and that by God.

(Philippians 1:29) 
For it has been granted to you on behalf of Christ not only to believe in him, but also to suffer for him,

(Philippians 1:30) 
since you are going through the same struggle you saw I had, and now hear that I still have.

(Philippians 2:1) 
If therefore there is any consolation in the Son, if any comfort of love, if any fellowship of the Spirit, if any affection and compassion:

(Philippians 2:2) 
Then complete my joy, by having the same understanding, having the same charity, being of one mind, thinking the same thing:

(Philippians 2:3) 
Let nothing be done through contention, nor by empty glory: but in humility of mind, let each esteem others better than themselves:

(Philippians 2:4) 
Not considering each the things that are his own, but the things that are of others.

(Philippians 2:5) 
For let this mind be in you, which was also in Christ Jesus:

(Philippians 2:6) 
Who, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal to God:

(Philippians 2:7) 
But emptied himself, taking the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men, and in habit found as a man.

(Philippians 2:8) 
He humbled himself, becoming obedient unto death, even the death of the cross.

(Philippians 2:9) 
For which cause also God hath exalted him, and hath given him a name which is above all names:

(Philippians 2:10) 
That in the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of those that are in heaven, on earth, and under the earth:

(Philippians 2:11) 
And that every tongue should confess that the Lord Jesus Christ is in the glory of God the Father.

(Philippians 2:12) 
Wherefore, my dearly beloved, as you have always obeyed, not as in my presence only, but much more now in my absence, with fear and trembling work out your salvation.

(Philippians 2:13) 
For it is God who worketh in you both to will and to accomplish, according to his good will.

(Philippians 2:14) 
Do all things without murmurings and hesitations:

(Philippians 2:15) 
That you may be blameless and harmless, children of God without reproach, in the midst of a depraved and perverse nation: among whom you shine as lights in the world,

(Philippians 2:16) 
Holding fast the word of life: that I may glory in the day of Christ, that I have not run in vain, nor labored in vain.

(Philippians 2:17) 
But if I am to be sacrificed upon the sacrifice and service of your faith, I rejoice, and congratulate with you all.

(Philippians 2:18) 
And for the same things do you also rejoice, and congratulate with me.

(Philippians 2:19) 
But I hope in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy to you shortly, that I also may be of good comfort, when I know the things concerning you.

(Philippians 2:20) 
For I have no one so of one mind, who with sincere care for you, will care about the things that are of Jesus Christ.

(Philippians 2:21) 
For all seek the things that are their own, not the things that are of Jesus Christ.

(Philippians 2:22) 
But know ye the proof of him, that as a son with the father, he hath served with me in the gospel.

(Philippians 2:23) 
Him therefore I hope to send immediately, as soon as I shall see what shall be about me.

(Philippians 2:24) 
And I trust in the Lord that I myself also shall come to you shortly.

(Philippians 2:25) 
But I have thought it necessary to send to you Epaphroditus, my brother and fellow worker and fellow soldier, but your apostle and the minister of my need.

(Philippians 2:26) 
Because indeed he longed for you all, and was sad, for that you had heard that he was sick.

(Philippians 2:27) 
For indeed he was sick, even unto death; but God had mercy on him: and not on him only, but on me also, that I might not have sorrow upon sorrow.

(Philippians 2:28) 
I sent him therefore the more diligently, that, seeing him again, you may rejoice, and I may be the less sorrowful.

(Philippians 2:29) 
Receive him therefore with all joy in the Lord; and such as these hold in honor:

(Philippians 2:30) 
Because for the work of Christ he came to the point of death, delivering his life, that he might fulfill that which was wanting of your service towards me.

(Philippians 3:1) 
Finally, my brothers, rejoice in the Lord! It is no trouble for me to write the same things to you, and it is a safeguard for you.

(Philippians 3:2) 
Watch out for the dogs! Beware of evil workers! Beware of those who mutilate the flesh.

(Philippians 3:3) 
For we are the circumcision, we who worship God in the Spirit, who rejoice in Christ Jesus, and who put no confidence in the flesh

(Philippians 3:4) 
Though I myself have reason for confidence in the flesh also. If anyone else thinks he has reason for confidence in the flesh, I have more:

(Philippians 3:5) 
circumcised on the eighth day, of the people of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew of Hebrews; in regard to the law, a Pharisee;

(Philippians 3:6) 
as for zeal, persecuting the Church; as for legal righteousness, faultless.

(Philippians 3:7) 
But whatever gain I had, I counted as loss for the sake of Christ.

(Philippians 3:8) 
Indeed, I count everything as loss because of the surpassing worth of knowing Christ Jesus my Lord. For his sake I have suffered the loss of all things and count them as rubbish, in order that I may gain Christ

(Philippians 3:9) 
and be found in him, not having a righteousness of my own that comes from the law, but that which comes through faith in Christ, the righteousness from God that depends on faith

(Philippians 3:10) 
that I may know him and the power of his resurrection, and may share his sufferings, becoming like him in his death,

(Philippians 3:11) 
that by any means possible I may attain the resurrection from the dead.

(Philippians 3:12) 
Not that I have already obtained this or am already perfect, but I press on to make it my own, because Christ Jesus has made me his own.

(Philippians 3:13) 
Brothers, I do not consider that I have made it my own. But one thing I do: forgetting what lies behind and straining forward to what lies ahead,

(Philippians 3:14) 
I press on toward the goal for the prize of the upward call of God in Christ Jesus.

(Philippians 3:15) 
Let those of us who are mature think this way, and if in anything you think otherwise, God will reveal this also to you.

(Philippians 3:16) 
Only let us hold true to what we have attained.

(Philippians 3:17) 
Brothers, join in imitating me, and keep your eyes on those who walk according to the example you have in us.

(Philippians 3:18) 
For many, of whom I have often told you and now tell you even with tears, walk as enemies of the cross of Christ.

(Philippians 3:19) 
Their end is destruction, their god is their belly, and their glory is in their shame, who set their minds on earthly things.

(Philippians 3:20) 
But our citizenship is in heaven, and from it we await a Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ,

(Philippians 3:21) 
who will transform our lowly body to be like his glorious body, by the power that enables him even to subject all things to himself.

(Philippians 4:1) 
So, my beloved brothers and sisters, whom I love and long to see, you who are my joy and crown, stand firm in the Lord, my dear ones.

(Philippians 4:2) 
I urge Euodia and I plead with Syntyche to agree in the Lord.

(Philippians 4:3) 
And I ask you also, my loyal companion, help these women, for they worked with me in the Gospel, along with Clement and the rest of my fellow workers, whose names are in the book of life.

(Philippians 4:4) 
Rejoice in the Lord always; again, I say, rejoice.

(Philippians 4:5) 
Let your gentleness be known to all men. The Lord is near.

(Philippians 4:6) 
Have no anxiety about anything; but in everything, by prayer and supplication, with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God.

(Philippians 4:7) 
And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.

(Philippians 4:8) 
Finally, brothers and sisters, whatever is true, whatever is honorable, whatever is just, whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is commendable, if there is any excellence, if there is anything worthy of praise, think about these things.

(Philippians 4:9) 
The things which you have learned and received and heard and seen in me, these do: and the God of peace will be with you.

(Philippians 4:10) 
I rejoiced in the Lord greatly that now at last you have revived your concern for me; though you were concerned before, you lacked an opportunity.

(Philippians 4:11) 
Not that I speak in regard to need; for I have learned, in whatever state I am, to be content.

(Philippians 4:12) 
I know how to be brought low, and I know how to abound. In any and all circumstances I have learned the secret of facing plenty and hunger, abundance and need.

(Philippians 4:13) 
I can do all things through him who strengthens me.

(Philippians 4:14) 
Yet it was kind of you to share in my trouble.

(Philippians 4:15) 
And you Philippians yourselves know that in the beginning of the Gospel, when I departed from Macedonia, no church shared with me in the matter of giving and receiving except you only.

(Philippians 4:16) 
For even in Thessalonica you sent me help more than once when I was in need.

(Philippians 4:17) 
Not that I seek the gift, but I seek the fruit that increases to your credit.

(Philippians 4:18) 
I have received everything in full and have an abundance; I am filled, having received from Epaphroditus the things that you sent, a fragrant offering, a sacrifice acceptable and pleasing to God.

(Philippians 4:19) 
My God will supply every need of yours according to his riches in glory in Christ Jesus.

(Philippians 4:20) 
To our God and Father be glory for ever and ever. Amen.

(Philippians 4:21) 
Greet every saint in Christ Jesus. The brothers and sisters who are with me greet you.

(Philippians 4:22) 
All the saints greet you, especially those of Caesar’s household.

(Philippians 4:23) 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.

(Colossians 1:1) 
Paul, sent on a mission by the will of God, along with our brother Timothy,

(Colossians 1:2) 
to the faithful brothers and sisters in Christ living in Colossae. May grace and peace come to you from God our Father and from our Lord Jesus Christ.

(Colossians 1:3) 
We always thank God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, when we pray for you,

(Colossians 1:4) 
because we have heard of your faith in Christ Jesus and your love for all the saints,

(Colossians 1:5)
